<Author>AnywhereUSA310
<Content>Another Good Stay at the Sofitel I discovered the Sofitel a couple of years ago when I fled the Algonquin (which is down the street) after just one night. (Warning - the rooms at the Algonquin bear no relation to the pictures on the Algonquin's website).On this trip I was staying with relatives in New York when I was struck with the flu and decided to decamp to the Sofitel to recuperate. I will often book through Priceline, but with the flu I knew I was going to be confined to my room, so I did not want to take any chances on getting a bad hotel by bidding for an unknown property on Priceline. So I booked the Sofitel on Expedia.Here are the things I like about the Sofitel.Quiet - it is one of the quietest hotels I have stayed at anywhere. That is saying a lot for a city like New York. On both this stay and on my last stay, I felt like I was the only guest in the hotel and did not hear any street noise or any noise from the other rooms.Window Treatments - great window treatments - you can block out all the light at night.Room size - the rooms are very spacious for New York. (One of the reasons I checked out of the horrible Algonquin back when I first discovered the Sofitel a couple years ago is because of the shoebox size rooms there).Bathroom - as many have commented, the Sofitel has very nice bathrooms. There is a lot of counter space to spread out toiletries and every room has both a separate shower and tub (which is becoming very hard to find in New York since the trend is just to have a large shower - not good if you like a bath).Good lighting - there is more than adequate light to read and work.Some complain that the rooms are bland. It is true that unlike some of the hip boutique hotels, there is no cutting edge design. But I would rather have comfort over cutting edge design and I find the rooms with the simple white duvets and clean lines to have a Zen-like serenity. (Some complain that you just get a duvet, with no top sheet. But that is exactly how I sleep at home since I find top sheets annoying - so chacun 脿 son go没t).If you are looking for a hip, happening hotel, you probably won't like the Sofitel. I find it very sedate. That is a huge plus to me, but could be a minus to you.Anyway back to this stay. Wasn't sure how long I was going to be sick, so booked two nights through Expedia. Got put on the 14th floor (floors 2-14 are the cheap floors) right near the elevator. Didn't matter - it was still dead quiet and I felt like the only guest in the hotel. The room was fine - spacious and sunny with a nice little view (helpful when you are spending your time in bed sick looking out the window). One minor quibble with the room - the flat screen tv is on the desk. There is still room to work at the desk, but if you really wanted a desk where you could spread out, you might be unhappy (not an issue for me because I was too sick to work, but just noting it for business travelers. If you have a really work intensive trip - book a suite - see below).When I still had not recovered from the flu after two nights, I booked an additional three nights at the hotel. Expedia showed no availabiliy, but I was able to book directly (albeit at a higher price than through Expedia - I assume the hotel had higher occupancy on those nights and thus the rate was higher).Although there was nothing wrong with my original room, when I decided to stay an additional three nights, I asked if I could be upgraded. They offered to put me on a higher floor - the rooms are the same, you are just higher up. I asked if they had something bigger. They offered a corner suite for $100 more a night. I hesitated, but then agreed and I am glad I did - best $300 I have ever spent. The suite was really lovely - a big window in the bedroom with a view of the Chrysler building - absolutely beautiful at night. A very large sitting room with another big window, a comfy couch and chair, a large desk (no tv on it - unlike in the regular rooms), a very attractive entry way and a walk in closet. Same bathroom as the original room, except in the suites the tubs are bigger. Made me feel a whole lot better about being sick to be in such a nice environment.Room service - as you can imagine, being sick I made quite a bit of use of room service. Thankfully, unlike at some hotels, room service at the Sofitel operates 24 hours a day, although the after hours menu is quite limited. I find it amusing that people on this website complain about the price of room service at the Sofitel. It's like complaining about rain - it is just a fact of life that room service in a big city hotel is expensive. (And room service at the Sofitel is cheaper than at some other New York hotels such as the Grand Hyatt and the Royalton). Anyway, I didn't think the room service menu was very imaginative and the food was okay, but not great. Room service was prompt and everything was nicely plated. If you order tea, be sure to ask them to bring the hot water in a metal pourer rather than in the tea pot as the water will stay hot quite a bit longer even though the pourer is not as pretty as the tea pot. The Sofitel uses a good quality tea bag for their tea service. But It would have been much nicer to have loose leaf tea (which, alas, seems to be asking too much at 99.9% of hotels). (If you want loose leaf tea, however, you can get it next door to the Sofitel at the restaurant in the Iriquois Hotel).One final word - avoid using the Sofitel's dry cleaner. They ruined a favorite knit top I gave them by shrinking it so it no longer fit. The hotel refunded my money for the dry cleaning, but that was small consolation for a ruined favorite article of clothing. And items that I gave to launder while not irrevocably ruined came back faded and stiff. They really need to improve the laundry service - avoid it at all costs.  
<Date>Feb 15, 2008
<Rating>5	5	5	5	5	4	4	-1	

<Author>rover54
<Content>Great Location for a first visit to NY We had never stayed in New York before and so have nothing to compare the Sofitel with, and it seems that all well placed hotels are eye-wateringly expensive.The Sofitel is superbly located for tourists, with Times Square/Broadway, the Empire State and Central Park all with 5-15 minutes walk in different directions. Despite its central location, the street the hotel is located on is quite quiet. Our standard room was a good size, spotless, with a very comfortable bed and large bathroom. The restaurant is 'French' but the menu seems to be the same every night. However there are numerous options within a short walk, both 'upmarket' and more basic. Breakfast at the hotel is good, but most days we ate at the Red Flame, a basic diner about two minutes walk away. The food is half the price and you get a taste of more typical New York life.Some reviews mention building noise. There is building work going on nearby and some noise does reverberate up through the hotel, but this is only during the day, when you spend little time in your room.Even walking back to the hotel past midnight we felt very safe - safer than in the average UK city centre after midnight.In summary this is a superbly located hotel, especially for tourists. It is expensive, but so it seems are its competitors. The hotel is of good quality in every way, the only downside for us being a restaurant menu that didn't change.If we go back to New York, we would stay here again without hesitation.  
<Date>Feb 15, 2008
<Rating>5	3	5	5	5	5	5	-1	

<Author>TheBigFourOh
<Content>Superb in the snow We booked our stay in the strength of previous reviews and the high ranking the hotel has, when compared to all the other hotels available. We are so glad we did. What a find!!. Hotel is oppulently decorated with a flower display in the lobby (at the time of our visit) all red roses amd white flowers to celebrate Valentine's day (ahh!). Our room was on the 19th floor (ask for a high room) and the view from the rooms, whilst in our case was not picture postcard, were fascinating nonetheless for all of the different styles of buildings we could see. And from this floor we could see a lot. In any event as we were out of the Hotel from a.m. 'till dark, the view was inconsequential. The rooms are very comfortable, the beds more so and everything in them you need - the mini bar was used but if the rooms also included tea or coffee making facilities it would have been better. Hotel bar quite pricey, but at a guess i would say no more than other 4 star hotels. Within walking distance of Times Square, Chrysler Building, G C Station, Macy's, Bloomingdales - all the theatres of Broadway.The staff all were affable and friendly; even when it snowed we were asked if we'd like to borrow an umbrella. My tip to pass on would be that when returning to the airport ask the doorman to get you a cab- he'll ask you whether you'd like a yellow cab or a Town car. The Town car costs $10 more than a yellow cab, but is infintley more luxurious and perfectly safe as the drivers and their care are all connected with the Hotel.

<Author>tabbykins
<Content>Return visit even better than the first Our second visit here in less than a year. The good service started before we arrived as the concierge was very helpful  prompt booking tables at restaurants we had been unable to get into EMailing direct. The concierge reconfirmed these bookings for us when we arrived and we dined at those restaurants without any problems or waits for tables.On arrival at the hotel we were greeted personally by M. Louis Lenglet, the Guests Relations Manager who showed us to our room. I'm not sure whether this was because we were returning guests or because it was my birthday, but he is a charming man  made us feel very welcome  important! We had requested a high floor  were on the 21st with great views of the Chrysler  beautiful Helmsley Buildings. For my birthday, there was a bottle of champagne  some luxury cookies waiting for us  also a birthday card. Nice touch for a special occasion. We had a King Room (Most Prefered catagory on their website) which is very spacious with plenty of wardrobe space. Very quiet  peaceful on a high floor.The location is fantastic for shopping, restaurants etc within easy walking distance. The staff here will do absolutely all they can to ensure your stay is a good one  anything you ask for is attended to immediately. I cannot really add anything to what has already been said in all the other rave reviews other than to say, it's all true. I have not stayed in any other hotels in New York so can't compare but I do know people who've been disappointed or just found their hotels to be ho-hum. So we will stick with the lovely Sofitel for our next visit to this fantastic city, 'If it's not broken, don't fix it'! Tips - as others have said, join the on-line loyaly scheme before you go for perks. The 4pm check out was great for us as we had an evening flight back to UK. You also get a free drink in the bar (ask for your voucher at reception). We used Franciso's Limo service to take us back to Newark. He is excellent  the cost is too. The doorman are great at dealing with all your transportation needs, including a stretch limo for a special treat if you fancy it, at a very bargain price. Sofitel feels like home in New York.

<Author>Tigger73
<Content>Loved it - Already recommended to friends who have booked Believe all the great reviews! You hear the horror stories about NY hotels offering poor service, tiny rooms with lots of traffic noise, shabby rooms etc but this doesn't apply to the Sofitel!The hotel is in a great location in between Time Sq (2 blocks) and Fifth Avenue (1 block) but tucked away from the hustle and bustle. Staff very helpful and polite, rooms lovely and big with beds that you just sink into. We stayed on the 17th floor overlooking 45th and had no trouble sleeping, no traffic noise (apart from the odd siren but it is the city!) and the black out curtains really worked in the morning!Already recommended this hotel to friends who have booked it for April. I don't normally like to re-visit hotels as I think its nice to experience new hotels each time but on my next visit to NY I will be back to the Sofitel.Can't recommend this hotel enough.PS - If its your first visit to NY I can recommend the open top bus tour on your first day, if helps you get your bearings and plan what you want to see and where they are.

<Author>byjove
<Content>Reasonable value for money We stayed in the Sofitel for four nights and it was a good experience overall. Excellent location, clean room, attentive staff, reasonably priced (for New York).The staff is courteous and friendly but has apparently been instructed to market the hotel's Frenchness, and to me at least, the often-heard 'bonsoirs' seem slightly over the top.Some oddities are typically French indeed, such as the main entrance's revolving door which doesn't move until you put your full weight behind it.Our bathroom doors were rather flimsy and couldn't be closed properly, and the ventilator wasn't working well.And now we are nitpicking anyway, the USA Today (free copy) is not up to the hotel's standard 鈥?should be the NYT or WSJ.But these are all minor issues of course.WiFi-access is an extra $10 per day or $40 per month (T-Mobile hotspots, US-wide).The bar/restaurant was uncomfortably warm so we decided not to try it.For lunch, try the nearby Indian restaurant (a 2-minute walk, direction Grand Central) which offers an extensive buffet for $16.98 per person.

<Author>jmason70
<Content>Loved the Sofitel !!!! Sofitel is a beautiful hotel in a very central location on W. 44th Street. It is walking distance to Times Square (about 3 blocks), to Rockefeller Center,Bryant Park,5th Ave and close to the subway. The staff was excellent, very friendly and always helpful. Our room was beautiful, very quiet and had a nice view on the 17th floor. Ask for the highest floor possible. The lower floors don't have much of a view. The bathroom was very nice, mostly marble and had a separate shower, with a candle and fresh flower. Housekeeping kept everything very clean and they even have turn down service with free bottled Avian water at night. The bed was almost too comfortable. The heavy duvet was too warm at night. The only complaint I have is that there was no top sheet to use in place of the duvet. The concierge knows everything about New York and was eager to help and very friendly. The doormen were always friendly and opening doors when we came and went. Drinks at the hotel restaurant bar were good (but expensive). Order the hummus as an appetizer. It was awesome! We just LOVED the Sofitel and will definitely stay there on our next visit to New York. **Tip- If you want to avoid the expensive breakfasts at the hotel restaurant, there is a diner very close to the hotel called the Red Flame. The food is great, inexpensive, and the service is excellent. We ate breakfast there all 4 days while visiting. As you exit the hotel, take a right and the Red Flame is just a short distance down the street on the right.

<Rating>5	4	5	5	5	5	5	4	

<Author>LemonTwist
<Content>Convenient and Comfortably Elegant But Not Luxurious We just returned from a surprise 50th birthday trip to NYC for my husband. The Sofitel was recommended to me by a trusted and well-traveled friend as being conveniently located and comfortably elegant. It was both. The room was really quiet and we found the duvet-covered bed to be perfectly comfortable and cozy. The room was clean, well-kept, nicely organized and tastefully appointed but I wouldn't say it was luxurious---very nice but not luxurious. We arrived to champagne, a personalized birthday cake that was delicious, and a lovely cheese and fruit plate sent by family. I had requested a room with a nice view and we were put in room 2221 facing the Chrysler Building. It was a nice enough view but nothing to write home about. I was a little disappointed to see on the fire evacuation map on the door that our room, though we had booked a deluxe king for a special occasion, appeared to be a smaller version鈥攁t least on that floor. Based on the floor plan it appeared that the 鈥?1鈥檚鈥?on each floor may be smaller versions of the other comparable rooms if the floor plan is the same---worth checking out when you request your room. Room service offerings were nice enough but at the price, it was well worth the effort to venture out. The bar was nice but the staff seemed very disengaged/indifferent---not a smile to be had. A little warmth makes all the difference. In general the hotel staff was perfectly polite but I wouldn't say they were overly warm. The housekeeping staff did a great job as far as I could tell. The various concierges were always happy to assist but I can鈥檛 really say that any of their recommendations hit the mark. I got the feeling that they were recommendations focused on the convenience rather than on the experience which is more what we were looking for鈥攑erhaps we didn鈥檛 adequately convey that. There were several other items that really weren鈥檛 that big of a deal to us but others may feel differently so I thought I would mention them. When we arrived the first evening, it quickly became apparent that the AC was not working. We called engineering and were told that the AC was out due to boiler problems. They said to turn off the air while they were working on it but then they never notified us when the repair was complete and we fell asleep in a hot room on top of the covers. One evening my husband made a run to the ice machine and found it not working. He went to several other floors before finding one that was operating. And lastly, the hotel provides a nice soap, shampoo, conditioner and hair rinse but no bath salts or anything to add to your bath so be sure to bring your own in the event you would like to soak in the tub. All in all, the things I mention as negatives were rather minor in our eyes but had they been tended to, our stay would have been even better. A solidly good hotel in a great location but not extra special.

<Author>BigT71

We booked a prepaid room with a supposed special rate for a preferred room, when we checked in we spent 15 minutes listening to the staff discuss all the rooms they couldn't give us for whatever reason. We were eventually given a room and went on up. The carpets were stained, there were crumbs on the bedside table, the window looked out on to a brick wall......this is a preferred room????? I called down and complained and they miraculously found us a room on the 22nd floor, it did seem smaller and more cramped and as it turned out it was. They moved us again the next day to a more comfortable room.What was so bad? The over all housekeeping i found to be poor, the general areas were not well cleaned, dust everywhere, dirty water in the flower pots etc.. the bedroom was very poorly serviced, i noticed before leaving for the day that there was an item on the floor in the bathroom as well as a piece of paper by the bed on the floor (scrap). The room was cleaned and neither item were even moved, quite how they managed to clean the bathroom and make the bed without even disturbing these items i have no idea! We waited 2 hours and had to make 4 calls to get extra pillows. The bell boy told us to call downstairs to get some complimentary drinking water as none was in the room. Next thing, room service arrive with a bottle of water and a $15 check........i sent them away. Next thing someone lets themselve into the room without checking anyone was there and proceeded to check the mini bar, they left 2 complimentary bottles of water on the floor in the hallway.On one of the mornings we decided to go out and grab some breakfast and then come back to the room and prepare for the day ahead thus i put the do not disturb sign on the door as we left. I can only assume housekeeping noticed this as by the time we returned they had made up the room, this was exactly what i wanted to avoid. I confronted the housekeeper and her response was there was no sign on the door as if there was she couldn't go in, she claimed it was in the room on the floor. I am 100% certain this was not the case.The worst thing about all this was that after several complaints from a guest you would think management would talk to you about it and try to rectify things, not a word. Anyway, my only regret was not staying at the Giraffe Hotel which we stayed at earlier and which was wonderful.I wouldn't be misled by the name and expect quality as in the words of the reception, we are only a 3 star diamond hotelPerhaps i was just expecting too much  
<Date>Jan 5, 2008
<Rating>1	1	2	4	2	2	1	-1	

<Author>Kevin1958
<Content>As good as the reveiws suggest Our first trip to NYC, and we booked the Sofitel based largely on the basis of the reviews we have read on TA.And we were not disappointed. The Hotel is very well positioned and from the moment we arrived we were made to feel welcome by friendly and efficient staff. No delays at reception or indeed at any other time during our 4 night stay. Although this is a large Hotel it doesn't not feel like it. The reception, lobby and bar areas have a comfortable and intimate feel.We would struggle to find anything to criticise. The rooms are large, comfortable and well equipped. The beds were very comfortable with a choice of pillows. Bathroom was spacious and spotlessly clean. Room service was of course pricey but again the service was freindly and efficient. The bar/dining area is a pleasant area to relax in after a hard day's sightseeing, although we did not eat in the Hotel. There is free internet access in the Hotel Lobby, including free printing if you need it. And how about this? On our last day we booked a Town car to take us to the Airport. We would recommned this as the yellow cabs are of variable quality, as are the drivers - just like most other big cities. Our luggage was loaded but the boot (or trunk) would not close properly. The Bell staff and Concierge were immediately on the scene, got us straght into another town car, apologised, and said that would be refunding the cost of the car. We thanked them and said that really wasn't necessary. But they did refund our credit card immediately. Well Done Sofitel - were looking foward to our next visit. Our own recoomdations (and you will never be short of these in New York!):1. Rainbow Room for dinner (or drinks) in the Rockefeller Centre for the best views in Manhatten. Book early2. Morton's Steak house for casual dining in the bar (with light bitesfor Brits/Europeans who aren't used to such large portions)3. Good light lunches/snacks when shopping in Bloomingdales (ground Floor)4. Carmines Italian restaurants for the atmosphere, but not for the food. 5. Tavern on the Green in Central Park for somewhere a bit different. Bit of a Toursit trap, but quirky. All in all a great trip based in a very good Hotel.  
<Date>Jan 4, 2008

<Author>Kittylala
<Content>Fab! My husband and I have just returned from the Sofitel and had an excellent stay. Its in an excellent location - we walked to so many places - the rockerfeller cente, Times Square, Fifth Ave, Central Park. However it is also close to other transport links - subways/ bus stops etc. The room was fab - the bed being the most comfy i have slept in ( besides my own)! I note someone complained it was too soft - why not ask for the matress topper to be removed then?! Bathroom was clean and also quite big - we had a big walk in power shower. If I had one criticism ( very minor one though) of the Sofitel, it was that there were no tea or coffee making facilities in the room.All in all we had an excellent stay and I would not hesitate to return there in the future!

<Author>Danzi
<Content>Wonderful My husband and I stayed at the Sofitel in October as part of our Honeymoon. We had booked it after reading the reviews on Trip Advisor and weren't disappointed. It was perfect!! They also had left us a bottle of champagne and a letter saying that if we needed anything we only had to ask. The staff were all perfectly helpful and friendly and couldn't do enough for us. Some people that have written reviews on this hotel obviously are those kind who always have something to complain about instead of enjoying their holiday.All in all our stay at the Sofitel was the best and made our honeymoon memorable and wonderful....I can't say enough and would love to return one day when we visit New York again.

<Author>Panda86

This hotel is in a perfect location, so close to Times Square. We could see the Chrysler building from our room, and had fantastic roof-top views of the City.The desk were very helpful and we made good use of the free internet in the lobby to hunt down restaurants to try and to plan days out.We can recommend Maxies and Dallas BBQ for great value meals (we failed to finish a meal in either of them they were so big!). <Author>Charlie28
<Content>Disappointed Maybe my expectations were too high. But, for me, the most important features of a NYC hotel are location, noise, view, bed, and shower. The Sofitel has a great location and is extremely quiet. But, completely falls down on the other keys. The bed was too soft. Both my wife and I were anxious to leave after four nights of waking up with stiff backs. And the shower --- I'm still rinsing off soap that the shower's trickle failed to remove. And the hotel lost all cold water one night -- none. No water in the sink, shower or toilet. While we didn't book a premium room -- for the price ($619) I expected at least a street view. Other features were as expected, excellent service, staff, cleanliness, decor, and amenitiesI'd rate the Westin or the London much higher.

<Author>jvtrav
<Content>Great Hotel in NYC As background, we went with our two kids, 9  11 years old for a quick family get away. The good: Every employee was helpful, cordial and treated us in a personalized way (in NYC!!!- weird). The concierges (Vladimir and Rene) and the front desk staff (Vivian and Melissa) went out of their way to make sure that we were well taken care of. The suite (it was an executive suite) had updated furnishings with flat panel TV's and a very clean, updated bathroom. The location is very central within walking distance of Radio City, 5th avenue shopping, Broadway theatres. The not so good: The closet space was very limited... although there were plenty of drawers. The room, despite being a suite, seemed cramped- I guess ok size by NYC standards. Maybe fine for two people but it felt a little small for us with our kids. If you are traveling with kids, perhaps better to get connecting rooms. Overall, this hotel is a little gem. Don't tell too many people- I want to go back, get connecting rooms and enjoy home-style service in NYC!!!

<Author>jmuemos
<Content>Loved the Sofitel! My girlfriend and I stayed at the Sofitel for one night the first Sunday in December for a shopping and sightseeing trip. We loved this hotel. The lobby is beautiful and was very nicely decorated for Christmas. Check-in was a breeze and the front desk staff very polite. The room was very nicely appointed - very clean, well decorated, and the softest bed! It was so comfortable to sleep in after walking all over the city. The bathroom was also really nice - marble with a separate, huge shower and tub. Nice amenities and bathrobes too. The best part of the hotel though was it's great location. You are really only steps away from Times Square, shopping on 5th Avenue, and Central Park is just a few minutes away as well. The room was a bit pricey (and we booked the early, non-refundable rate) but it was definitely worth it. I'd stay there again!

<Author>kecoco
<Content>Loved the New York Sofitel I had not been to New York since 2002 so I did a lot of research for the right hotel. Considerations were price, location and amenities. Located between 5th and 6th Avenue on West 44th this hotel has a great location with easy access to all of Manhattan. I had booked a suite and requested a high floor. The suite was on the 29th floor which is the top floor so my request was granted. The suite had a nice sized living room with pocket doors opening into the large bedroom. The bed and bedding were excellent. The bathroom was one of the best laid out I have seen in New York - great lighting, plenty of counter space and a deep soaking tub and separate walk-in shower. The only room service used was an order of coffee each morning that came within 10 minutes of placing the order. The most important feature of this hotel and all hotels is staff, cleanliness, working ac/heat and the quietness of the room. This hotel gets an A+.

<Author>Bluewater81
<Content>Throughly mediocre I travel a great deal for my work, and as a consequence have stayed in a large number of hotels worldwide, including the Sofitel in Bangkok, Hanoi ( the Metropole) and Paris (Dokhan's). The Sofitel New York was in every respect a clear underperformer in both absolute and comparative terms, from what is, normally quite a dependable chain. The room was okay (just), but it didn't require close inspection to see that it was grubby (heavily stained curtains for example), an ugly emply raw plug left in the wall, a flat screen TV thoughtlessly dumped on the desk, and little attention to detail or style overall. The corridors were frequently littered with the aftermath of room service dinners and there were disturbing building works going on from early in the morning, (a fact the hotel didn't seem to see the need to trouble me with when making the reservation), and which the front desk seemed to regard as par for the course. All this may just about be okay if if you are paying for a three star, but this holds itself out as a stylish top of the range choice, and it's simply not up to the mark. It has a reasonable bar, and in fairness the bed was comfortable. Its principal redeeming feature, however, is its location in midtown, but the hotel itself is second rate. Avoid.  
<Date>Dec 20, 2007

<Author>Steve_Med

<Author>BenW
<Content>Sofitel sooths Stayed here during peak Christmas season. There are many good writeups on here about this hotel. I agree with all the ones that define the hotel as an excellent one. Some pointers:Try to get upgraded to a king room. They are on the higher floor. We did so after one night in a standard room and were not disappointed. Had a nice view of the Chrysler building; close enough to see the gargoyles. As mentioned earlier, the higher you are in this hotel, the better. The staff here is very friendly and goes out of their way to make you happy. This statement does not apply to the inept servers at the hotel bar however. Go elsewhere for libations. Regarding the glowing writeups of the 'Red Flame Diner', I just don't get it. The place is o.k. for breakfast and they are certainly fast with delivery, but it is nothing special. A more interesting choice for breakfast and fast is 'Dishes'. Great quality food, even if the atmosphere is 'cafeteria-ish'; two blocks away. Ask the concierge. We ate at DB bistro (two doors down from hotel) and were sorely disappointed, especially after having eaten at the flagship Daniel two nights before. Of course it is much cheaper, but you can do much better for the money. For those from out of town, NYC water is terrific. It comes from upstate New York and does not have to be treated. Drink it from the taps, you are wasting money otherwise. Yes, it was expensive at $500 a night with tax, but my friends stayed at the Roosevelt for $300 and hated it. This hotel is so worth it. Planning to return in early summer; tres bon.  
<Date>Dec 15, 2007
<Rating>5	4	5	5	5	5	5	5	

<Author>FatBoySteve
<Content>Not as Good as Sofitel London I love the Sofitel in London, and so with a vist to New York up and coming, I thought I would try the New York Sofitel.I booked directly with the hotel, telling them that I would be there before there usual 3pm check in - no problem I was told. As you can guess there was, and due to delays arived at 2:30, only to be told I needed to wait. A swift dicussion with the duty manager sorted things out, but not a great way to start the stay. I had also been promised breakfast, but when I came to check out, this has also been forgotten. Not a great customer focused hotel. The rooms are good, we had an exec suite, which is a corner room with windows on two sides, not the same level of comforts as London ie you have to pay for room service tea/coffee. At over $500 per night I expect to be able to make myself a cup of tea rather than pay an additional $20 + tip !!All in all an OK hotel, good location, near Times Square, but not up to the high standards Sofitel usually set.

<Author>gareththeranger
<Content>Great hotel, great location... We visited NYC as our honeymoon and booked the Sofitel on the basis of TripAdvisor reviews.The location of the hotel is absolutely ideal for mid-town Manhatten. For example, Times Square is 3mins walk away, subway stations the same and the Empire State Building is 5mins walk away. The hotel is smack bang next to 5th Avenue for all you shoppers out there!The hotel itself is beautifully decorated. It's style is French art-deco and this is reflected in the lobby and throughout. All areas of the hotel are spotlessly clean and well-maintained by staff.The concierge and reception desk are especially helpful and the free internet access in reception is also very useful. We checked in late on a Saturday night and the receptionist was incredibly friendly and polite. I had put a request in for a 'high' room for our honeymoon and the hotel obliged and even left us a lovely bottle of champagne in an ice bucket up there! A nice touch!Rooms are immaculate and the beds are really comfortable, plenty of TV channels, mini bar, chaise longe etc and the bathrooms are nicely decorated, well-maintained and spacious. The 'turn down' service, where the staff come in at night and prepare your bed ready for you made me smile each night!We enjoyed a wonderful stay at the Sofitel NYC. I can't comment on the food at the hotel, as we ate out for every single meal, but I would highly recommend this hotel for any type of visitor to NYC

<Author>DINKYorkshire
<Content>Mmmn....Very nice but ............is it me ? I love TripAdvisor, I've not been to New York - When I was booking this place was #1 - What could go wrong?Well nothing really...its just a hotel Yes its a good location, yes they speak french - We were probably in the cheap seats ( floor 9) so the room was ...just a room with a bed, which was ok...a bit soft if anything..in short it was all very nice but nothing special - London price hotel room with same size and same remote service - can t complain but cant rave about it either New York is fantastic though so it kind of doesnt matter A few tips if you've not been before...NY that is - Helicopter rides are ok but the view from the skyscrapers are just as impressive - Talking of big buildings - do not underestimate the queue for Empire state building - Huge - 40 mins at least - View is very big and you've go tto go havent you - but wear comfy shoes and go to the Heartleand brewery bar underneath it to chill out afterwards - Bit touristy but nice people and a decent pint- View from the rockefeller center in my opinion was better because you actually see the empire state building so get a a perspective of just how high up you are - fabulous - if you can do one of them at night and one during the day...really good - We went to Carolines comedy store just off Time square - we fell upon a talent contest type thing that was very good - Good night to relax after a day of sight seeing- Broad way show a must - book early or pay concierge prices - guess what we did ??!! however fabulous seats and a great time was had ( hairspray sunday matinee followed by cocktails what better way to spend an afternoon? )- Buy a Zagats guide for restaurants - Obvious if you know, a real life saver if you dont - As a result of it we ended up in the better class of touristy places reasonably close to the Hotel - Virgils BBQ, and Bardolinas for example both very american and enjoyable - Also went to Les Halles ( Anthony Bourdains spot - Fantastic Friday night ) Red flame diner was ok weak coffee big omelettes and friendly/tip hungry staff, Convenient but nothing special in my opinion - Staten Island ferry is a good thing to do - We did the Gray Line bus tour for 2 days - mixed bag of guides but on the whole a good introduction to manhattan island - Do the Harlem Loop, very interesting .- Wear comfortable shoes, pace yourself on distance but not on the good stuff and please enjoy ...the hotel is just somewhere to sleep

<Author>ShopperUK
<Content>A great stay I booked this hotel after reading the comments on this website. I wanted somewhere really special as this trip, our 4th to NY, was to celebrate my Mother's birthday, we were not disappointed. A speedy and efficient check in, during which we were shown the restaurant and bar. My Mother was also wished a happy birthday, (I had mentioned the reason for our stay when I made the booking). A bottle of sparkling wine was also waiting in our room. A nice touch.Get a sofitel privilege card via their website, this gets you, amongst other things, a free drink and a late checkout (4pm), great if you have an evening flight.The room was great and the beds were so comfortable. We were on the 22nd floor, no city noise and a great view. Towels and bedding were changed daily. A large bathroom with a separate walk in shower. If I had one criticism, it would be there is no tea/coffee making facilities in the room.The hotel is in a great location, near to the shops and sights. Within walking distance of Macy's, Empire State etc. If you want to go to Abercrombie  Fitch, on 5th, go early unless you want to queue!After seeing the comments about the Red Flame we too went there for breakfast. A great start to the day.For my Mother's birthday we booked an evening dinner cruise on the Bateaux New York. This was a great night. Service and food were excellent and some great photo opportunites. Plenty of time between courses to take photos. A great trip and I would definitely stay here agin.

<Author>Janet176
<Content>Fabulous Hotel! My husband and I stayed at the Sofitel New York from the 17th to 21st November and had a fantastice time.We have used Sofitel several times before in Europe and have never been disappointed so we chose this one based on our own Sofitel experiences and the Tripadvisor reviews.After a rather hairy ride into Manhattan in a NY cab we arrived at the front door. (Make sure you pick up a cab from the official stand at JFK - the drivers have to give you their details so you can make a complaint if you need to, and charge a fixed fare of $45 plus tolls and tip). The concierge was straight out to take our luggage and we headed inside for a very swift check-in by very efficient staff.We had a room on the 24th floor with great views, especially at night. The room was spotless and very well equipped - and it's true what they say about the beds!! Heaven!The hotel is very well situated just a stroll away from Times Square where we picked up the Tour Bus. We bought a 48 hour pass with Gray Line which was excellent. OK - so you get caught up in traffic from time to time but you are in the middle of Manhattan!! The Tour Guides were great fun and had loads of little tips and secrets to tell!From the hotel it's easy to get to 5th Avenue, Central Park, The Rockerfella Centre, Empire State Building, Grand Central ... infact most of central Manhattan!We had breakfast at the Red Flame Diner .... massive portions, more than enough to last the day and ate out locally at night. Ruby's, just along Broadway from Times Square was a great place to eat and had a great selection if you wanted to get away from burger and chips!We had drinks in the hotel bar where the staff were very friendly and efficient, infact every member of staff we met greeted us politely as we passed.The free internet in the lobby was excellent - much easier to email everyone than send a postcard - and checkout was quick and efficient.All in all a great stay in New York. I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone.  
<Date>Nov 27, 2007
<Rating>5	4	5	5	5	5	5	5	

<Author>Ryan.W
<Content>Stunned.....not stunning I remain awestruck that this hotel is rated so high by fellow tripadvisor.com travelers. It is surely enough for me to rethink the usefulness of this website; since I made my decision based on the Sofitel's previous #1 ranking here.From start to finish it was one problem after another. I've been so lucky in my past choices that I guess it's time I had a bad experience. Every traveler has his day.Without a doubt the entire visit was marred by the arrival. The doorman stood and talked to a young lady (not a guest) on the street while I unloaded my own luggage, went inside for a bellman's cart and completed the entire process. He was oblivious to my entire existence. When I informed him of my displeasure he then chastised ME. What?Other less than satisfactory areas: room design, room service and restaurant appearence and service. With so many good hotels in New York I would suggest considering other options.

<Author>OCCouple2004
<Content>Fabulous Stay at the Sofitel! My fiance and I stayed at the Sofitel for one week. What a great hotel! The location is perfect. Its about 2 blocks from Times Square and 7 blocks to Central Park. Check in was a breeze, they were able to change our room to a higher floor. The Bed in the room is amazing. There is a restaurant and bar at the hotel, although we didnt vist the restaurant, the bar was great. There was always available seating- and the service was excellent. Another fabulous part of this hotel is the concierge service. Everytime we had a question, if we needed reservations made- they were always there are willing to help. There is a restaurant about 3 doors down; Kellari- highly reccomended!!! Stay at the Sofitel, you wont be disapointed!

<Rating>5	5	5	5	5	5	5	5	

<Author>gerardkelly
<Content>The Perfect Hotel for your visit to New York!! My wife and I returned to the Sofitel for a second time this year and again we were not disappointed. This is a beautiful hotel. The lobby is spacious and very tastefully decorated.The staff are helpful and very friendly. Our room was on the 11th floor and was clean, comfortable and spacious. The marble bathroom is quite large with a walk in shower. The best part however is the bed, it is so comfortable!The hotel is well located on 44th street between 5th and 6th avenues. It's only a 2 min walk to the shops on 5th. (if you're planning to go to Abercrombie and Fitch go early..we had to queue to get in). The hotel is a perfect base for all your shopping/sight seeing needs. You can walk to Times Square, Broadway, Madison Square Garden and Port Authority (to get the bus to Woodbury Common or Jersey Gardens). Make sure to visit the Top of the Rock at the Rockefeller Centre (5 -10 mins walk). The view at night is absolutely spectacular. A visit is a must.We ate breakfast at the hotel on our last morning. It is not cheap but the quality is excellent. Try the blueberry pancakes. For the other mornings we ate at The Red Flame diner on 44th. (Turn right as you leave the hotel, the diner is on the right).Overall this is a top class hotel and I would highly recommend it.  
<Date>Nov 26, 2007

<Author>CheltenhamLady
<Content>Loved the Sofitel We booked the sofitel after reading all the great reviews on this site. We weren't disappointed. This was my 5th trip to NYC, and this was the best hotel I have stayed in, in the city. Even better than the Plaza. The staff were so friendly, the room was a good size (we had a deluxe king) nice shower and the beds were to die for. It is expensive, but then anywhere you stay in New York is. The location was perfect, we could walk almost anywhere. I can also reccomend the red flame diner, the waffles and coffee there are just what you need for a long day in the city. Also the DB Bistro Moderne which we booked for dinner was excellent. We booked it and then realised that it was only 3 doors down from the hotel. Out of the hotel and turn right. Highly reccomend it. Stay here, you will you have a great time!

<Rating>5	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	

<Author>Carollaine
<Content>Second visit just as good as the first! We have just returned from our third visit to New York City and our second visit to Sofitel. I booked it again, hoping against hope that it would still be as good as when we visited in November 2005. It was.Just how they manage to find that calibre of staff I don't know. Without exception they were friendly, helpful, approachable and highly professional in all areas of the hotel.Our check-in was promptly dealt with - one of the Reception Staff took the time and trouble to go up to our room whilst we were checking-in in order to ensure that it was ready for us. As I hold a Sofitel Privilege Card I was able to arrange a late check-out and we were given two vouchers for a glass of champagne or drink of our choice. It is worth applying for a card if you are going to need to check out late - and it gives you ''points' as well!During our first evening we noticed that there was a problem with the plug in our bath (it would not stay upright to allow the water out) and a slightly loose wall lamp fitting. We also found that one of the 'card keys' would not work in our door. I reported it when we went down to breakfast - I was immediately given a replacement 'key' and, by the time we had returned from breakfast, the other small problems had been remedied too.The beds are 'clouds' of comfort - in New York you need comfortable beds after walking all day! They have feather mattresses toppers, and beautiful duvets and pillows. The bedlinen is divine!!Breakfast in the hotel is a 'must'. Yes, the Red Flame Diner along the road is an experience, and is a good and cheap place to eat, but the attention one receives in the Restaurant is insurmountable. One word in the ear of the UK visitors - unfortunately even Sofitel have not yet managed to crack the taste of the Brits for a decent cup of tea!! However, once they had got to grips with the fact that each of us needed three teabags per individual teapot to get it somewhere near proper strength, we never had to ask again - word had got round and, despite the variety of waiting staff we had, three teabags always materialised!Checkout was straightforward - I had already checked my account online on the TV in the room - no inaccuracies at all.Last time we stayed the concierge advised me to book a limo back to JFK. In case it's your first time, you should know that there is a flat rate for yellow cabs from airport to central New York but to do the same journey back would be on a meter. In consequence, and particularly if you are travelling at rush hour as we did, it can turn out to be an enormously expensive business.In consequence we did the same thing this time and asked the concierge to book a limo. This was charged at $124 and could be put on our bill, which we did so that we didn't have to worry about keeping cash available for the journey back. This sounds a lot, but, believe me, it was worth every dime! It covers absolutely everything - tolls, tip, the lot. As it happened New York was gridlocked that evening (just before Thanksgiving) - we moved two blocks in 30 minutes getting out of the City! Our driver was superb - found less congested roads where he could and got us there in time for our flight. We had been advised to order the limo for 4.00 pm for the 7.00 pm flight - fortunately I asked for a 3.30 pm pickup for safety and we finally made JFK at 5.10 pmten minutes late for official check-in! Be warned!! You need to allow plenty of time and I doubt very much whether we would have made it in a yellow cab, and certainly it would have been very costly indeed.Despite what I had been told, clearance both in and out of JFK are very smooth and comparatively quick - certainly quicker and less chaotic than Heathrow.Oh yes - The Rockeleller Centre now has its Observation Gallery open - The Rock at the Top - it is well worth a visit - you can book online or there are booths at the foot of the Centre. It's a wonderful view from there - it IS open-air - we rather assumed it would be enclosed - so wrap up warmly. The elevator is an experience in itself but not for the faint-hearted!Another word of advice - for those who don't know - if you go to the Visitors' Centre in both Macys and Bloomingdales (just off the ground floor of each store) and show your passport they will issue you with a Visitors' Card which gives you 11% discount on everything you purchase in Macys and most things in Bloomingdales. It's well worth it! And also, on the shopping front, be sure to go the Central 21 which is immediately opposite Ground Zero - it has fantastic bargains if you can steel yourself for the nightmare crowds and lack of customer service!It was a wonderful trip - do try Sofitel - it hasn't been top of Trip Advisor's list of recommended NY hotels for nothing - it deserves every recommendation it is given.Enjoy!!  
<Date>Nov 25, 2007

<Author>Swansealady
<Content>Stunning This hotel was superb. On arrival reception staff were very friendly and upgraded us to a king size room as it was our birthdays. The room was lovey, clean, and the bed amazingly comfortable. Bathroom large and clean- separate bath and shower. They brought us water and a box of chocolates every evening for free as well!We also had a free bottle of sparkling wine waiting for us in our room:)The concierge booked our reservations for our evening meals at whatever restaurant we wanted and also phoned to confirm our shuttle bus arrangements to the airport. We didnt have to pay for the use of our room phone to do this. The staff at this hotel couldnt have done more- so helpful and friendly.There is free internet access downstairs in the lobby which is great. May have to wait 5-10 mins if computers are full but this was an added bonus to our trip. We got engaged so could share our photos and write emails to friends and family without it costing.Location is brilliant, 5 mins Times Square and subway. easy access to Macys. Grand Central and accessing subway to travel. Minutes away from Bryant Park which is great to grab a coffee and sit in the sun watching the ice skating.I recommend tavern on the green restaurant for an excellent (pricey) meal. Stunning location in central park. Use the subway as much as posible, it leaves you with more time to do things and it is so easy. The red flame diner is good for a cheap american breakfast though if you go after 9 on a weekend expect to wait 10 mins for a seat. It is always busy in there.I would recommend this hotel time and time again and if I return to NY will stay there again myself without a doubt. Enjoy!

<Author>Jenna781
<Content>Great location! My boyfriend and I stayed at the Sofitel for a long weekend. It was our first time to New York City and this hotel was very close to alot of things so it was well worth it. We heard the rooms in NYC are very small but the Sofitel's accomodations were very nice. We didn't stay in the hotel much seeing as there were lots of things to see and do in the city. This hotel was very close to central park, shopping, times square, and the empire state building. There are also plenty of restaurants around the hotel. We were able to walk to Broadway where we saw the Lion King and highly recommend it. Also check out NoBu and Mercer Kitchen for dining. They were pricey but excellent. You will need to take a cab to shop in Soho, Tribeca, Meatpacking district ect...but cabs are quick and we felt they were less expensive then getting around Chicago. If you like to go out we thought that Hotel Gansevort, PM and Ten June were great places in the meatpacking district. All in all we thought that the Sofitel was the perfect place and location for our first time in New York. I would definitly recommend this hotel but if we went back again we would probably try one of the many boutique hotels in the city just for a different atmosphere.

<Author>KathyOxfordEngland
<Content>Wonderful Stay We stayed at the Sofitel for 6 nights with our three children aged 14, 13 and 4. We had two rooms; a junior suite and a room next door with a shared private hallway. We got all this booked easily over the phone, the staff were very helpful in accommodating us. What a surprise we got when we pulled back the curtains - we arrived in the dark and were blown away by the view of the Chrysler Building. The rooms were large, clean, well equipped and luxurious with fresh orchids. The staff were efficient and friendly, the hotel location is excellent. The breakfast was pricey, thats not unusual. We tried it once then hot footed it to the Red Flame which is practically next door. We also tried the Hard Rock's breakfast buffet (not recommended) and Europa Cafe (ok). I cant emphasise enough how great all the staff were, we had an excellent stay. And the beds are WONDERFUL!!!! Had great sleeps, felt like I was floating.

<Author>aorrdalca
<Content>Understated excellence Considering the prices, one might have expected opulence, which is not what we, at least, experienced. However, the room was bright and modern and quiet and exceptionally clean. It's the details that make this place stand out, particularly on the customer care side: the promptest room service I've yet found, an untiring concierge. Given the ideal location and the generally high price of rooms in NYC, we feel we received good value. One small caveat: when a room costs several hundred dollars, why can't internet access be included? I recognize that the Sofitel is not the only premium property extracting some additional revenue in this manner, but it seems increasingly anachronistic and exploitative.

<Author>RHimelfarb
<Content>Wonderful Hotel!!! My Husband and I took our 2 children (ages 13 and 10) to New York to celebrate our daughter's 13th birthday. We also brought along the grandparents to help celebrate with us. We booked 3 king suites for a 4 night stay (Thursday thru Monday). Our rooms were on the 29th floor which is the top floor of the hotel. There were only 10 suites on the entire floor. Each suite had a slightly different layout. We had a king sized bed in the bedroom with a pull out couch in the living room. There was a tv in the bedroom and the living room. The decor was very fresh and the room was very clean. We had maid service twice daily. There were fresh orchids in the room as well as cold bottled evian water and chocolates left each night. We decided to include the breakfast in our room package. This turned out to be a good choice as the breakfast was delicious. We made an 8:45am reservation at Gaby's for the duration of our stay. We were served freshly squeezed orange or grapefruit juice, coffee/tea and a choice of entree. The food was freshly prepared and always hot. My kids enjoyed the french toast and the nutella pancakes. We required extra bedding for the pullout coaches and it was delivered within 15 minutes. The bathrobes and slippers were a nice touch. The concierge was extremely helpful with suggesting dining options. Rene was more than happy to call any restaurant to make a dining reservation. He suggested a great diner (Brooklyn Diner) which was on 43rd and Broadway. Great family restaurant. Overall, I would not hesitate to recommend this hotel. I would absolutely return to Sofitel on my next trip to New York. You can't beat the location. At 44th in between 5th and 6th Ave you are in walking distance to theatre, dining and great shopping! We walked to Canal Street, Central Park, Macy's, Bloomies and Saks 5th Avenue with no problem. Don't forget to grab a green apple on your way out the door!!

<Author>leedslen
<Content>An oasis of calm and comfort Together with my wife I have just returned from a four night stay at the Sofitel,New York and cannot praise it highly enough. The hotel is situated a five minute walk from Times Square and within walking distance of all the major attractions.On arrival, the check in staff were polite and friendly.We were upgraded to a king size room free of charge and without requesting one.The room was fantastic.The biggest most comfortable bed we have ever slept in,situated on the ninth floor the room was completely silent,We slept like babies.The room was spacious and well furnished, as was the bathroom,with bath and a seperate large walk in shower.Our room was cleaned each day and a turn down service offered each evening.As with all the staff that we spoke with the chambermaids were very friendly and helpful. The room features a safety deposit box and a box of chocolates and water are left each night.As with all city hotels breakfast and drinks at the bar are expensive but we can highly recomend the Red Flame Diner four doors up from the hotel for a hearty breakfast at a good price and with excellent service.This diner is open 24 hours a day, so is a great place for 5am on your first morning when the jet lag wakes you.We could find no fault at all with the Sofitel and would certainly book it again should we return to New York

<Author>YodelsPortsmouth
<Content>Hotel Stay Let Down By Sloppy Mistake As a surprise start to our stay at the Sofitel New York my father had arranged with the hotel for a bottle of champagne (paid for by him) to be in our room on arrival. The champagne, in an ice bucket with glasses, was in the room but the housekeeping staff had forgotten to leave the note he had requested explaining who it was from. So, suspecting that the champagne was not complimentary and with no idea to the contrary, we left it unopened where we found it and there it stayed for the week of our stay and that was how it was left on our departure. Bizarrely, although housekeeping were (obviously) in our room on a regular basis, no one thought to enquire why we hadn't enjoyed our bottle of champagne. Confirming our thoughts, of course, that it wasn't complimentary. You can imagine our disappointment on our arrival back in the UK to discover we could have enjoyed that bottle of champagne - at any time during our stay! On phoning the hotel, guest relations apologised (as one might hope) and said they would refund my father the cost of the bottle of champagne - the least they could do! However, that could not change the fact that we'd missed out on what would have been a lovely start to our holiday. Also, on check in at the hotel, I was told my credit card would be charged $700 at that time for those additional services (mini-bar, telephone calls etc) that we might use during our stay. I said I did not object to paying for these things after our stay, clearly, but thought it unacceptable that my card would be charged in advance for services I might not use. Because of my objection, the 'pre-charge' was revised to $300 but it was not the best start to our stay. In the event, we ended up only making $15 worth of phone calls which I paid for in cash. These two experiences let down a stay at what was otherwise a pleasant and comfortable hotel.  
<Date>Sep 23, 2007

<Author>nuttah
<Content>5 star luxury if you are prepared to pay for it Booked this 5 star hotel for my husbands 50th birthday. Check in was smooth and professional. But the Red Coffee House just along from the hotel does amazing pancakes for $9.Check out was excellent - we had to leave at 5am as we had a day flight back to London. <Author>aeroeng
<Content>Perfect Engagement Stay My girlfriend (now fiance) and I spent a night at the hotel for a romantic couple of days in New York. What can I say--it was the best hotel experience that either of us has ever had. We entered the lobby which was full of friendly employees and thousands of beautiful, freshly cut flowers. The smell was amazing. Upon check-in, I had requested a high floor, non-smoking. The clerk informed me that for the rate I had requested, he could only give me up to the 10th floor, but he assured me that I would hear no noise. So after our 5 minute check in, we were whisked to the 10th floor where we found our beautiful corner room. The room seemed to be large by New York standards, and had two sitting chairs, a Queen sized bed, a nice wardrobe, all the amenities you would expect from a four star hotel. The bathroom was exquisitie. There was a separate tub and shower, and it was one of the largest I had seen. There was even a freshly cut orchid on the counter. The decorating scheme of the apartment was modern, but warm, and every detail was taken into consideration. Needless to say, my fiance was impressed and we definately hope to revisit the Sofitel New York.

<Author>JJ25
<Content>Gret hotel in a great location I stayed at the sofitel for 4 nights in early september as part of a birthday celebration. I'd booked a suite which was fantastic - loads of room, huge bed and masses of storage space. We got a good deal on the room through the hotel site. On our first day we received a bottle of bubbly to say happy b'day from the hotel which was a lovely touch. The hotel restaurant is quite expensive for breakfast, though the blueberry pancakes we had on the 1st day were fantastic!. The service in the hotel was great - check in was very smooth and the room service and help from the concierge was brilliant. We were also allowed a late check out as we weren't leaving for the airport until 4pm.There's a diner (The red flame grill) just down the street and we used that for breakfast most mornings - there's a huge choice on the menu and the service is very efficient. The hotel is between 5th and 6th avenues and you only need to walk 2 blocks to reach times square, which is completely mad, esp. on the weekend. I'd recommend the View restaurant on top of the marriott Marquis hotel in time square - it rotates round and gives some great views of the city plus some lovely food and good service.The hotel arranged a private car to pick us up and take us back to the airport. This is about $50 more expensive than a taxi but well worth the extra money for the comfort and ease of journey.I'd definitly recommend this hotel to anyone who wants somewhere with good service, in a great location with lovely rooms. I was sad to leave on our last day - but will hopefully be back soon.

<Rating>3	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	

<Author>Keiichi73
<Content>A rough start, but a smooth finish For my recent New York theater trip, I decided to stay at the Sofitel due to the reviews and the fact that it was ranked #1 in the city on this site at the time. When its popularity began to drop, and mediocre to lukewarm reviews started popping up more frequently, I started to worry that perhaps the hotel was going downhill somewhat right before I was about to arrive. Fortunately, although my stay had a rough start, the friendly and eager to please staff were willing to go out of their way to make my visit enjoyable.I had booked a King Executive Suite after I found a great deal on the Sofitel website where the room was only a little over $100 more overall (including tax) than I would have paid for a standard room. I arrived at the hotel, and was informed by the front desk clerk that they had prepared for me a room on the top floor of the building with a view of both the Empire State and Chrysler Buildings. I anxiously headed for the elevator, looking forward to experience my room, only to be met with disappointment. While the room seemed nice at first glance, there were a number of small problems. For one thing, the window shades were broken, and would not go up. What's the point of having a top floor room if you can't enjoy the city view?? Furthermore, the closet door was broken, and would not close all the way unless you forcefully pushed it three or four times. The television remote was tempermental, and seemed to work only when it felt like it. There were numerous other small technical problems in the bathroom as well.I eventually went back down to the front desk to inform them of the many problems. The staff was greatly apologetic, and I was eventually moved to a corner suite on the 12th floor. It wasn't as high up as the previous room, but it was a lot bigger, a lot nicer, and most importantly, everything was working the way it should be. After I checked into this room, my stay went a lot smoother, and I was finally able to enjoy my experience. This really is a lovely hotel with a staff that not only listens to you, but will go out of their way to make you happy, and answer any question you have. The room itself is very clean due to the fact you get two housekeeping visits each day. (They never actually bothered me or walked in on me, though.) Almost everything in the room is of the highest quality, from the sheets on the bed right down to the toilitries found in the bathroom. Speaking of the beds, while I agree with everyone else that it was one of the softest hotel beds I've ever slept on, they were perhaps a bit too soft for my liking. I would have liked just a little bit more firmness and support, but that's just me, since everyone else here seems to rave about them. I always slept well, I just had a hard time finding a firm spot that I could fall asleep on.The location of the hotel is located just off of Times Square and Broadway, so you're within walking distance to the heart of the city without actually having to be there. I've stayed in hotels in the Times Square area, and would sometimes step outside the front door of the building, only to be met with a wall of people walking past me, making exiting the hotel difficult. This never happened at the Sofitel, as it's located far enough away to avoid heavy crowds. It's still centrally located, however, and in walking distance to all the shopping, subways and transporation, theater, and sights that most are looking for when they stay in that part of town. There are even two movie theaters in close walking distance from the hotel, so you'll never be lacking in entertainment. The 7 Broadway shows that I saw on my trip (Spring Awakening, Curtains, Deuce, Legally Blonde, The Year of Magical Thinking, Frost/Nixon, Mary Poppins) were all about a 10-15 minute walk away. There are also a number of restaurants in the local area, which means you most likely won't have to resort to paying the outrageous prices the Sofitel charges for room service unless you really want to. There is a restaurant in the building, but I never ate there. I did visit the bar on most nights, though, and found the atmosphere very warm and friendly.I really don't know what went wrong with my first room. Maybe it hadn't been rented out to anyone for a while, or maybe previous guests just didn't complain and put up with it. Whatever the case, the staff succeeded in making my stay memorable after a rough start. I'll be returning to New York in December and will be staying at The Michelangelo Hotel. But, if the chance ever presents itself, I would stay at the Sofitel again. Yes, it has some rough edges here and there (The TVs in the rooms look like they're from the early or mid 90s and should really be replaced.), but for the most part, I had a good experience.  
<Date>Aug 14, 2007
<Rating>4	3	4	4	5	5	5	5	

<Author>jack06
<Content>Fantastic Location, can't beat it! I recently stayed at the Sofitel for 5 nights. Like others, I don't want to repeat the many great reviews already below, but would like to recommend the hotel.The hotel is in an excellent location, near the Theatre district. Within walking distance of fabulous shopping and many tourist attractions. Time Square is only a 2 minute walk away.The hotel itself is lovely, beautiful rooms, very friendly stuff (particlarly the concierge), who helped us booked a helicopter flight over New York, and had many great restaurant recommendations!The food is great, both the room service and the restaurant. Great if you've had a really long day and just can't be bothered eating out!Definetly recommend joining the Sofitel Privillege Club when you arrive, as this entitles you to a complimentary cocktail during your stay, and a 4pm checkout. Very handy indeed when flying home in the early evening.

<Author>fanmailer
<Content>Management with an attitude This was our first stay at the Sofitel Hotel NYC. When we arrived late after a delayed flight, we were pleasantly surprised by the friendly night staff, clean hotel and lobby, and large and spotless room on the 26th floor. This hotel is on a quiet and somewhat dark (dingy?) street, but it serves well to escape the bustle of the city. Great shopping and Times Square are a very easy walk (5-10min). Exercise facility is small but cool and clean. There is not much of a 鈥渓obby feel鈥濃€ore like a hallway鈥ut who cares unless you鈥檙e with a large group. Even the cleaning people and bellmen were very personable. This appeared to be a well-trained staff! Small issues...not enough hangers, bathroom doors open out into closet area, no privacy for toilet when someone else is in the bathroom. The design could have been thought out better. The main issue for us...the front desk management. This hotel is not cheap, and there are plenty of choices in the city for the $500+ prices we paid at a 鈥渨eekend getaway鈥?rate. When we checked in we noted that the Sofitel website internet rate that we booked 2 months ago had now dropped (a grand total of $55 for our $2500 four day stay). So we asked for a credit. The front desk manager鈥檚 (Catherine Michel) response: an absolute no! Giving credit for reduced rates is not 鈥渙ur policy...you should have discovered this earlier. I absolutely despise a condescending policy excuse... bad business and very impersonal. So I asked for internet credit instead...less of a refund but less of an impact on the hotel. Again, no. What if I rebooked? 鈥淲e will charge you the cancellation fee.鈥?A dead-end discussion that next time leaves me looking for other $500+ hotels for a mere $55 matter of principal. Even the restaurant, room service and mini bar rates are astronomical ($6 for a regular bottle of water, $27 for omelet and coffee, plus tax and delivery). Lot鈥檚 of places to eat within 300 feet of the entrance. Dine elsewhere.Bottom line, a very nice hotel and staff that would have had me back if we didn鈥檛 feel somewhat insulted by the manager. Looks like this French hotel is going the way of the US airlines...policy, not personality. What a pity.

<Author>DottyUK

<Author>zussinek
<Content>Very disappointed I just returned from a three-day stay at the Sofitel New York. I've tried to stay there several times because it has often ranked Number 1 at TripAdvisor. It was always booked when I tried, and I was therefore thrilled that I was finally getting to stay there.However, now that I have, I wonder why hotel guests rank it as highly as they do. I travel all over the world, stay in 4 and 5 star properties wherever I go, including Sofitels in London and Rome. The Sofitel New York does not live up at all to the standards at these hotels.Let's talk about the service -- or shall I say, the lack of customer service. When my husband and I walked in, I walked over to the front desk, and greeted the guest service agent with a big smile, and said: Hello, how are you today?The man didn't lift his eyes to even look at me, and said. I'm fine, thank you. Never bothered to ask me how I was -- or indeed greet me at all.I had negotiated a rate that included breakfast, but the agent said there was nothing on my file about that. He made no attempt to look into it, and relied entirely on me to find the documentation to prove it. That took some time to resolve, but finally it was and we received the breakfast coupons.The room itself was not at all impressive. We were two people staying in a king room. Most people travelling alone do not need a king bed, so one would think that king rooms would have sufficient drawers and hanging space to allow two people to unpack their suitcases. Not so in this room. The hanging portion of the closest was about a foot wide, with an iron and ironing board crammed in there as well. I had to remove them to make room the clothing we had brought for our 3-day stay, which included evening attire, day clothes, and business suits.The bed had only a comforter, with no single sheet between the duvet and the fitted sheet. That meant that, if we found the comforter too warm, which we did, we had nothing to cover ourselves with.The view we had outside our window was obstructed by buildings, making the room very dark. The floor lamps did not have bright enough bulbs to give ample light for reading.The Panasonic TV was an old model, not one of the flat-screen kinds I've seen in most hotel rooms I've stayed in elsewhere recently.There was only one bathrobe in this king room, which disappeared on two day, never to be seen again.The doors to the bathroom open outward into the closet area, requiring guests to remember to close one set before opening another. Not a well-thought out design.The best part of our stay there were two Albanian servers in the hotel restaurant. They brought a friendliness and eagerness to the hotel that was lacking in all the front desk agents.All in all, this was a disappointing stay. I will not likely return to the Sofitel New York, and would not recommend it, given its high cost and lacklustre service and ordinary accommodations, well below any 5-star hotel I've stayed in.  
<Date>Jul 25, 2007

<Rating>5	4	5	5	5	3	5	-1	

<Author>BusinessBrit
<Content>Worth every cent This Midtown Manhattan hotel on West 44th St between 5th and 6th Avenues gets high marks from other reviewers (which was why we booked it) and they are not wrong. Location: great. Five mins from Times Square and Broadway, ten mins from Macy's and all that wonderful shopping, Empire State Building, and a cheap cab ride from Central Park. For longer expeditions use the ultra-safe subway at just two dollars a trip. Hotel amenities: no excessive frills (eg no pool but a good gym) and an attractive brasserie with terrace that doubles as breakfast/bar/restaurant. Hotel interior very clean and smart with well maintained public areas and plush spotless carpets. Rooms vary in size but all have good bathrooms and extremely comfortable beds - ask for high rooms for the best views (we had views of Empire State and Rockerfeller Centre on 23rd floor - stunning.). Housekeeping first class, with exceptional attention to detail and cleanliness. Breakfasts sumptuous (but make sure you know the deal you are staying on: some deals include breakfast, in which case you are given a voucher to present in the restaurant - this can lead to a muddle if you are a family of four like us two of whom had vouchers and two who did not - this is one area the hotel could do with clarifying for their own waiters' benefit as much as guests'). Desk staff are terrific: friendly, efficient, helpful. We had a welcome complimentary bottle of champagne to mark one of our birthdays, and chocs too - a nice touch. Everyone seems thoroughly trained and the atmosphere is of calm professionalism. Concierge and his team excellent. Most remarkable of all: in your room, high above the horn-honking mayhem of Manhattan, you will hear....nothing. Not the merest whisper of a police siren disturbs your peace. You could be in the middle of the countryside. This is not the cheapest Manhattan hotel but solid value for money, and with the pound going so far in the USA it is even better value. As I said, a hotel does not earn such a consistently high rating without being consistently reliable, so book the Sofitel with confidence.  
<Date>Jul 16, 2007
<Rating>5	4	5	5	5	5	5	3

Aside from this I would recommend this hotel to other people.

It is a very nice hotel, indeed.It is clean and borders on the luxurious with very nice appointments. I certainly agree it is well located. A quick walk to Times Square (but two or three blocks away so it is quiet) and a fast walk to the F subway or Grand Central Station.The conceierge was quite helpful with reservations for dinner. Our room was cleaned at least twice a day that we noticed.The on-site restaurant was very good for breakfast; it wasn't cheap (of course, we didn't much care since we had booked a deal that included whatever we wanted for breakfast) and was willing to make whatever one wanted even if it wasn't on the menu. (We had fantastic lox  eggs  onions, which was not on the menu). We didn't eat there for other meals.It was the kind of place where when you went into the bar and asked for champagne, crackers, mustard and a knife, to go, no one blinks an eye: they just get it for you.Yes, we would stay there again.

<Author>bao903

A scone was $9, pancakes were like $19. We would have been better off grabbing something from Starbucks instead. Even with the two vouchers, the breakfast bill was outrageous for the fare. Next time, we'll skip the Gaby.

<Author>WishfulTraveller72
<Content>Well worth it! Top Notch! Just returned from a NY weekend trip and stayed 3 nights at the Sofitel NY. Check-in was fast and courteous - our room was ready whenwe arrived at noon and our luggage was quickly sent up. The hotel lobby is beautifully decorated but without the snobbery or attitude.All staff were friendly and very helpful. Our room, on the 7th floor was extremely clean although it was really damp - the carpet was moist. But, we just turned up the temperature in the room and left it to run. It was fine when we came back. The room was spacious and soundproof. We didn't have any problem with street noise. Spacious bathroom too. Housecleaning was efficient yet invisible. Our room was always spotless and nothing was disturbed in our room. We never saw housecleaning staff or cleaning staff yet our room or the hotel was always perfect. Another room perk: there is a room safe for valuables.We made a lot of use of the computers/internet access in the lobby although it could be busy and you would need to wait sometimes. Printer access was a nice bonus.The location was ideal - the hotel is a close walk to great shopping,to Times Square/Theatre District, to Central Park, to Grand Central Station, Bryant Park, MoMA, NY Public Library, Radio City Music Hall,etc...Also, close to subway and of course, lots of good eats nearby.Overall, the Sofitel is first rate in my book.
