<Author>City99
<Content>The other reviewers are right, as usual For a first time visitor to New York, this hotel is close to the Midtown action (44th St, just west of 5th Ave ) without being so close to Times Square that you can't sleep, and the previous reviewers are spot on with their comments. Choose a high floor by paying slightly more and the view and traffic noise will be fine; we had the Rockerfeller Center view to the north which was spectacular. The front desk was warm and helpful, the concierge knowledgeable although a little brusque. I recommend avoiding the breakfast in the Gabi Restaurant- sure it was OK, but for a fraction of the price you can eat in a NYC diner or deli, with real New York atmosphere and none of the pretension. The Pax cafe (part of chain) on Bryant Park SW corner with 6th Ave serve anything from fresh pancakes to Granola with fruit- we took it out and ate in the park.The hotel was clean, everything worked fine, the decor was plain and tasteful- will need touching up soon though, and the beds were soft but very comfy to sleep in. , Be aware that it does have a French air of insouciance about it, but all things considered it was a comfortable, safe choice and we were not disappointed.

<Author>Jesse1
<Content>Bon - a pleasant stay This hotel is a solid choice for those wanting to stay in midtown Manhattan. The Sofitel is on hotel row with other noted properties such as the Algonquin on 44th. The lobby has plenty of comfy seatingand has a hushed and yet welcoming feel. There are three computer terminals tucked off into an alcove by the lobby, ideal for printing boarding passes or mapquesting. The chairs, however, do not encouragemore than a few minute stay at the terminal. Check-in was prompt and friendly. The room is a good size and very pleasant, although the carpet looked a bit worn and could have used a good steam cleaning. The bathroom is well lit and does have a lot of space and a real (read English soaking) tub. The personal care items are top-notch as well. The bed - ahh - you will sleep and dream well. No street noise, although granted I was on the 22nd floor. Morning USA today is left by the elevator. Get breakfast elsewhere, based solely on the Paris-like cost.

<Author>EVC
<Content>Great value I took my mom to NY to celebrate her 80th birthday (June 14-17). I gave her the option of the Sofitel or a larger hotel. She looked at the online photos and selected the Sofitel because it was smaller and looked nice. We both were pleased. The hotel was clean and quiet. The location was good because it was less than two miles from everywhere we wanted to go - restaurants, shopping and shows. Considering the average size of a NY hotel room (very small) the room was large. The bathroom was well-appointed and we liked the updated style of separate shower and tub.The staff was friendly and helpful. I liked the fact that there was a cubby hole in the lobby with three computers and a printer. Free of charge, you could access the Internet and print boarding passes. Although I had read other reviews that it would be difficult for the doorman to hail a cab, we did not find that to be the case. The staff was knowledgeable about the area and offered ideas on shopping areas where we could find bargains.The one problem we had was with our room service the first night. We ordered the lobster bisque and did not like it. I was hesitant but decided to call room service to let them know we didn't like it. They sent someone to get the bowls and credited our bill without any hassle. Also, be aware that the minibar has a sensor on it. When something is removed your are charged but the sensor does not detect if you return something to the bar. I removed a diet Coke and changed my mind. I immediately returned it to the bar and selected a regular Coke. When I noticed that I was charged for two, I contacted the front desk and they told me about the sensor. They removed the second charge without any hassle.I would recommend it to anyone and would stay there again. We got good value for your money.  
<Date>Jun 22, 2007
<Rating>4	5	5	5	5	5	5	-1	

<Author>luli38
<Content>Some positives, some negatives Just got back from a long weekend in New York city and stayed at the Sofitel for 3 nights. There are some definite positives about staying at this hotel. Definite positive is the location--which cannot be beat. Great Midtown West location which is convenient to just about everything. No need to take a cab or any other public transportation. We had great weather so had no problems walking to Central Park, Times Square, or Uptown. We did walk all the way to the World Trade Center, but should have probably taken the subway (due the amount of time that it took) which we did on the way back. Walked down 6th Avenue so that we could get a feel for the different areas such as Greenwich, Chinatown, and Soho which I have never had much chance to visit. With regard to the hotel, I don't have much to add that hasn't already been said. The hotel is fine for the most part. Great beds--no yucky bedspread only crisp white sheets and comforter/duvet. The bathroom was clean and nice and the bath products were very good as well. The carpeting was a little stained looking and the room was a little small, but no smaller than most hotel rooms in New York. Didn't eat at the hotel as it seemed rather pricey and I prefer to experience independent establishments. The concierge was very good at providing recommendations and for the most part we enjoyed the recs. Make sure to get the free Sofitel privilege card as it entitles you to free drinks when you arrive. My one complaint was that the hotel was unwilling to adjust my room rate despite the fact that the website was now showing a better rate. I booked about 2 months prior to my trip and got a room rate for about $303 which did not include breakfast and could be cancelled up to 24 hours prior to arrival. The week before my trip I noticed that the Sofitel website indicated a $274 room rate (for the same room that I had booked at $303) or a $309 room rate which included breakfast. I printed out the sheet and when we arrived I assumed that the hotel would be willing to honor the $309 rate and include breakfast. I realize now that I should have cancelled the reservation (since there was no penalty) and then rebooked at the $309 rate as it was only $6 more but would be well worth the increase as both my spouse and I would get breakfast each morning. I assumed that the hotel would be willing to make this change and honor the rate but was fed some line about it being an internet only rate. It amazes me how customer service is valued differently at various organizations. I really expected more given that I am a Sofitel Privilege member. Anyway, I didn't make a big fuss about it, but will probably be less likely to book a room at the Sofitel for my next New York trip. I might consider the Iroquois which is right next door as I have heard good things about it. Restaurant to consider--Del Friscos -nice steak house with a reasonably priced 3 course meal served prior to 6:30 PM and within walking distance from the hotel in view of Radio City Music Hall.

<Author>IRISHMEN
<Content>Fantastic Location Stayed at the Sofitel for six nights for our 25th Wedding Anniversary. From the moment we arrived at reception we were treated with the utmost courtesy. At reception we were congratulated on our anniversary (an e- mail had been sent when booking) and on arrival at our room (25th floor) we discovered a bottle of Champagne had beenleft for us along with a personal letter from the manager. Our room was actually a suite with its own living area and a wonderful view towards Times Square. Staff were very friendly and the Concierge was wonderful. He recommended excellent restaurants and even booked them for us. The location is excellent on 44th Street as you are between 5th and 6th Avenues so you are only 5 mins walk to Times Square and the same distance to the Rockefeller Centre. Sacks 5th Avenue is about ten minutes and is beside St. Patrick's Cathedral. Beside the hotel is a wonderful Greek restaurant called Kellari (not anywhere like the rubbish you find on Greek Package Holiday) and along the same street is a very good but reasonably priced Italian Restaurant called Osteria al Doge. Breakfast was not included in the room rate so we ate out. There is a diner called the Red Flame which was okay and always busy but try the Brooklyn Diner on 43rd Street. Breakfast may be twice the price but the food was beautiful and decor was very appealing too!On our first night we ate in the hotel's restaurant called Gaby. The food was very good but New York has some excellent restaurants so do try to get about. This was a perfect trip but if the hotel isn't up to scratch then the rest of the holiday is downhill. In this instance The Sofitel excelled themseves and I woulddefinitely stay here again.

<Author>bristol_traveller_06
<Content>Fantastic Hotel, Great location, great room, a couple of minor quibbles We stayed at the Sofitel New York for five nights. This hotel is absolutely fantastic, one of the best I've stayed in. It is very well located, just two blocks from Times Square in one direction and Grand Central Station in the other. We booked via the Hotel website several months in advance and got a great deal on a King Suite. I also asked to be up high and we got the 25th floor which was really nice, though it was on the same level as the ledge for the window cleaning equipment which did slightly detract, but I'm not too fussed as the views of the Rockefeller center were very nice.The suites are very pleasant, lovely lounge area, two televisions (one in the lounge, one in the bedroom), the beds and pillows are fantastic. The bathroom is great as well.The staff always treated us very well, with courtesy and professionalism. We never ate at the restaurant but did get Room service, do read the fine print on the room service menu which states all the extras that are added onto the price (tips  taxes are all added on, yet there is a section on the receipt you sign for extra tips, but I can't see this is necessary as it is basically double tipping).I found no pressure to tip anyone, they even asked on arrival if we needed help with our bags  we said no so were able to take them up ourselves, we had heard that at other places they can insist on taking your bags so that you have to tip.Also I let them know it was my Birthday and they very kindly gave me a bottle of very nice sparkling wine beautifully presented in a classy ice bucket with some glasses. The maid service was excellent, we left them a tip each day which they took  would leave a note of thanks. We were never disturbed while our do not disturb sign was out.The only quibbles I have, and this is because I am pedantic, are:1. The lifts can be a bit slow sometimes, and the timing seems to be out, our floor for instance was almost always serviced by the same lift, which could take quite a while to turn up, making me wonder what the others were doing2. The In-room TV system is very comprehensive, and does have a good billing system to let you know what you've spent, but it can be very slow to load, occasionally will crash and freeze up (even turning off  on the TV doesn't work). Also sometimes it can appear in blackwhite or have distorted sound. However the movie we purchased through the system played flawlessly which was good3. The Ice Machine on our level was broken which required us to go to the next level, a minor inconvenience but worth noting.4. The Iron in the room sparked in the plug socket  tripped the breaker for the entire room one morning. They were quite quick in resetting the breaker and gave us a brand new iron straight away, but it was slightly disconcerting none-the-less.These are minor things though and I would stay at this hotel again without a moments hesitation, It really is an oasis in the madness, but excitement, of Manhattan!

<Author>Minu6
<Content>Excellent location Returned 10 days ago having thoroughly enjoyed a 5 night stay at the Sofitel. The facts are: the beds are great, the rooms are a good size for New York but best of all the staff and location are simply second to none. If you are in New York to shop, visit the sights or just to be engrossed by the unique atmosphere this is the place to stay. Tips: The Red Flame Diner is a good start to the day, St Andrews Alehouse for a steak, Top of the Rock is unmissable and Central Park worth a long visit. Also do NOT drink the Kronenbourg in the bar it is $14 a pint. Ask for a room high up - we had the 27th floor with a wonderful view of the Chrysler Building. Also we took the advice of fellow trip advisors and registered for a Sofitel loyalty card prior to arrival the complementary drinks and late check out (1600 hours) were much appreciated. Agreed it may not be a 5 star hotel but it is a 5 star experience.

<Author>Minx77
<Content>A good city base My husband and I have just got back from a 5 night stay at the Sofitel, and we were very happy with our choice. We booked a standardroom but were upgraded to a suite, which was really nice! Therefore I'm not sure what the standard rooms are like. The suite was clean, large and neutral with a really nice bathroom, comfy kingsize bed andlovely views of the Chrysler building. The rate was about $300 a night which is cheap at the moment for us from the UK! The hotel has a fitness suite which looked OK but we didn't use it, and free internet access in the lobby. If you are looking for a hip hotel this isn't for you. Last time we went to NYC we stayed at the Royalton which is much cooler but twice the price! The Sofitel is beige, neutral and corporate. Its not a characterful hotel but if you're looking for somewhere to stay where you'll be guaranteed good standards, a quiet room with great air-con,good housekeeping, in the middle of town, for a fair price then I don't think you can go wrong with the Sofitel. NB One downside is the ridiculous price of room service - I don't think I've ever found one more expensive, and I've stayed in some lovely 5 star hotels throughout the world - don't even think about ordering!

<Author>JH46
<Content>Great hotel, staff, location. We stayed here for our first trip to NY and found it a very comfortable room, excellent bed, large bathroom, quiet in room, and super friendly staff. Helpful concierge, reception - no hassle check in / out, doormen found cabs, checked them for left items and secure doors/trunk ! There is a good selection of diners / restaurants nearby which are cheaper than the hotel food. The location is ideal for tourists, walkable to most sights, or the hopper bus, shows, etc. Ditch the car and take a cab or subway, as parking is expensive. For us (a 40 something couple on a 3 day tourist trip) this was absolutely ideal and hassle free choice. We experienced, first hand, all of the following:- great welcome at check in at midnight, quick and easy - no big forms to fill out (9/10 marks)- staff (almost) always on hand, behind the counter but also - critically - in the lobby area - also very willing to help - this is really different (10/10)- modern, comfortable, well designed, large (for NYC) rooms (8/10)- great room service (9/10) - spotless- little to no noise from street outside or adjacent rooms (9/10)- friendly staff almost always smiling or saying hi (9/10)- free internet in the lobby (3 terminals - could do with 2 more) (7/10)- ok concierge (5/10)- ok bar - (dreadful bar nibbles - -pls change them!) <Author>Kokes
<Content>Loved the Sofitel The Sofitel is a fantastic hotel. Believe what you read on trip advisor about the beds - they are so comfortable! Gorgeous fluffy duvets and pillows which make for a great night's sleep - along with the quiet rooms (I couldn't believe we were in Manhattan!) with no street noise and none of the usual banging of doors which you can often get in hotels. Staff were friendly and courteous. Lobby is gorgeous and the rooms are finished to a great standard with beautiful large bathrooms. Only thing missing for me was tea and coffee making facilities in the room. The location is great - 2 seconds from 5th avenue shops and 2 minutes from Times Square. As per the other reviews we visited the red flame diner for breakfast which was OK if you want the whole american diner experience with no frills. For something a bit more refined try the cafe 57 on 6th avenue right near central park - it's lovely and they do a great and very reasonable brunch with everything from fruit and granola to eggs and pancakes. Beautiful atmosphere too. Overall the Sofitel was gorgeous and I'd definitely recommend staying there.

<Author>Jessica
<Content>Okay hotel - Amazing Staff and service - No pool We stayed at this hotel with our children. The hotel is smart and with probably the best hotel staff in the world. I think the staff makes the hotel. The staff just cannot do enough for you. They remember our names every day of the five days we were there. The hotel manager or whoever trained the staff should be commended. The hotel itself is just okay, clean, smart, you have to pay for the gym, and $35 for parking with no in and out priviledges, so if you park the car now and go out 10 minutes later, its another $35. Yikes. manhattan, all you can see are walls of the next building. We got upgraded to a better room. The rooms are small, and the bed was very small. The staff however gave us another double bed in the room. There is absolutely no view being in MThe hotel doesnt have a pool and apart from using the gym or sit in the lobby, there is nothing else to do in the hotel. Will not stay there again. I like my hotel to have a pool, jacuzzi, steam room and spa.

<Author>collywobbles
<Content>Super-duper Sofitel I booked this hotel as a suprise 30th birthday treat for my husband, and as he knew nothing about it I was somewhat worried about picking the wrong hotel - so I relied upon Trip Advisor for a recommendation.It cost more than I wanted to pay, but after researching prices of similar hotels in New York, I quickly recognised the price was neither expensive nor cheap.I arranged for the Sofitel to get a limo to pick us up from JFK, and whilst it was a good experience it did cost $154, whilst a yellow cab costs just $45 (fixed rate).I mailed the hotel in advance to ask about champagne being delivered to the room (as we arrived on hubbie's actual 30th birthday), and was given a price-list and order form. They wanted quite a bit so I chose not to bother, but in the evening a free bottle of bubbly arrived with a birthday note!We arrived at noon, and were told none of the rooms were ready so we would have to come back at 3pm, so the receptionist recommended we visit Central Park - which we did, and then upon returning at 3pm we had to wait another 45 minutes as the computers were being backed up. But when we finally got to our room, it was just perfect.Really clean, bed was the comfiest I have ever slept in, the bathroom was luxurious, there were slippers and robes, the usual TV, mini-bar (expensive) and safe. The rooms were checked/cleaned twice a day, and evian water appeared in the evenings - they didn't bother folding pyjamas though, and we found ours screwed up in various places! We paid for the higher rooms, and the view was good - typical New York.Reception were helpful, and the clientele was very broad - tourists and business-people mixed without any issue.We used the concierge a number of times, and they helped us with directions, restaurant reservations and helped us plan a baseball match trip.We didn't use the hotel restaurants, as there are so many other places to eat - for breakfast most days we went to the Red Flame Diner just a few doors down, as it was always full and the food was tasty but cheap.As this was our first trip to New York, we did the usual tourist things - Central Park (took a pony trip - very expensive for what you actually get), Empire state building and Statue of Liberty (note - if you want to avoid long queues make sure you get there really really early (we were the 5th/6th people onto the Statue of Liberty). Also took the Red Hopper Bus (but got very busy, and they all expect you to tip - which becomes expensive when you get on and off at every stop!), went to a Mets baseball game, visited Ground Zero which was quite moving. We went over to Brooklyn one evening to look at the Manhattan skyline by night (head for the River Cafe, but instead of paying a minum of $25 per person for high-class stuffy food wearing a jacket, check out the neighbouring boardway which offers exactly the same view for free) - quite incredible, but we felt a bit unsafe walking back to the subway.We ended up buying a weekly subway pass - it didn't cost much and we used it loads - I think you can use any subway or bus anywhere you want within New York within the one week period.We'll definitely be coming back to New York - and when we do, the Sofitel will be where we stay.  
<Date>May 19, 2007
<Rating>5	3	5	5	5	5	5	-1	

<Author>ManchesterPammy
<Content>The Sofitel is 'Wonderfel' Long live Trip Advisor! I wouldn't travel anywhere without consulting it first and have recommended it to soo many people. Do yourself a favour, please, please book a table at The River Cafe in Brooklyn (but do it before you leave home). You can walk across the bridge, as we did, then double back to the water's edge where this 'barge' restaurant is located. The food was wonderful but the view of the Manhattan Skyline was priceless and there's not a bad seat in the house.Oh, and on the day before we came home, a guy got in the elevator with us and was chatting away to my husband because I'd lost the power of speech. After he got out I told my hubby it was Billy Bob Thornton but he did'nt know who he was! (One of the staff confirmed it). So if it's good enough for Billy Bob..............

<Content>Sofitel - top notch location and service We stayed at the Sofitel 4 nights to celebrate my wife's 40th birthday. The lobby is spacious with plenty of comfy chairs and several computer/internet terminals. The room was not overly large, but had everything we could want, and was very nicely decorated. <Author>tabbykins
<Content>A great choice for our first visit to New York Difficult to know what to add to the positive reviews already posted. I had mixed feelings coming to New York as I did not think that the city or this hotel would be my thing. How wrong I was!! We had a beautiful, spacious suite on the 25th floor with views toward the Rock. I think the floor was an upgrade as I think you are meant to pay extra for the top floors  we didn't, just requested one if possible. Our stay was for a week. Everything in the hotel done very efficently for you with a minimun of fuss. The hotel is very European in feel, I thought that may be a mistake for us as coming from Europe to NY for the first time perhaps we should have gone for something less European in feel but we loved the Sofitel so 'Je ne regrette rien!' A lot has to do with perspective  expectations. The Sofitel is a great deal, even for a suite upgrade, coming from UK with the present exchange rate. Visitors from inside the USA may feel differently. Also, I have no idea how it compares with other hotels in New York. I did my research on TA  after reading the reviews for this  many other hotels, this seemed like the best bet. It certainly worked for us. I loved New York  the Sofitel added to our enjoyment. Result!!

<Author>ravenna
<Content>Excellent Experience My wife and I stayed here five nights and had no issues. The Sofitel has a great location, perfect for knocking around the neighborhood or going uptown or downtown. The room (2104) was well appointed, extremely quiet and had a nice city view. The marble shower had plenty of pressure and hot water. The bed was outrageously comfortable. The staff were courteous and helpful. The bellmen were so efficient that a taxi, even on a rainy evening, was never hard to come by.We found the quality of room service to be very good andenjoyed a nice meal at Restaurant Gaby. That being said, keep in mind that Chef Daniel Boulud has a bistro only a few doors down that serves breakfast, lunch and dinner with excellence. We cannot give a single reason why we would not return to the Sofitel next time we visit NYC.

<Author>caz1979
<Content>Fantastic! My fiance booked the Sofitel for 4 nights at the end of March/start of April as a birthday pressie combined with getting my engagement ring at Tiffany  Co. As others have done in the past, we subtly mentioned we were here for an occassion but alas no champage. What we did get though was room 2820. 28th floor, only 3 rooms at this particular side of the hotel and boy what a view! The TV was a bit old, not a great deal in the way of storage space but the room was the best I have seen yet even compared to the Fairmont in Toronto. Kudos to whoever makes those beds as they were the best nights sleep I have ever had. The bathroom was to die for and in a moment of nosiness I eventually figured out the knob in the bathroom was great for knowing what the other half was was watching on TV. The location was amazing with Central Park, Empire State, 5th  6th, Broadway and Times Square all within walking distance although if you do walk to Central Park I'd advise stopping for coffee half way as it is quite far. We received complimentary turn down and 2 bottles of Evian every evening plus the weather forcast for the following day but no chocolates - probably just as well.New York itself wasn't a total let down but I think the weather was very kind to us which helped. Guys, if you're thinking about getting a nice piece of jewellery for your other half (especially the diamond ring variety) definately visit Tiffany on 5th near Central Park. 3 glasses of champagne later and I had the most beautiful engagement ring that would have cost double in the UK.Other things to do/visit - Red Flame (breakfast, lunch, dinner or midnight snack, this place was always welcoming and the selection and prices were great plus it wasn't all tourists there), Apple store on 5th, Grand Central Station (5 minute walk from the hotel). I, like others, found that the hotel staff thought we were made of money when it came to recommending restaurants. I don't think jeans  trainers helped our cause for door opening but when walking that much, I wasn't doing heels! One negative factor about the trip was the red NY sight-seeing buses. They were over priced, over crowded and at times you could have walked faster. Great for learning more about NY but a travellers guide would be cheaper and warmer. A crowd of 50+ (including us) were stranded for over an hour at Battery Park waiting to get home on a day when winter woolies were required but not worn. We were lucky enough to get on the bus home but had to sit upstairs (open-air) in freezing conditions or risk not getting home at all.

However, we went on three tours while we were in New York City and let me tell you that everyone there on each of these tours feels that you really need to look at the Empire State building so I have pretty much seen it in every view the you can possibly see and likely have at least 50 to 60 pictures just because of the number of times that was mentioned and I much like a lemming feel the need to take a picture each and every time.The bedding is sumptuous, the room is very comfortable. the only thing I would have liked is that I would've greatly appreciated having free Internet access in the hotel room. There is no information on the hotel website to indicate whether or not the Internet is free or not however I have discovered that virtually all the hotels that I stay at that are in the $200-$400 price range never include free Internet. Oddly when I stay at hotels in the $50-$75 range they always include free Internet.I would recommend joining the membership club as well because of the expense of the hotel I have quite a substantial amount of points now with the membership club and will recommend everyone to join because it does enable you to have a late checkout and also provides you with two free drinks. In the room was standard size unlike most of the hotels I stay at in New York which are extremely small and I would highly recommend that you stay here for just about anything.

<Author>jodean1979
<Content>Wonderful Hotel in a Good City Stayed in Sofitel New York from 6 - 11 April 07 was greeted by very friendly staff and very professional staff. Upon arrival I was able to change Travellers Cheques without charges up to $200 but as I wanted more they said that on the 1st exchange only they would do this for $400 (had I known how little we would spend I would not have put the lady at reception out.) We were there for an easter break, both me and my partner really found the hotel to be the best location wise, cleanliness, friendliness and so on I cannot praise Sofitel enough for keeping French Front of House staff to retain that consistently high level of service.If you have booked to stay at the Sofitel New York you will not go away disappointed. New York may not be what you are expecting but the hotel will be!Found New York to be so so. It is not a city we could fall in love with such as Paris but it is okay and enjoyed the stay. Well worth a visit but not much in the way of romantic essence especially not at The Empire State Building as I thought there would be here if no where!The Empire State Building is okay, it is a construction site inside and not only do you queue to get up but you queue to get down too and Top of The Rock at Rockerfeller Centre is far better, much closer to the essence of New York I was expecting and more professionally managed.As other reviewers have said if you are due to stay at the Sofitel anywhere in the world it is well worth getting yourself a Sofitel Privilege Card in advance - takes about 3 weeks to arrive but if you apply online there are no fees and you can ring France obtain your card number and expiry as I did and quote upon arrival or booking in order to gain you can get your free drinks on arrival and 4pm check out without hassle. You need to ring France to get your details if they don't arrive in time number on their website.Didn't spend much as food was relatively inexpensive best meal and most expensive meal we had was at Grand Central Station in the restaurant opposite Jordon Steak House, can't remember the name something like Caprianio. Also The Red Flame Diner a few doors down from the Sofitel is excellent for a cheap and cheerful meal but a bit of a nightmare at breakfast time very busy but that just goes to show how good it is not just tourists either.All in all a very nice experience both of New York and Sofitel. But everyone's tastes are always different but the hotel most certainly will be favoured by the majority but the jury is still out on New York.

<Author>TravlingBard
<Content>Sweet Dreams We stayed here for two nights after 2 nights on the West Side. It was good to be in the midst of the action of Times Square and convenient to Broadway shows. We walked to ours and saw the Drowsy Chaperone which was highly entertaining and funny. The view on the 20th floor was fine, not great, but we did not care to pay a premium for great. The room was well appointed with space to place clothing in drawers, and a decent sized closet. Very nice art and lighting. One neat feature was the speaker in the bathroom that lets you hear what your partner is watching on TV, or turn it off for peaceful bathing. The bed was fantastic, formidable as they say in French. The service was superbe - one actually felt that the staff really cared if you had a wonderful restful visit. I had the feeling they'd be very nice about letting one practice one's French too. Not Parisians evidently. We were obliged with a late checkout on a miserably rainy Sunday - the day set a record for rain in Central Park - so we enjoyed being able to sleep half the day, something that turned out to be particularly beneficial later in the airport when we were delayed from departing until midnight and our flight turned into a redeye. We are both early risers but not at this hotel. The concierge gave very good leads - Rene in particular. The concierge got us GREAT tickets to the B'way show center orchestra 7 rows from the front, which I booked with them by phone a month before after I had booked the room. Outstanding food at Gaby's in the lobby. Also Junior's has opened a location on 45th nearby for what's often referred to as the best cheesecake in NYC not to mention other excellent traditional deli. We caught wonderful jazz by Christian Finger band at Cornelia St. Cafe in Greenwich village, and the food was great there too, with an eye to organic and low-fat. Some of the best entertainment was in the subway, of course. The lobby sports three computers with a super fast connection so no need to bring the laptop. Occasionally they all get busy but one opens up relatively quickly. I've seen more spectacular lobbies but this one is well dressed and very pretty. Kind of strange to say this but this very French hotel offers a quintessential NYC experience, and reminds me of my best times in the French countryside while providing a haven in the City. Very satisfied.

<Author>terps82770
<Content>FABULOUS!!!!!! My husband and I stayed at the Sofitel for a getaway (from three kids) weekend. It was our first time in New York and, I have to say, our experience could not have been better!! The room was immaculate, the service impeccable (the concierge and the doormen were WONDERFUL). Tony's di napoli was, by far, the best Italian food we have ever had and had a wonderful atmosphere.  I have to mention the beds at the Sofitel. Down pillows, down comforter, down pillow top - need I say more? We actually napped for a few hours after a day of shopping on nearby 5th Avenue just because the beds were so amazing and PLUSH. We are ordering the pillows from the Sofitel shop for our bed at home. The entire hotel was sophisticated and beautiful - we very much enjoyed the art deco decor. I loved the fresh flowers and candlelight. The rooms are not enormous (although the bathrooms have a separate tub and shower along with marbled floors), but WHO CARES when you can sleep in the bed as if you were at home. More than worth it. We will not stay anywhere else for our future trips.

<Author>SusaB
<Content>Excellent Hotel My husband and I stayed here for 3 nights over Easter weekend. Webooked the hotel through Priceline. This is an excellent hotel witha superb location and outstanding service. We arrived before the 3PM check in time and were given a room on the 3rd floor with a queen size bed. The person who checked us in claimed there were no king size beds available and said we could upgrade to a King suite for $100 per night, which we declined. The room overlooked some kind of power unit and I could hear the muffled sound. I went down and asked for another room to no avail. Later I approached another person at the desk who assured us we could get a room with a King size bed the next day. This room was on the 14th floor and much more desirable. Every night they left two bottles of Evian and a small box of chocolates. The bathroom is lovely and there is nothing negative I can say about this hotel. A wonderful property and you can't beat the location. We easily walked to theater district, Fifth Avenue shopping, etc etc.  
<Date>Apr 14, 2007
<Rating>5	5	5	5	5	4	5	5	

<Author>Jacol
<Content>Absolutely Perfect Just returned from a week long stay at the Sofitel visiting our son.The weather was absolutely freezing but the hotel was wonderful and exactly as described in previous reviews. Having walked every inch ofManhattan, including the Brooklyn Bridge (a must at dusk to see the lights come on in Manhattan), it was a joy to get back and relax in our gorgeous bed! We signed up for a privilege card and were upgradedto a room on the 21st floor with an amazing view of the Chrysler Building and were given vouchers for two free drinks in the bar and late checkout. Can highly recommend doing this. We took breakfast either in our room or in the Gaby Restaurant and the little extras and attention to detail made it well worth the money. Our son works in SoHo and took us to many trendy cafes and restaurants inGreenwich, SoHo, Alphabet City and East Side, which we would have missed on our own. They may look scruffy on the outside but are packed with locals and ooze atmosphere, especially for the younger visitor. I can't remember all the names but we lunched at Chat 'n Chew at 10 East 16th St and had dinner one night at Esperanto Restaurant in Alphabet City, as well as quaint French and Italian restaurants. Be sure to also visit Cafe Lalo at 201 W 83rd St on the Corner of Amsterdam Avenue where 'You Got Mail' was filmed. Our first day we took a 'New York Party Shuttle Bus' tour which I can heartily recommend. The small bus with guide takes you all around Manhattan including the Statten Island Ferry and Ground Zero and the guide gives a personal insight into the whole of Manhattan. Check out their website. On returning to the airport the doormen arranged for us to travel in the black limousine shared with a neighbouring hotel, costing 65 dollars including tolls, and worth the extra for the comfort. From the hotel we could walk to Grand Central, Empire State Building, Rockerfeller Centre (the views from the top are as good if not better than the Empire State, and the queues are a lot less - again dusk is a popular time to see the city in daylight and as the lights come on), Chrysler Building, Times Square, Maceys, etc,making it the perfect location. I'm glad we didn't stay in Times Square as this gets very busy and noisy but a cut price show can be booked at the TKTS booth now by Drowsy Chaperone (didn't see this show but it was recommended to us). New Yorkers are very friendly and helpful and the city felt very safe. Apart from the weather we had an absolutely wonderful stay in New York.  
<Date>Apr 14, 2007
<Rating>5	5	5	5	5	5	5	5	

<Author>doremifaso
<Content>Above average, yes. Best hotel in New York? No. We have not long returned from the Sofitel and found it above average,. but not much more. I am surprised that it ranks so highly, to be honest. It is clean, well situated and the staff were helpful on the whole, but there was little to distinguish it from other hotels of its ilk - the Parker Meridien, for example matches the Sofitel and has a rooftop pool, too! It met our needs and was pretty good value for money, but was resolutely unremarkable overall.

<Author>WolfCobh
<Content>First time in New York - and First Class Hotel experience! My wife and I (both in mid-40s) stayed in the Sofitel for 7 nights. The overall experience was fantastic! The room was spacious (!!), high up, with top view, modern design, a bed that you did not want to get out of (what comfort!!), and was being cleaned and serviced each day par excellence! Free water and (what indulgence) free chocolates every day. The staff was friendly and attentive. And the restaurant offered really excellent food (yes, we had dinner there twice, despite hundreds of other choices)! Few people go for the breakfast, though, as there are lots of places around with good choices. The location is fantastic! 5 minutes to Times Square/Broadway, 10 minutes to the central bus stations and the Port terminal, and 5th Avenue just around the corner. You are right at the edge of all what makes NY so exciting! We will come back to this hotel next time!

<Rating>5	5	5	5	5	5	5	-1	

<Author>ZedZedH
<Content>Excellent This is a GREAT four star hotel. I think it's important to clarify that -- it's a FOUR STAR hotel. It's totally not the Four Seasons or anything else that is five star, so I don't understand why people go there expecting it to be at that level. However, if you accept that it's a four star hotel, you'll probably find it's the BEST four star hotel in Manhattan.Stayed there for a week during late March this year, and had an absolutely lovely time. Absolutely no dramas during our stay, and we found everything to be clean, efficient, well managed and friendly. I booked a King Suite via their website on the '3 night getaway' rate, which was tremendously good value. The 7 full nights in this massive 650 square foot suite was just 2942 USD, which is remarkable value for a room this size in New York in my opinion. The suite itself was absolutely lovely. Plenty of room to relax in, which is vitally important if you are in New York for a blazing 7 day tourism extravaganza, and you come home heavily laden with shopping bags every day :) Rooms in NY tend to be a bit smaller than other cities around the world, so this wasn't the largest suite I'd ever been in, but it was an okay size. Of particular note is the bathroom, which had the most wonderful deep soaking bath tub that we made good use of almost every day.Concierge was excellent -- we wandered down to Daniel and said we needed a nice restaurant to have dinner in on Saturday night before our Broadway show, and he very quickly got us into an award winning restaurant nearby. His efficiency and professionalism was quite amazing.Reception was also fantastic, but it depended on who you spoke to. Brook / Brooke was absolutely sensational. She had so much enthusiasm and was so incredibly friendly, that we couldn't help but have a huge smile on our faces as we checked in. Every time I needed to come down to reception, if I saw Brook I would make a bee line for her because she was so lovely.The bed -- oh my goodness. Yes, people rave about the Sofitel bed and I was always like sure, whatever, but then I got in this one and I totally understand what everyone is on about! They put this very VERY soft featherbed thingy on top of the mattress, and it turns the bed into an absolute slice of heaven. We were often thinking about it while we were out and about :) Great down pillows too.Room service was good, although they did make a mistake once, but quickly rectified it without any hassle. The food was very nice.The downstairs restaurant has been badly slated in past reviews, but we ate dinner there on our first night and found it to be very nice, although the service was a touch slow. We cannot comment on the breakfast because we never ate it there. For breakfast, as has been mentioned in previous reviews, head down the street to the Red Flame Restaurant. This is a kind of 'diner' with lovely big breakfasts, fast service, and a real cool New York street ambience. People come in and queue up at the take-out counter for bagels and coffee, while we sat in one of the numerous booths and just soaked it all up. The waitresses may not be Minnesota nice, but they are super fast and efficient, and ice cold water will be on your table just as you sit, with coffee not far behind it. We had breakfast there every morning, trying different specials and can recommend a stack of things! (great poached eggs, home fries, omelettes)Okay, back to the hotel!Niggles: the cupboard for hanging your clothes in was very small, especially for a suite. However, we managed to get by. We didn't get a fabulous view, even though we were on the top floor. The view was of some unrecognisable buildings, so if you want a view of Chrysler (which you can absolutely get from this hotel) please make sure you request precisely that well in advance.The water pressure in the shower was perhaps below average.On the whole, we had a wonderful stay here and I cannot give this hotel anything less than full marks. I would have paid two to three times the price at the Four Seasons, and I'm sure the experience would not have been that much more comfortable to warrant it. They have great staff at the Sofitel, it's in a fabulously convenient location, and our time there was hassle free and completely pampered. What more can you ask for? Get it on a good rate, and stay there!!!!  
<Date>Apr 10, 2007
<Rating>5	5	5	5	5	5	5	4	

<Author>tommer1
<Content>Bravo Sofitel!!!!!!!!!!! I opted for this hotel after the mainly positive reviews posted on trip advisor. I am one who can be a harsh critic and when I'm spending my money. I have an attitude that I should get what I paid for and I'm entitled to premium service. We have stayed at numerous hotels around the world some better than others. New York City based on experience is a place that can be dicey when it comes to accommodations. In many cases the room was OK the staff not so hot, location etc....never have we stayed at a place that put it all together.That is until we stayed at the Sofitel, from the minute we arrived to our departure this hotel has found the formula. An excellent attentive staff that genuinely seem to care how not just your stay is but how your overall trip is going. Polite, professional, conscientious, dedicated are only a few of the many QUALITIES I could use to describe their team.If anyone was considering getting into the hotel industry they would be wise to go and stay at Sofitel for a week to get an understanding of how a hotel should be run.The rooms were stylishly furnished, immaculately clean, the bed comfortable with basically no street noise. The location was proximate to everything New York has to offer. There is no doubt when we return to NY where we will be staying. As a matter of fact I was so impressed with this place we would build our vacation time around the hotels availability.Bravo Sofitel!!!!!!!

<Author>basnight
<Content>A near perfect stay! I stayed with the wife for a long weekend and picked the Sofitel based on the reviews from this site and I couldn't have been happier with my choice. 5 years ago I made the mistake of staying at the Waldorf Astoria and vowed never to get ripped off again in NYC. The rate from theSofitel website averaged under three hundred a night which is very competitive. Loved the close proximity to the theatre district and 5th Ave. The staff was friendly and when we thought our first room smelled like smoke the woman who checked us in brought up our new room keys personally and in an instant. The lobby is art-deco beautiful and there is free internet access on 3 hotel computers 24 hours a day. I particularly liked the gym. It was bigger than most hotel gyms, had TV's with all cardio equipment, free headphones, and the gym was complementary ( unlike a lot of NY hotels which charge extra or make you walk to an adjoining health club ). The only negatives were that the hotel TV did not get ESPN ( it was NCAA tourney weekend ) and the comfy bed does not have a sheet but a duvet only ). Other than those tidbits, I couldn't have been more pleased with my choice.

<Author>AnointedTraveler
<Content>One Word - Magnifique!!!!!!!!!!! 5 Star Experience My teenage daughter and I just spent her Spring Break week at the Sofitel. From the moment the car stopped in front of the hotel we were treated like royalty. Every guest is greeted as a welcomed loved one returning home from a journey. The greetings, smiles, and genuine attention to every service need or request underscores the superelative service of this hotel. I work in the travel service industry and travel to NY often and have stayed in many lovely hotels in and around Manhattan. With all of the state of the art bedding that is touted by other hotel chains, Sofitel's is far and away the most comfortable. I have chronic lower back pain and can only sleep on any mattress 5 hrs at a time. Well, I slept a full 8 hours on their wonderful bed w/o any kinks, crimps, or negative physical impacts. I fully intend to try and buy one of these beds for myself. My finicky and highly pampered teen ADORED the hotel. The internet access, the friendliness of the staff, and the superb room service - the food is fabulous- had her raving from the moment we entered the room. The delectable Lenotre chocolates each guest receives each evening helped to seal the deal that this is now the ONLY place my daughter wants to stay when we visit NY. Daniel -the best doorman on the planet, Ronald- The most informative and debonaire reservationist ever, Nick -the spot on bellman, and the the classy and helptul Concierge all underscore the serious commitment that the Sofitel makes to serving their customers. The lovely location, critic's choice cuisine, blissful bedding, and stupendous staff all underscore the Sofitel's universal appeal. Make the Sofitel your home base in NYC.

<Author>BrooklynGirl4
<Content>I hate to whine, but..... I hate to whine, but although the overall experience was fine, there are a few minor points to make. When we checked in we were in a room on the 5th floor, on the 45th street side. The jackhammering was unbelievable. The noise was very disturbing. It began at about 7:30 AM. We asked nicely for another room and were moved to the 19th floor, specifically room 1901, on the same end of the hotel, although opposite side. The noise was less, but you could still hear it. On Saturday and Sunday morning, no noise...a VERY stark contrast to weekday jackhammering all day. We understand that the hotel has no control over this, but until the jackhammering is over, we will stay elsewhere on our next NY visit. I read on here about chocolates and turn down service. I believe that perhaps this is a selective service as we received turn down, but no chocolate! The staff was nice, room clean, great location, all else was fine.

<Author>damonandtina
<Content>A couple oddities, but overall great! Although the Sofitel near Times Square has a couple odd quirks that keep it from gaining a 5-star rating, my daughter and I thoroughly enjoyed it on a recent visit and would gladly stay there again.Among the MANY positives of this hotel:-Wonderfully comfortable beds-Plush bath robes and great, thick towels-Very quiet atmosphere-Complimentary computers in the lobby to check e-mail-WONDERFUL bathroom with separate tub and shower-Great amenties and complimentary Evian water-Great location about 4 blocks from Times Square and 5 blocks from Rockefeller Plaza-In-room safes that are easy to operate-Great air conditioners that truly cool the room (a rarity in NYC, where most don't cool properly)-Friendly staff and housekeepingWith all these positives, you might think this the perfect NYC hotel, but then a few little missteps make you scratch your head and wonder what they were thinking:-NO COFFEE OR COFFEEMAKERS IN ROOMS!! An astoundingly strange oversight.-Evening turndown service, but no chocolates or mints on the beds. Picky, but for $350 a night,....?-Bathroom doors DO NOT have locks! This invites the uncomfortable possibilities of a couple oops moments on your vacation.-$350 a night seems about $50-$75 a night to steep for this quality of a hotel.-They took a $900 deposit on my credit card for incidentals, even though I had a PRE-PAID room!!!! Did they think I was going to eat the entire mini-bar,....twice?!?!This is a great hotel and worthy of staying at on your next trip. However, they've certainly left some t's not crossed and i's not dotted in their lack of attention to detail. With that said, however,very clean, very quiet and very nice.

<Author>Lee4
<Content>Excellent hotel! My husband and I stayed at the Sofitel NYC for 3 nights and really enjoyed our stay. I must say that the bed is the most comfortable one I've ever slept in--I wanted to pack it up and take it home! The room itself was large (even by NYC standards) with a king bed, 2 chairs w/ ottoman, 2 nightstands, and a dresser/desk type table that held the TV and also had a mini-bar hidden inside. The bathroom was large with a shower and separate tub. The space around the sink was plentiful, with an extra shelf to store things on. The room also had a small closet, hair dryer, iron, ironing board, safe, robe, and slippers. The room was clean and we would happily stay there again. The hotel's location is excellent and it was easy to walk to many places in the mid-town area and to Times Square/Broadway. We saw Spamalot, which was on the same street, just 3 blocks or so away. Bryant Park is very close by and there are several subway stops nearby as well. Grand Central Station was also a quick walk away. Just a great stay!

<Content>Great Hotel My husband and I just spent 3 nights at the Sofitel New York. We loved it. The 44th Street location is wonderfull, walk one way to Times Square and the other to 5th Avenue. We had a king size bed on the 23rd floor. There was no street noise at all, a very quiet room. The view was not that exciting but we spent very little time in the room looking out. The bathroom, which is one of my pet peeves, was lovely. I liked the marble and the layout was spacious enough that both my husband and I could be in there at the same time when necessary. The closet was very small and we had a lot of stuff with us as we were attending a wedding in the city. Housekeeping arranged for us to have a mobile clothes rack to accomodate us and the room was plently big to have the rack in the room. The bed was very comfortable. The elevator was fast . I called housekeeping a number of times with special requests and all were handled quickly. We had a drink in the bar but didn't try the room service or the restaurant. Overall the Sofitel was excellent. We would love to stay there again.  
<Date>Mar 26, 2007

<Author>SarahDelaney
<Content>Staff and service were Excellent! Wow! My husband and I after much consideration settled on the Sofitel NYC for our 1 year anniversary (March 10). We read through all the reviews of hundreds of hotels on this site and had a hard time choosing since it seems that no matter what hotel you choose someone has quams about it. I went to book the hotel online the night before we were scheduled to arrive and found that the prices had gone up so we called the hotel directly and they offered us a fantastic rate (no cancellation policy). We were trying to be economical so booked only a queen between the 3rd and 14th floor. We had taken the train into the city form a friends house in Nj and arrived earlier than check in which is at 3pm, the front desk staff checked us in 3 hours early without one word about check in being at 3. Also, the front desk staff ( who were very very lovely) upgraded us to a King on the 21st floor, not only did they upgrade us but we went out for dinner and came back to find a congratulatory note and a complimentary bottle of champagne and chocolates as an anniversary pressie. The room was extremely clean and the bed was soooooo comfy, I said to my husband that I think we might have had a brand new comfortor and new sheets because everything was so clean and pristene, it was like we were the first ones to ever sleep in the bed. The bathroom was equally pleasing with marbleverywhere and a seperate shower and tub. There were also fresh orchids in the bathroom which was was a very nice touch.Everytime we went in and out of the hotel the staff greeted us and were very friendly, the concierge was great and very helpful. Another plus we found was that the hotel stored our luggage for the whole day on our day of departure so we were able to walk around the city without be lagged down.Over we had an amazing anniversary and loved every aspect of this hotel and plan on returning next chance we get!

<Author>Arkansastravel

<Author>VP1
<Content>Well up to expectations This was our first visit to New York and I booked the hotel purely from the comments on this website - and the hotel more than lived up to our expectations. As mentioned in so many other reviews here, it is the staff who really make the hotel. When we checked in the Receptionist who served us was so friendly and helpful - it made such a pleasant change from hotels in the UK and Europe where staff really feel they are doing you a favour by letting you stay there. I got a Sofitel loyalty card before we arrived (again, as suggested by the reviewers on this website) so we got a free glass of champagne in the bar on our first night, which was a real treat. We didn't use the bar much after that as it was beyond our budget but would certainly have done so had we been a little wealthier!! The room was lovely and the bathroom superb. The area is fantastic - everything is very accessible from there and lots of nice restaurants and bars nearby.

<Author>Jamie&Hannah
<Content>Awesome Hotel!!! My finacee and I stayed in the hotel for 4 nights in mid February. The staff at the hotel were incredibly friendly, especially the concierge, Daniel, who recommended and booked some fantastic restaurants for us at very short notice. If you want the best steak you've ever had, then go to Morton's on 5th, but for breakfast, then the Red Flame diner has to be done (it's right next to the hotel). For burgers, go to Connelly's and don't forget to go to the Stage deli on Broadway for the biggest sandwiches! Anyway, the hotel room was cleaned daily with fresh towels and has massive floor to ceiling windows with great views of the city. The beds really are a comfy as the reviews say - getting up in the morning was quite difficult! The bathroom is modern, with a walk in shower and separate bath. There is a free Internet connection within the reception area, which is very useful. The doormen are happy to answer any questions you might have about where to go, and they'll get you a cab while you relax in the foyer. The hotels location couldn't be better for both shopping and sightseeing - most sights are within walking distance. Overall, it was a fantastic break - we can't wait to go back!!

<Author>mickko
<Content>Slightly Disappointed Expected too much, and like the last reviewer, definately not the 12th most luxury hotel in the world. I was expecting to enter some utopia completely out of this world because of the reviews left here.Stayed here 4 nights over Xmas. No Plasma in the rooms, just some dingy old Philips TV. I thought the views were a little restricted even though I was gauranteed at reception that I had a great room on top floor. Concierge were a little unattentive when we were leaving, however very helpful in organising in room massages for us. There seemed to be noise coming from some electrical room which was behind our room. Complaint was dealt with very well. Rooms and bathrooms are lovely, especially the carpet and beds. Walk around in your bare feet and if you're there to sleep, you'll have the most amazing nights sleep ever. I've never experienced anything like the comfort of the beds at this hotel. Great location for shopping, just off 5th. Gaby restaurant well worth a try.My expectation aside, this is still a top class, near-faultless hotel. What I would question is the system TA use to rate hotels. Look a little further down the list and I'm sure there are other hotels equally as good, if not better than Sofitel.

<Author>GewJayne
<Content>Simply the Best!! I chose this hotel to celebrate my wife's 40th birthday, based solely on the trip advisor reviews and was not disappointed. We stayed for four nights. (2nd-6th March 2007) Staff were extremely friendly and helpful; we had a King Size suite on the 29th floor with a terrific view of the Chrysler Building. The room was clean, spacious and the bed was the most comfortable ever! Bathroom was lovely with a deep bath plus shower and daily change of towels. I had told the hotel prior to arrival that it was my wife's birthday and as a result, a complementary bottle of 'sparkly' was sent to our room together with a letter from the manager. Nice touch I thought! I had arranged for a Sofitel Privilege Card to be sent to me prior to departure which entitled us to a 4pm check out and a free drink at the bar. (Costs nothing to apply on line) Gaby's Restaurant was 'nice' but expensive. We had one breakfast there which was fine but then tried the Red Flame Diner (which is about a thirty second walk from hotel towards Times Square) and the breakfast was more than adequate with excellent coffee. Good value too. All in all I would say that it was the best stay I've had in any hotel.

<Author>BrettLondonUK
<Content>What a welcome! Returned from a long weekend in NY to celebrate our silver wedding . After reading several reviews we plumbed for the Sofitel . You are also able to take advantage of their late checkout 16.00 as opposed to 12.00 . great when you have an evening flight like us as you get an extra day.The Red Flame Diner is 4 doors down and serves up an adequate breakfast for a fraction of the hotel prices.You are a five minute walk from times square or grand central station and have no shortage of restaurants for dinner.Use the Macy's 11% discount card when shopping there you get it from thier vistor center in the store and look for their sales as the 11% is added on. Did I mention the beds , they really are comfortable.

The bathroom was elegant, and spacious, although the bath itself was too small, but the shower cubicle was more than fine. Being so high up there was zero noise from the street.It was our wedding anniversary and we had champagne on ice delivered to our room gratis, not one evening but twice! Evening room service included two small bottles of Evian and a small box of chocolates.Room service was excellent but expensive, as was the bar and restaurant downstairs.As everyone on here has mentioned, the Red Flame diner a few feet down on the left is an absolute gem. <Author>bradgirl
<Content>My favourite hotel ever! Booked the Sofitel as part of a package on Expedia, so can't comment too much on the price, apart from to say that it seemed very reasonable.Overall this hotel was the best my partner and I have ever stayed in. It was fantastic - felt very posh, but didn't make you feel inferior when you were wearing your trainers and ear muffs on your way out!The location is awesome, a 5 minute (maybe less) walk to Times Square and lots of other New York attractions. Getting a taxi was so easy, especially because of the great guys outside the hotel who would go into the street to stop you getting snowed on or blown over in the wind. Didn't try the food in the hotel, because there's a lovely diner just down the street which serves brilliant breakfasts, and who wants to eat in a hotel at night, when you can hit the New York streets!The room was lovely, very clean and very spacious. The bed was the most comfortable bed ever, we called it our marshmallow because it was so warm and squishy. Housekeeping came in twice a day to sort the covers out, turndown service I think its called, she also brought Evian water which was a nice touch.Bathroom was perfect, bath and seperate double shower with pedestal sink and mirror with lights around (felt like a movie star!). Very quiet at night, had no trouble going to sleep, even though the street was a busy one. And no noise from other guests coming back to their rooms either. All in all, the hotel was fantastic, and if you can get a good deal, I would recommend it to anyone!!

<Author>LondonSudha
<Content>OK not brilliant We booked this hotel after reading the reviews on tripadvisor as everyone seems to think it is the best hotel in NY. Don't get me wrong it wasn't bad but it wasn't anything special. We arrived to a friendly bellman and concierge who took our suitcases promptly. we checked in and were given a room on the 15th floor. I paid for a room between floor 15-30, queen bed and city view - i got the first two but not the last. The room was small and overlooked some sort of enormous air vent. The room itself was nice enough - lots of nice goodies in the bathroom with a big marble bath and an excellent shower. The bed was very comfortable and we were only there for one night so did not see the need to ask to be moved. There is free internet downstairs which was useful for checking in to our flight the day before we left. The location is good if you're a first time New Yorker (we were not!) it is a couple of blocks from Times Square, Empire State, Grand Central etc. However, as we know NY very well now we know better places to stay and at an affordable rate. There are no little extras here and it feels like a big chain hotel with no character or anything to remember it by. Overall it was an average hotel however, as a whole although the room was very comfortable and it is in a good location for those visiting for the first time.

<Author>mrolfes
<Content>Mixed feelings, My expectations where too high. I have stayed at other Sofitels before, and the Chicago Sofitel many times. My expectations were very high because T.A. ranked the New York Sofitel best luxury hotel in America and #12 in the world, which it definetly is not. I think that is why I was disappointed. The New York Sofitel was nice, but not as nice as other Sofitels. No comparison to the Chicago Sofitel. We booked through expedia and did get a very good rate, so maybe they gave us one of their worst rooms. Our very old T.V didn't work very well, but they came up quickly to try and fix it. They offered to move us to another room, but the TV wasn't that important to us. We were told they will be updating the rooms soon, which needs to be done. On the plus side, I would stay at the NY Sofitel again and recommend it, but only if the price was right. The beds were very comfortable just like all Sofitel beds. Very clean rooms. The service was very good and quick. The staff was above average for Sofitel. This is just by comparison. In my experience some of the Sofitels front desk staff, (usually the staff from France) can be abrupt, but that is part of the French feel right. Well not in New York. Everyone was very nice, friendly and helpful. Another big plus was having The Red Flame restaurant so close. We were able to get coffee and breakfast to go to bring back to the hotel for the slowpokes. Saved us lots of time and $$$.

<Author>mhbtr
<Content>Five Stars for the Four Star My husband  I recently stayed at the Sofitel NY based upon the reviews from tripadvisor. Needless to say, we were not disappointed. I must preface these comments by stating that I am a hotel snob,  mind you, the Sofitel is not a five-star hotel, but it does not claim to be. (Although some of the service we received was better than some we have experienced at certain 5-stars.) Location: The Sofitel is situated 44th  5th, making it just about the perfect location for walking to just about anything (Times Square, Broadway, 5th Avenue, Empire State Building, Rockefeller, MOMA, etc.). Though it is a fair (but entirely manageable) walking distance to Central Park. Service: The service we received was prompt  unobtrusive. Our rooms were cleaned meticulously morning  evening; I requested once for extra towels  note was made for the remainder of our stay (unlike some other five star we've stayed). (We also appreciated the bottles of Evian  box of chocolates each evening.) The concierge was helpful at recommending restaurants  obtaining reservations. Ammenities: The fitness center was sufficiently equipped with treadmills, weights, etc. Our room was a suite on the top floor with a view of the Empire State Building from the bedroom  Rockefeller Center from the sitting room. The rooms themselves are not especially large, but more than sufficient (though more storage space would have been nice). The beds were quite comfortable. The bathroom was spacious enough (not huge)  extremely well lit. The least appealing aspect of the hotel is Gaby's where we found the food to be mediocre at best. Not bad, but not worth eating there twice. Would I recommend Sofitel to friends? ABSOLUTELY. For the great rates you can get on the rooms, I don't think you could do any better.  
<Date>Feb 27, 2007

<Author>Highlandscots
<Content>Loved Sofitel After doing much research on Trip Advisor we decided to follow everybody else and book directly and managed to get the hotel within our budget. The hotel is just perfect - we arrived and were told we had been given a upgrade on our room to a higher floor which we were delighted about. The room itself was lovely and the bathroom was to die for! The bed, as everybody else has said, was fantastic - just wish we could have fitted it in the suitcase! The hotel's location is also excellent - when you come out of the door you turn right and you are a 5 minutes walk from Times Square, on the way passing The Red Flame which is also as good as all the other reviews say, and by turning left at the hotel and after 5 minutes you are at Grand Central Station. We would recommend the Circle Line boat trip, and Empire State Building as good points to view New York.As far as steaks go, we met up with a family member who works in Manhattan and he treated us to a meal at the Capital Grille. We had the most amazing food at this restaurant starting off with French Onion Soup which was layered with Gruyere cheese. The steaks are just to die for, washed down with excellent wine and just for more badness we finished off with cheesecake .... you have to be bad sometimes! We did use a cab twice but this was only on our first evening - after finding our bearings we walked everywhere apart from going to ground zero when we took the subway. Our top tip if you are going to Macys - go to the visitor centre and collect your 11% discount card. The prices are cheap compared to what we pay at home anyway, but this makes it evey better. We absolutely loved the Sofitel and would not hesitate to go back there, or to recommend it to anybody.  
<Date>Feb 24, 2007
<Rating>5	5	5	5	5	5	5	5	

<Author>Leyton
<Content>Fantastic! My girlfriend and I stayed at the Sofitel over the New Year. The hotel is great. We chose it because it was rated number one on tripadvisor and it didn't disappoint.The room was extremely clean, a good size and the bed is like sleeping on a cloud. As others have mentioned, if you are in New York for a special occasion let the front desk know in advance. We were there for my girlfriend's birthday and after mentioning this we were given a room on a higher floor and champagne (sparkling wine).The hotel is in a great location and is within walking distance of most of the big tourist sites (Times Square, Fifth Avenue, Empire State Building etc.)My top tip - register for the Sofitel privelege card. It's free and you gets you guaranteed late check in, free drinks on arrival and late check out (4pm) which was great as we had a night flight back to the UK.Next time I'm in New York I know where I'll be staying...

<Rating>5	4	5	5	5	5	5	4	

<Author>AlysonP
<Content>Its all true... the negative comments are fools! Every word of the positive reviews on Tripadvisor are true, we picked this hotel, after lots of homework, for our 5 day honeymoon over Valentines weekend. We took the advice and joined the hotels priviledge club and was upgraded to a higher floor room with a king bed and a view of the Chrysler Building. We got 2 free drinks at the bar (champagne) chocolates and a bedding turn down every night not to mention the free bottle of champagne sent up to help us get our honeymoon off to an amazing start!EVERY member of staff work terrifically hard to give you a great feeling about this hotel and it became 'home' for us on our trip. In New York the people are not always too friendly so it was refreshing to get back to the luxury and oasis of service that is the SofitelInstead of boring you by repeating what has already been said about this amazing hotel. I will give you our tips for a great trip to NY, and also things to avoidWe didnt try the breakfast at the hotel and followed others advice and went to the red flame diner a couple of doors down from the hotel. A bit rough and ready, but good food and service make it all good and great value.If you want to really splash out and have a world class breakfast, take a cab to Le Parker Meridian up near Central Park, and BOOK into Norma's inside Le Meridian, all they do is breakfast and boy do they do it well, outstanding and a bit pricy but you will NEVER have a better breakfast, make sure you book, while we were there people were being quoted 1.5 hours for a table and still staying!!At the same venue is a Burger Joint that you wouldnt find in a month of Sundays, tiny place hidden behind a curtain at Le Meridian, signed only by a small neon burger sign, keep an eye out for it, its easy to miss! World Class burgers and fries, and thats all they do but wow its done well.Avoid Rainbow Room Grill like the plague, it was a fab view no doubt there but the food was appalling and they 'recommend' a 20% tip on a $300 bill, and that was with no dessert or coffee, massive rip off and not to be repeated.Book in at Metrazur in Grand Central Terminal - sounds mad to eat in a station, but what a station, the ambiance is amazing and ask when you book for a balcony table, you wont speak much but you will marvel at the view!After Metrazur cross the main floor up the stairs, come out of the main doors and turn left and head into Campbells Apartment, a hidden gem of a cocktail bar, small and atmospheric...the mojitos and prohibition punch were the best we have ever tasted!Gotham Bar and Grill was divine, words cant measure it, service and food to die for, every bit was amazing.Go to Woodbury Outlet about an hour out of the city for discount designer shopping heaven!! We went by bus so got to asee a bit of the countrysideForget about Empire State building, the place is a dump, queues were 3.5 hours and once I got up there I couldnt wait to come down as I was so naffed off from queuing and pushing, it was rubbish...head for Top of the Rock at the Rockerfeller centre, no queue, up and down in 30 mins, and much nicer, glass panels so you can see more, a bit smaller than Empire State but the same experience, but no queuing and messing about. TRUST ME ON THIS ONEAll our meals were reseached on Zagat...highly recommended .. and booked through OpenTable.. again really recommended. Thats it, amazing trip, if you go to any of these places you WILL NOT BE DISAPPOINTED

<Author>ninewinx
<Content>A few concerns I haven't read all the reviews but I have found this website to be on target most of the time. We liked the Sofitel and it was a good value with a few caveats...1. The security is very lax. There are two entrances- one through the front lobby and another from the restaurant. There is open access to all floors with no limitation provided by insertion of the hotel keycard. Anyone could be followed to their room.2. The bed is comfortable but there was no sheet - just a duvet cover. 3. The heating system hums.4. I was told the windows were triple paned and that the rooms were quiet. Unfortunately, we heard the garbage pick-up at 4 am every night- even on the 11th floor.5. Breakfast was $30 per person in the restaurant. Go out the restaurant door  across the street for your Starbucks and into the little grocery store for a very complete and inexpensive alternative.6. There are other boutique hotels with better locations for the theater district.

<Author>atateka
<Content>Sofitel Aims to Please We have just returned from our fifth stay at Sofitel. It's tempting to explore other properties, but it's a gamble as well. At Sofitel we know we will be greeted warmly, the concierges and doormen will be tremendously helpful, the elevators fast, and the room clean and quiet.We love the excitment of the city, but really appreciate the calm and quiet of this hotel. We went to the Marriot Marquis to enjoy a drink from the 48th floor. While that was nice, we could not imagine staying at that hotel. It was loud, crowded, huge, and too busy for our tastes.Many reviewers mention the Red Flame, and that is a good choice. We also like Cafe Manhattan which is on 45th. If you exit the hotel from Gaby's restaurant you will see it's red awning across the street. They have a nice selection of fresh fruits, vegetables, breakfast and lunch choices. While there is no wait staff, there are tables for patrons. It's clean, bright, and quiet by NYC standards.I find it remarkable that many of the same staff remain at Sofitel year after year. The staff is knowledgeable, warm and friendly. Guests are often greeted by name and always politely. I would encourage anyone to stay here. Sofitel has excellent standards of customer service and hospitality.

<Author>warum
<Content>Good hotel in central location Due to the excellent ratings at Tripadvisor we booked Sofitel New York from Dec. 21 - 25, 2006. We stayed in a standard room (347,20 USD Tax incl.) and a suite (503,00 USD Tax incl.) located on the 22th and 26th floor.The plus:- modern rooms in good condition, very clean, comfortable bathroom with separate shower stall,- turn down with a free bottle of still water,- good locationThe minus:- a la carte breakfast menu only (quite expensive, just a few choices), no breakfast buffet,- lobby with not inviting atmosphere (too cool music),- no shoe shine service available (not even a machine),- a dvd-player (which is not standard in a suite) was brought to the room free of charge but there was a country code restriction so you couldn't play an european dvd (an international hotel chain should be better prepared with its technical equipment),- the last morning housekeeping first disturbed at about 8am and came back twice within the next hour! When coming back after breakfast the bedding was already changed and the luggage stored in the corridor,- a forgotten tie wasn't found two hours after checking out (it probably was thrown away from the housekeeping).In total Sofitel has nice and comfortable rooms, a good location but some aspects to improve. Compared to others N.Y. hotels one can recommend the hotel when the rate is O.K. P.S. Although we are Sofitel privelige card holders we didn't get a free welcome drink or choclate.

<Author>JLTP
<Content>Tasteful My wife and I had a lovely stay at the Sofitel. While there are certainly glitzier, more opulent hotels in midtown Manhattan, the Sofitel did all the little things right. They have friendly, attentive desk staff; a quiet lobby; valet parking (not very common in NYC); and clean, reasonably spacious rooms done in tasteful decor. Plus the location is great--right near Times Square and the theatre district. While not inexpensive, it was a relatively good value. All in all, this is a very good choice.
