<Author>lovemypup
<Content>A complete bargain for NYC!! I am a self-professed hotel snob, and am still mourning the closing of the Plaza. I have since stayed at the St Regis, Trump International, Waldorf Towers, and Four Seasons. They are all nice, and expensive. That's fine. . .you get what you pay for. I saw the rates of the Sofitel (booked on their website for around $250/nt) for three nights in late July. I didn't have the highest of expectations given the price for a hotel in NYC, but boy what a pleasant surprise. I was able to check in almost 2 hours early, and took advantage of their late check-out, and I greatly enjoyed the location in midtown. The twice daily maid service was wonderful, including morning service on the day I checked out! I echo everyone else's comments on the beds, the great Roger  Gallet amenities, the huge bathroom, and I greatly appreciated the peace and quiet (and I was in a room right by the elevator) and rarely heard anyone outside in the hallway. Finally, my room on the 14th floor didn't have much of a view, but it was nice and quiet and comfortable. I believe I may have finally found a new home base in NYC!! Merci Sofitel!!

<Author>goldberry
<Content>Where there's smoke, there's fire There's a reason that the Sofitel is ranked #1 for NYC hotels on TripAdvisor. The service is simply excellent. Yes, the hotel is elegant and clean and the beds are fantastic, but the service is what really sets them apart.We arrived and were warmly welcomed to an early check-in on our room, which had been upgraded. The staff is beautifully trained and friendly, even when they're just passing in the hallway or the lobby. The room was so clean and nice, and the beds ensure that you won't do much sight-seeing because it's too hard to get out of them. Plenty of immediate hot water in the bathroom. In fact, be careful because it you're like me, you're used to waiting for a long time at other hotels. You won't be waiting here, so watch your fingers. The bath products are a cut above most of those you receive in hotels. It was a nice touch to receive complimentary Evian water at evening turndown, but if you want more than water, the bar has an amazing wine selection. Granted, the prices aren't what I'd call a bargain, but the selection gets kudos.All in all, we had an excellent experience, and we'd stay here again, especially after discovering Kellari Taverna, a wonderful Greek restaurant, just a few doors down. We were cautious about staying at an unknown hotel chain, but the raves in TripAdvisor swayed us. Glad they did!

<Content>Good hotel .. great location .. The place was spotless, decor was in good condition throughout. The rooms - spacious, clean, quality decor,large well equipped bathroom. The bed was total comfort - nice to return to after long days out  about. Hotel  surrounding streets were quiet throughout the stay - so no issues getting a good night sleep (6th floor). Ate room service only once (breakfast) - quality  service was v.good. Room prices were a little on the steep side, plus no coffee-making facility in the room - main reasons it didn't score 5/5 for me. Otherwise, if you're happy paying the money - I don't think you'll be too disappointed with a stay at this hotel.

<Author>HUTCH1113
<Content>Top Notch Hotel My wife and I took our annual trip to NYC on July 13th and returned on July 17th, so we got to spend 3 fabulous nights at the Sofitel. Once I laid on the bed for the first time, I wished I was staying there for a month. The room itself is a perfect size with plenty of storage for clothes and anything else you may want to store. We were also extremely happy with the bathroom and the oversized towels that were provided. The bathroom was tastefully decorated, had great lighting and there was tons of room for a NYC bathroom. We stayed in room 1720 and had a nice view of the Chrysler building at night. During the day, you were looking down into an alley and on rooftops. Not very appealing, but the night time made up for it.The location can not be beat, as it is right on 44th street between 5th and 6th avenue. Extremely close to all the great midtown attractions, yet in its own little quiet world. In fact, you would never know that you are only a block and a half from the ever bustling Times Square. We ate at the Red Flame diner next door one evening and had a very nice meal for a reasonable price. We sat by the window, so we got to watch NY walk by as we ate. Also.....I wanted to extend thanks to the Sofitel for the following reason. The day before we were set to leave, my wife got food poisoning from the Rock Center Cafe in Rockefeller Center. She was sick all day and night to the point she couldnt even stand up. Our flight did not leave until 8:30pm on that day, so we had originally planned to store our luggage and do some more sightseeing. Well, that obviously wasnt going to happen. I asked the front desk if we could have late check out (only expecting a couple hours at most). She gave us until 8pm for no extra charge because of the circumstances. Normally, they would charge half the daily rate which would have been an extra $175. Needless to say, we were very grateful for their cooperation. Also, in past cases where we have been granted late checkout, the housekeepers bother you every 15 minutes until you leave. We stayed until 6pm without a peep out of anyone. That was very appreciated since my wife was asleep. I thoroughly enjoyed this hotel. I didnt have one complaint.  
<Date>Jul 25, 2006

<Author>vml5
<Content>Solid Four Star Hotel We just got back from staying at the Hotel Sofitel for the weekend. After taking a red eye flight, we arrived at the hotel around 7am on Sat. The front desk graciously checked us in immediately, and upgraded our room to the extent possible. They had no problem with our early arrival. Doormen, concierge, bellhop and front desk were all very friendly and polite.We stayed in a regular (petite) queen room...the deluxe was not yet available. By NY standards, the room size was average (on the smaller side...two people could not walk together in the hallway/path leading to the room's door). Small amenities like down comforters and pillows and complimentary evian water and fresh orchids in the bathroom were nice touches. The bathroom was average with a separate tub and shower, one sink with an over sized vanity. Everything done in marble, glass and chrome finishes. Soft padded carpeting, terry robes, and digital thermostat control gave the room a comfortable feel. The rooms were clean and so was the bedding and carpet.We had drinks and dessert at the Gaby restaurant downstairs. Prices were normal for NY, leaning on the high side. The raspberry tart was about $17 and very mediocre. The hotel is close to the theater district/Times Square so if you want to be in that area, this is the perfect hotel for you.Overall, this is a solid four star hotel which earns all four stars. I would stay here again.

<Author>doggiebus
<Content>Great Everything Location, Service, Room Great Hotel. We checked in Thursday at 1:30 in the afternoon and checked out Sunday morning with no problems. Got to the room, very nicely decorated and the bed was very comfortable. For NYC the room was a good size. The Queen size bed we had, was fine. (FYI, We sleep in a California King Size bed at home) We had a view of the GE building which was nice for NYC standards. I loved that our luggage was hidden in the closets and the clothing too. My husband wished there were more drawers, he is an unpacker at hotels, which I am not. The bathroom was nice, the tub isn't the Ritz, but the shower was niice. The shower condiments smelled so nice too. They have a speaker in the bathroom that is connected to the TV, whcih is a nice feature. Other than hearing a phone ring from the room next door late one night, it was quite. Not sure if that means the walls are thin or not? We actually never saw a person on the floor the whole trip. Anyways, concierge was helpful. The Sofitel is in walking distance of the GE Building, Rockefeller Center, Empire State Building, Time Square, Central Park, 5th Avenure Shopping, Saks, Macy's, St. Patricks Cathedral, the U.N, Grand Central Station. There is a diner style restaurant called the Red Flame, that is great to get the day started with lots of carbs. Its on the same bloack as the hotel (44th between 5th and 6th) but closer to 6th. I would highly recommend staying here.

<Author>Postcorner
<Content>A class above We too stayed here based on tripadvisor and all I can say is thank you, thank you, thank you tripadvisor and of course, Sofitel.Not to brag, but we have been lucky enough to stay in hotels all over the world and this is quite possibly the very best.We read the reviews and, knowing New York, were trying not to build our hopes up. Well we shouldn't have worried.It was my partners 30th birthday and, following a tip on here, I emailed the hotel. On arrival we had been upgraded to a high floor room and on our first night had a complimentary (full size) bottle of champagne. The staff at reception were wonderfully polite and pleasant as were the bar staff, concierge and cleaning staff.The attention to detail in the room was amazing, plentiful soaps and accessories, even candles. After one night the staff had learned where we liked things and left the room as we liked it rather than rearrange things every day (I find that so annoying in most hotels). There is even a turndown service with complimentary water (necessary in the heat), fresh towels, etc. The staff were always very friendly and courteous and we didn't feel disturbed in anyway. They respected us as customers and you didn't feel like you were disrupting their schedule, as you often do elsewhere.The standard of cleanliness is impecable and the size of the room very generous for New York. The bed, well, just amazingly comfortable, even little details like the bottom pillow being slightly bigger had been thought of.Can't say enough, complimentary internet, very nice evening bar area and it goes on.I have never stayed in a Sofitel before and will certainly be using them again. I would not stay anywhere else in New York, that's for sure. The hotel is quite obviously managed extremely well and hopefully the standards won't slip as it becomes more and more popular thanks to tripadvisor.Oh and location, 200 yards from 5th avenue, 3 blocks from times square and the deli just on the right as you head to sixth, The Red Flame, serves a hearty breakfast. In short, (at last!) everything about Sofitel New York was just perfect and made our trip quite possibly the most pleasant vacation we've ever had.

<Author>Hank298
<Content>Without Peer I had a dual purpose stay in NYC, July 7-9, celebrating my anniversary and meeting with a significant client. I made reservations at the Sofitel Hotel because of the high recommendations made here. I was not disappointed.From the time of our arrival we were treated as honored guests. In looking for a location in the hotel to meet with my client I was introduced to the business sales director, Ms Francoise Christine, and she personally took us to several rooms to find the perfect setting for my meeting. The first evening, just prior to our night on the town to celebrate our anniversary, my wife and I were treated to a wonderful bottle of French champagne, compliments of the hotel. The beds were totally as advertised and our suite on the 25th floor had a great view and was a bargain by New York standards. You really can't find a better location for a pleasure visit. It's central to everything..... 5th Avenue shopping, Times Square, and the theater district. Everything was within easy walking distance.Away from the hotel, which is hard to leave because of the pleasantries of the entire staff, we saw Mamma Mia, which was great, light-hearted fun. We dined the first evening at the Divine Bar known for its wine and tapa selections. While nice, it didn't meet the standards of the recommendations I had read. Nevertheless, it was very convenient to Broadway and our show that evening.Our second night we dined with my clients at Michael's Restaurant, W. 55th St., on the recommedation of my next door neighbor and we arrived on celebrity night! We dined early and the restaurant was almost empty on our arrival at 6:15pm and the group following us in included Mary Tyler Moore and Bernadette Peters. Shortly afterward, Frank Gifford took the table next to ours (sans Kathy Lee) with another couple. The food was quite good (I'm a tough food critic) but the ambience and wine selection were wonderful. We completed the evening with a visit to the Gotham City Comedy Club headling Tony Rock, Chris Rock's younger brother. Anyone going to NYC should strongly consider a visit to the Sofitel Hotel. It's a great value and they out-Ritz the Ritz!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Simply The Best We have just returned from six nights at the New York Sofitel.Whilst this is our first Tripadvisor report - our opinion of the Sofitel is based on comparison with a variety of Hotels across four continents.Our 'Best' Hotels to date have been the Shangri La Singapore and the Bangkok Marriott Resort  Spa.Until now we had not stayed at a Sofitel Hotel.So why has staying at the Sofitel caused us to go into print?Because the Hotel made a great visit to New York even better.We were on the 23rd floor with a great view of the Chrysler Building.The room was a good size with ample space around the bed and a separate seating area.The bathroom had both bath and separate walk-in shower which we consider essential.The non-smoking room was well presented, clean with good quality furniture, towels etc.The bed was simply the best Hotel bed we have experienced - just so comfortable.The room was serviced twice a day which meant when you dropped back to the Hotel (great location 鈥?central but quiet) to have a midday shower (its hot and humid in July) you knew that the clean room and towels you were using would be replaced for the evening.Best of all - all the staff are so friendly, informative and helpful.Meals were expensive compared to local eateries.We choose to to eat out for three quarters of the time on the basis of cost and also to experience New Yorkers food 鈥?but when we did eat in the Hotel we found the food and service excellent. Why was the Sofitel New York so different and so good?It is very difficult to put into words - we have stayed in many Hotels which provide equally as good rooms, clean beds and showers, a pleasant ambiance, friendly staff and are situated in good locations.But being at the Sofitel just made us 鈥榝eel鈥?good.The overall experience was greater than the sum of the parts.You will just have to try it for yourself.

<Author>57sport
<Content>1st Rate Accomodations  Returned late Mon night after spending 3.5 days @ this beautiful hotel. The positive reviews posted on this forum were right on target. Visited NYC w/ Mom, 2 sisters, cousin and her friend, June 30 - July 3. I was the only one in our party that had never visited the city before and each encounter with anyone was friendly (almost as good as the south).If you've never been to the Sofitel, please go, if only for 1 night. The room was very spacious and we were on the 21st floor. I speak a little French and was amazed that each french-speaking employee took the time to slowly ask questions and respond to mine to make sure I understood. Formidable!I travel quite a bit for pleasure and the ammenities were top notch. Ditto to each post regarding the room  the hotel. We were 2 to a room and the european twin beds (longer and wider than standard twin in the states, although not as wide as a full bed) were parallel to the Wynn beds in Las Vegas. Registration as well as check-out was a breeze; concierge (Vladimir) has lots of patience with guests on the phone or in line at his desk. The bellman could answer our questions specific to any subject and made sure we understood his directions.Due to time restraints we were able to cram lots of attractions, however, will return to complete the sights. Bring very comfortable shoes, lots of water and a camera, as this is a walking city, sort of like San Francisco, without the hills.Once you've had a taste of the luxurious atmosphere at the Sofitel, you won't want to stay anywhere else. I absolutely, positively, give the Sofitel 5 stars in all catergories and can't wait to return! Au Revoir et Bon Soir mes amies...

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Best hotel experience - ever! We chose this hotel thanks to Trip Advisor, and we're so glad we did. All the other reviews are spot on; it's difficult to praise the Sofitel NYC too much. The comfy bed, sumptuous bathroom and quality decor are all as previously described. We thought we'd mention a few special touches that really impressed us.In the bathroom we had both a generous shower cubicle and a full-sized bath. Far too many clean towels appeared every day and the toilet roll was regularly folded into a neat pointy shape at the end when the cleaning staff had visited. They also left us complimentary bottles of Evian and a handy card telling us what the weather would be like the following day. The staff were friendly and helpful the whole time. We even spotted the doorman handing out an umbrella to a random passer-by as she was getting so soaked (it rained a lot while we were there). We loved the xylophone chime the staff used to summon the porters (obviously we weren't allowed to carry our own cases).The only thing to avoid would be using room service - which is very expensive. And don't believe what you see in the main mirror either - we've never looked so tall and thin!We got a very good deal on a Premier Queen room, so much so that we were convinced there must have been some mistake! We'll definitely be going back, but now we've seen pictures of the King rooms...

<Author>golffanatic
<Content>Fantastic hotel (just one "but"...) My daughter and I stayed at the Sofitel at the end of April and were delighted with the hotel, in common with most other reviewers - room and bathroom very clean, very comfortable beds and friendly staff. Despite all the good mentions of the diner just outside the hotel, we decided to be lazy and had room service breakfast every day, which was brought up by a delightful lady. However, on the last night, when we came to settle the bill, we noticed that there was a charge of approximately $50 for Gaby's Restaurant food, and we had only been to Gaby's for one drink on one occasion. On further enquiry, this turned out to be a breakfast of French Toast. When I asked to see the signed bill, someone had written my surname (but spelt it wrongly) and my room number. As we had obviously not been there, due to the room service breakfast, the item was deducted from my account. In view of this, I feel there should be some form of checking when signing in the hotel, and the fact that my name was on it, was quite worrying. As I was checking out of the hotel, I asked for the manager's email address. I was given a business card, which I later noticed was an Assistant Front Office Manager's card. I emailed her when I returned, but six weeks later, have had no response.As I said at the beginning of this review, overall we were delighted with the hotel and would certainly return, but I am disappointed that no-one saw fit to reply to my email.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>The only problem was I didn't want to leave! An exceptionally great hotel, very clean (I'm very fussy about that kind of thing!) and the location couldn't have been better for a base to explore NYC.When we checked in the lady at reception said as we were staying for a full week that they would upgrade us to a King room which had a view of the Empire State Building!I know everyone reviewing the hotel has mentioned the beds, but they are most definitely worth mentioning again! it was like sleeping on a big fluffy white cloud! exactly what is needed after full days and nights of shopping, sightseeing and enjoying NYC nightlife.I think that although the hotel is a bit expensive it is worth it as NYC can get a bit hectic and I personally found the Sofitel to be a comfortable and relaxing haven to recharge!The buses were a great way to get around and see more sights, we paid 24 dollars to get a weeks pass which is unlimited travel on the buses and also the subway (which is about a million times better than the London underground) otherwise each trip is 2 dollars regardless of destination.I personally found New Yorkers to be incredibly friendly and very helpful. I hope anyone choosing the Sofitel will have a great stay as we did.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Perfect in every way We were spending only one night in New York, so I did a lot of online research to pick one that sounded nice, comfortable, was convenient to the theater district but not right in it, and which fit our budget of $300 or less. Based on the reviews here, I chose Sofitel and booked the cheapest room at $259. What a great deal -- you get so much for what you pay, particularly in New York.As recommended, I mentioned it was our anniversary online, not thinking anything would come of it, but when we arrived, the extremely friendly and helpful Gabrielle told us we had been given a deluxe room on the 27th floor. We had a view of Chrysler Building (and the Puerto Rican Day Parade preparations the next morning) and there was sparking wine waiting for us with a thoughtful note.The bed indeed was the most comfortable I've ever slept in. The room was big by any standards, and the bathroom was enormous by any standards. Both a shower and a tub (with a detachable showerhead), large sink with a large lit mirror, mood lighting, a candle, and fresh flowers. Lots of closet space with all different kinds of hooks. The blackout curtains were great, as we were up late the night before. The room was totally dark. Best of all was the soundproofing. Not only could we not hear any street noise, particularly the preparation for the Puerto Rican Day Parade, replete with bands and DJs blaring full blast as we discovered when we went outside, but, most incredible of all, when I opened the door, I discovered someone vacuuming right outside our door. I couldn't even hear the vacuum when I was on the other side of the door!Left our bags with the concierge as we explored the city on Sunday. No charge to leave the bags. Also, when we checked in the night before, Gabrielle asked if we wanted late checkout. Staff was extremely helpful. We were sad to go and wished we could have stayed longer.Only criticisms: bathrobes were a bit scratchy (big deal) and the air conditioning was finicky. Either too cold or too warm, even if you only adjusted it one notch.  
<Date>Jun 12, 2006
<Rating>5	5	5	-1	5	-1	5	-1	

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Sofitel NYC = Fantastic Just got back from a quick 2 night get away to NYC with my girlfriend. We had been to NYC once before but stayed in a different hotel. I did a lot of research this time around and all the reviews on this website about the Sofitel are bang on.We had a great room with one of the best beds in the world! I think it was better than my bed at home. Anyways, hotel staff was great and very friendly. The hotel was pretty quite for NYC and overall a great atmosphere.As for location you are about 1 minute to all the shopping on 5th and 6th Avenue, 5 mins to Times Square, 15 minutes to Central Park.One suggestion is to join their rewards program on-line (it is free) you get a late check-out (if you ask 4pm) which is perfect for a late flight, 2 free drinks at the bar and points towards a free stay.Next time we go to NYC we will be staying at the Sofitel.

<Author>labyrinthhuntrr
<Content>Great stay at a well-run hotel My husband and I stayed at the Sofitel this past weekend. The hotel is beautiful, with fresh flowers and a deep, thick carpet in the lobby. Even the lobby music was hip and subtle, but not pretentious. We didn't go to any Broadway shows this trip, but it would have been a convenient location if we had decided to do so.We locked ourselves out of our room, and the front desk staff was polite and quickly gave us new room keys. Storing luggage and having taxis called was also done politely and efficiently.Our room had a view of the city. The art hung in the room was tasteful and romantic. The bed and bedding were very clean and comfortable. The bathroom included a marble shower and a standard tub. The room service menu was extensive and delivered quickly, if somewhat pricey.If I had to nitpick, I would note that only one washcloth and one bathrobe was in the room (although I'm sure if we had requested more, they would have been provided). One of the closets did not close properly without some finagling. The bathroom had double doors, which left a small gap between them. However, these were definitely minor issues and we thoroughly enjoyed our stay, and would return.

<Author>ardenp
<Content>Fabulous hotel! We stayed at the Sofitel for a quick anniversary getaway in Manhattan - I picked it based on its excellent reviews on this site, and couldn't have been more pleased. The service was amazing - we checked in early, got upgraded to a suite when they didn't have a room on the upper floors (which I had reserved online) and received a complimentary bottle of champagne with a handwritten note congratulating us on our anniversary! (I recommend mentioning this in the comments section when making the reservation). The bed was very comfortable with luxurious linens (very similar to the Westin Heavenly Bed), and the bathroom was beautiful as well. The suite was spacious (we did see the standard sized room as well and it was reasonably sized). The room was well soundproofed.I had looked at many of the other luxury hotels in Manhattan - I can't imagine how they could have been any nicer than the Sofitel, which was priced more reasonably. I would definitely stay there again, and would consider staying at its other resort locations in the future.

<Author>HappyTravelers4106
<Content>Join the Club! My husband and I stayed at this hotel while we were visiting New York for a wedding. We joined the Sofitel privilege card club on the internet just a few hours before we checked in. We requested via-e-mail our card number so we could add it to our reservation. We called ahead and gave the number, which meant we got an upgraded room, late check out, free use of the gym and a two free drinks at the bar. It's absolutely worth taking a few minutes to sign up. Definitely try the French Martini's at the bar! The rooms at this hotel were very clean and pretty spacious. I was surprised they did not have a coffee pot which would have been nice and a friend ordered a pot of coffee for an nearly morning wake up only to find they brought her decaff. But the location of this hotel is perfect if you want to be in the heart of things and if you are seeing any Broadway shows. Almost everything is within walking distance or a quick cab ride. The staff was helfpul if not overly friendly. We would definitley recommend this hotel for nice getaway in the City.

<Author>KeysOceanDrive
<Content>Sofitel New York - ASK for extras! We stayed at the Sofitel for 3 nights (May 20-23, '06). We paid $302.35 each night including taxes thru Expedia when booked with our airfare. I have seen better and I have seeen worse rates....Another guest did the following which I think are excellent ideas- I didn't read thoroughly enough though to do this for our visit- I hope you do....: -emailed the hotel prior to arrival to confirm booking and request a room with a good view- also mentioned that it as a special trip for both-On arrival they were given -a free upgrade to a deluxe Queen room on the top floor (29th) with an amazing view of the Chrysler Building- a complimentary bottle of Champagne on ice with 2 small boxes of chocolates and bottled water- It's in a great location, with plenty going on in the surrounding area - between 5th  6th Aves. at 44th 45th Sts. Theatre district to the west and shopping to the north.-Our room was #1414, no view but still nice. Very neutral decor and everything is newer and updated throughout.- The room was a nice size with a desk, chair, 2 side chairs and table, mini bar ($5.50 for 1 can of Diet Coke), 2 nightstands, safe large enough for laptop, built in lighted closet and shelves for clothing. -The bed was very comfortable., it felt like you were sandwiched between two duvet covers, ask for a top sheet though!- Nice marble seperate shower, sink and porc. bathtub , makeup mirror, towels were large but not thick and fluffy- given 3 for 2 peoplle, ask for more if needed!- That diner is really good and convenient, Starbucks out the back door thru the restaurant.-Restaurant/bar nice for after dinner drink, decorated in leopard prints.-We would definitely stay there again!And do take the Top of the Rock tour at Rockefeller! Also, the Boathouse restaurant in Central Park was beautiful on the pond on a beautiful sunny May day! Also the discount tickets box office has been moved off of Times Square (think west) near the Marriott Marquis Hotel!

<Author>Westonian
<Content>An unusually quiet NYC hotel We stayed in a basic double room facing 45th Street on the 16th floor for the Internet rate of $399 + $56.89 taxes = 455.89. The check-in was fast at a well-staffed front desk. The room, while not large, was well furnished and well-equipped with the exception of coffee/tea-making equipment, which is not even available from housekeeping on demand. The bathroom had a separate, glassed-in shower stall. Everything in both the bedroom and the bathroom was like new.The biggest plus was the excellent soundproofing, which yielded total silence throughout the night -- no trace of any traffic noise -- something not provided by many much more expensive NYC hotels. Another unusual plus in New York City was the very smart, polite, efficient and apparently bilingual staff in both the hotel and the restaurant.The biggest minus was the lack of coffee/tea making equipment. The minimal continental breakfast from Room Service costs just under $25 per person when the taxes and mandatory tip are factored in. Check-out was fast and accurate.

<Rating>5	5	5	-1	5	-1	5	-1	

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Excellent Location - Great Hotel Stayed at the Sofitel for 3 nights between 20th April to 23rd April 2006 which was purely based on the recommendations on Trip Advisor and I am pleased to say I was not disappointed. I booked it online direct with the Sofitel as I found this was cheaper. The trip was a surprise for my husbands 40th birthday and after requesting a high floor we got a free upgrade on arrival to floor 26. (We didnt get the champagne that others have mentioned but didnt let this spoil it). The reception staff and Concierge were always helpful and we were allowed to check out 1 hour later and left our luggage at the front desk until we had to catch our flight.Great view from our wiindow of the Chrysler Building and round the corner from Empire State Building. The room size was ample for the two of us and yes the beds are the best we have ever slept in. We have never walked as much as we did in New York and we felt the comfort of the beds more than met our standards. (I agree you do need comfortable shoes). Bathroom was quite large and the room had lovely finishing touches and we were told the weather forecast and given free water every night by the maid service. Did not eat at the Sofitel mainly due to being expensive but there are so many great places to eat that this was not a problem. Turn right when you come out of the hotel and there is a great diner called Red Flame which serves great breakfasts which were great value. Also try Planet Hollywood they do BOGOF drinks between 4 and 6 pm. Other good places were TGI Fridays which had several locations throughout NY. There are a couple of good Irish pubs on 45th Street, one of which is called Connollys which do nice food and it has a good atmosphere. On a Sunday there is a big street market going down this street which was quite good.The hotel is located within 5mins walk from Times Square and close to Grand Central Station, Chrysler building, ESB, Bryant Park and Rockefellar centre. It took us about 15-20mins to walk to Central Park. We used the subway to get down to Ground Zero and the Statue of Liberty which was hassle free. One experience worth doing is the Helicopter Tour called the Big Apple which takes you over the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island and down the Hudson river with Liberty Helicopters. Try to catch a show on Broadway, we went to see Chicago at the Ambassador Theatre which was excellent. Shopping in New York is excellent we found Maceys as one of the best stores (dont forget to get your discount card from the customer service desk in Maceys). We flew into Newark and got taxis to and from the Sofitel which cost about 拢35 including tip one way. Whilst in NY we had two extreme sides of the weather - first 2 days were scorching hot and the last 2 days were downpours but the hotel very kindly borrowed us a large umbrella so we were still able to walk about and not get wet. We flew with Continental airlines which were also excellent and by being able to check in online at the hotel we found this saved us queuing up at Newark. All we had to do was drop off our suitcases at a desk. New York is a great city where we felt safe walking around and we would definitely stay at the Sofitel again, its a bit pricey as you don't spend much time in your bedroom while visiting NY but well worth it for a once in a lifetime visit.  
<Date>May 18, 2006
<Rating>5	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1

<Author>mcmdee
<Content>One of the best city hotels ever! If you look at all the previous reviews, you'll see a recurring theme, so I won't go on too long in this review. In a nutshell, if you look for the following in a hotel when going on a city break, then don't waste your time searching for other NY hotels because Sofitel New York has it all:1) Excellent location for both sightseeing and transport2) Spacious rooms and good facilities, ie soft beds, lovely bathrooms3) Friendly and efficient staff in every department4) Fairly priced for the luxury obtained (even cheaper if booked as a package on Expedia)5) Spotlessly clean grand lobby and floors - high attention paid to maintenance6) Nice touches, eg free bottled water, robes, etcIf you're going to New York on a medium budget, STAY HERE!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Highly recommended hotel in a great location I booked this hotel on the strength of previous positive postings and I was not disappointed. You felt like an important guest from the moment of your arrival. The doormen (Special mention to Randy and William) who were very helpful.Check-in was quick and painless and you didn't have to wait an age for the lift to arrive!Usually rooms in NYC are relatively small (ie not much room to swing a cat) but its fair to say that my jaw dropped when I entered our room. It was huge!! And the bathroom was a decent size with both a shower cubicle and a bath (being 5 foot one I fitted in it perfectly!) The curtains were heavy and thick so it was easy to fall asleep at night. A fresh bottle of evian with a note on the following days weather forecast was also left every night.I would disagree with previous comments about not going up the Empire State if you've never done it before. All I would say is go first thing in the morning or late at night to avoid the queues - the view is incredible. Other suggestions would be:-Take the free Staten Island Ferry - the views of the Statue of Liberty and Manhattan are amazing on a clear day. The crossing takes roughly half an hour. Take the subway to Bowling Green then its just across the road.Head to Strawberry Fields in Central Park - there's usually a good crowd with musicians so you can have a sing song.I would also recommend the Monkey Bar which is on East 54th Street between Madison and Park Avenue. For all you Sex and the City fans - this is where Carrie and Big decide to be friends after their affair. It's very chic and moody and the Cosmopolitans are to die for!  
<Date>Apr 28, 2006
<Rating>5	5	5	-1	5	-1	5	-1

<Author>eurolondoner
<Content>It's the human touch that makes the difference I concur with most of your other reviewers: this is a truly wonderful hotel. To me, however, it is the people who mostly make the different. I stayed at the hotel during the February snow blizzard, and my plane was cancelled. The hotel concierge, Dimitri, spent hours on the phone to try and sort out the problem with the airline. The rest of the staff were ever so flexible about telling me I could tell them at the last minute if I needed to extend my stay and pledging to offer the same (highly discounted) rate I had paid for my one night stay. Rooms are beautiful and pleasant, room service breakfast was lovely, and once again, the staff are some of the best I have met.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Perfect Stay We stayed at the Sofitel for a long weekend trip to the Big Apple and absolutely loved it. Absolutely no complaints. The hotel has a beautiful lobby with lots of comfortable seating, the staff throughout the hotel was courteous and helpful, and our room was gorgeous. Not the biggest room in the world - but as I've heard, much bigger than most rooms in New York. The bed was fantastic, the room was very, very clean, and I LOVED the bathroom. Particularly, the feature of a separate bath and shower is really nice. In general, the hotel was perfectly lovely, and within close walking distance to SO much. Grand Central Station, the NYC Public Library, Times Square, broadway, and many, many excellent restaurants are all easily within walking distance. I would definitely stay here again. Also, there are two great breakfast places - one just on 44th, a few doors away, is a little diner - pretty cheap and hot food, and another is around the corner on 5th avenue - the Cafe Europa. We didn't eat at the hotel at all because we heard the prices were pretty extreme. The Algonquin, a hotel next door, is great fun at night for enjoying cocktails. On Sunday night singers from broadway shows came out and sang and played piano in the lobby. It's a delightful place.

<Author>Youngtravellers
<Content>Nowhere better, no questions! Just returned from the Sofitel over Easter Weekend and had the best time in New York. The hotel is positioned between 5th and 6th Ave. on 44th Street so puts it within 10 minutes walk of everything worth looking at. The place is simply splendid, fresh flowers every-other-day and everyone (barr some but i'll explain later) is so helpful. We were recommended to get a high room, we were on the 15th floor and could see nothing but when you realise that New York is only huge due to everything being so high you'll understand!The lack of view didn't spoil a thing, the hotel was just the perfect place to relax after a hard day of walking and shopping. We didn't eat in the hotel cos they tend to be more expensive and we'd had some other recommendations.The only thing that let the Sofitel down was the fact that my girlfriend and i are quite young so the doormen didn't -ever- open the door for us on the way in. The concierge seemed reluctant too, but yet overly helpful to the older guests! Ah well.If you stay here go to breakfast at The Manhattan Cafe across the road, round the back. It's fantastic! And for dinner Michael Jordans The Steak House, at Grand Central Station is great but dress smart, it's a bit glam! Buffalo steak is superb, but the garlic bread for starters is divine! The other place we tried was Del Friscos on roughly 49th and 6th, the McGraw-Hill Building. It's a bit expensive but we were sat next to Colin Farrell so who can complain!!!If you need any info then please email me, i loved it! Enjoy!

<Author>L_Palmer
<Content>Fab hotel, fab location, fab city!! We stayed at the Sofitel New York from 7-10 April, and booked it based on the reviews we read on Tripadvisor. It lived up to expectations in every way. Minutes from both 5th  6th Ave on 44th St, the location was fantastic. We were on the 10th floor and our room was so quiet, we did not hear any traffic, sirens or noise the whole three nights. Bed was the most comfortable we have ever slept in. Spacious, clean room, and excellent marble bathroom with large shower cubicle and separate bath. Staff were extremely friendly and made us feel very welcome. Hotel has a nice bar and thought drink prices were reasonable. Only minor criticism would be the lobby which is quite dark, but apart from that, we loved it and would go back.Travel tips:For a cheap breakfast go to the Red Flame diner, turn right out of hotel, 1 min away. Always busy, great bacon and eggs! Dinner - we tried Tavern on the Green. Firm believer people should make their own minds up about restaurants, as everyone likes different things, but we were very disappointed, overpriced  boring food which lacked flavour, no atmosphere....but good location though and pretty park views.Top viewing spot - Top of the Rock observation centre at Rockefeller centre. 67 floors up, stunning views, cost $17 per person. Well worth it.Nice walk - we did a great 3 hour walk from Pier 17, through financial district, then up West Broadway through Tribeca, lunch in Soho cafe and Greenwich, then back up 5th Ave to hotel. Saw so much, brilliant weekend.

<Author>Austin2NY
<Content>Large rooms (for NY), great location, overall good value!! We recently stayed at the Sofitel New York the last week of March 2006 (27th - 31st). We chose the Sofitel due to the overwhelming positive reviews on this board and it did not dissappoint one bit! When we first arrived, we were greeted at the front desk by an extremely friendly individual. She upgraded our floor level and room size from a Queen premiere to King Deluxe after hearing it was my wife's birthday present. We also received our 2 free complimentary drinks at the bar (sign up for a free Sofitel card on their website to receive them), and we were off to our room. Although we didn't spend alot of time in our rooms each day (we came to NY to sightsee/have fun), it was always nice to be able to walk to our hotel regardless of where we had just been (did I mention how convenient the location is?) and rest up in that ultra-comfortable bed! The afternoon/evening turn down service + complimentary water each day was also appreciated. Our first night there, we also had dinner in the hotel restaraunt (Gabby's). While I'm not one to generally eat in hotels (they are often over priced and average quality), Gabby's quality was really good (I highly recommend the lamb chops!). If (OK when) we travel back to NY, I'd stay at the Sofitel again as long as we can book a room for under 300 a night. (we paid $269 a night)

<Author>nakedmaestro
<Content>Outstanding, but not ultra luxe Recently stayed at the Sofitel NY for 2 nights on a Friday  Saturday evening in early March. It's my favorite chain and it's too bad Sofitel doesn't have more properties in the U.S. As was the case when I stayed at the Sofitel Chicago,  Philadelphia, the Sofitel NY didn't disappoint. Everything was as good as it could possibly have been from check in to check out. I requested a view room on a high floor and got it. Bed was very comfortable and bathroom very spacious  clean and the toiletries were fantastic. Room service was good and arrived promptly. For those that are not familar with Sofitel, it's a French chain that is very popular in Europe, the middle east, and Africa, but only has like 12 properties in the U.S. I'd compare it to a Westin, Le Meridien, or W. Sofitel is certainly as good as any of those chains and I'd argue that they're actually better due to the room amenities they provide that American chains lack. Those little extras make all the difference. Although it's ranked #1 in New York by this website, it's certainly not the best hotel in NY by ultra luxury standards. For value, convenience, and service, the Sofitel NY is absolutely deserving of its Trip Advisor ranking. That said, wealthy travelers expecting the Sofitel to deliver Four Seasons, Ritz Carlton, Penninsula, or Mandarin Oriental style decadence will inevitably be disappointed. It's a fantasic hotel for vast majority of people, just don't be confused by the #1 ranking and expect it to be the most luxurious place in New York. It isn't, nor does it claim to be, but it is a fantastic hotel nonetheless.  
<Date>Apr 2, 2006
<Rating>5	5	5	-1	5	-1	5	-1	

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Sofitel exceeded my expectations Just returned from a girl's weekend with my sister. Having been to NYC four times previously and having stayed at the Michelangelo twice this past summer, I have to say that the Hotel Sofitel on W 44th was definitely a great value for my dollar. The staff was extremely courteous. Our check in was smooth and we were even offered an upgrade at no additional cost. We had prepaid for our room and were to share a queen bed. The front desk staff offered us an open room with two oversized twin beds (which was a higher cost when I booked our reservations) and suggested that we would enjoy our stay much better as we could both stretch out and sleep in our own beds. She was definitely right! We loved the room. The decor was exactly as described and pictured. The room was pristinely clean and the fresh orchid in the bathroom was a lovely touch. The bathroom is what really made the room enjoyable. There was both a separate glass shower and a porcelain tub. The walls and floor of the bath were all marble. There was ample room for toiletries, a magnifying mirror, adequate electrical plug ins, and good lighting. The only drawback I could see to the bathroom was the lack of a ventilation fan. Evenso, I would definitely highly recommend this hotel. The maid service was equally efficient and thorough. We never saw any carts or heard the service staff at all. Our room was meticulously clean each time we returned. I had no qualms about soaking in the tub after a long day out walking. We paid $319/Thurs and $229/Fri  Sat evening. If being close to Time Square  the theaters is essential to your trip, I would most definitely choose to stay here. The next time I come to New York I would love to stay at the Hotel Sofitel again. The concierge even gave us the name of a car company that took us to the airport in a town car for the same price as a taxi. A top notch hotel!

<Author>exeter
<Content>A lovely place to stay My daughter, age 15, and I had a WONDERFUL time in New York over March break. Even the weather was warm and sunny. We stayed at the Sofitel, a beautiful, clean and quiet hotel just two minutes from the bustle of Times Square and close to the best shopping in the world. The hotel staff are very friendly and service is European, meaning polished. Many of the staff speak French. The room was as requested with two double beds, the linens superior, and the bathrooms incredible. The toiletries were wonderful, and after long days shopping and sightseeing I appreciated the luxuries. The big hotels at Times square always had lineups at the front desk and for elevators: never at the Sofitel . And the doormen got to know us and were very helpful.  My daughter loved having a personal shopper at Bloomingdale's and got some great things...  We reserved through NYCVP, which saved us over the hotel rates offered by the usual discount providers. The packet of vouchers was waiting for us at the hotel and they gave us a room on a higher floor as requested. It couldn't have been better. NYCVP also arranged for theatre tickets to sold out shows, and got excellent seats , both on shows that were otherwise unavailable.The Red Flame diner next door was a cheaper alternative to breakfastat the hotel. We also went to the Rockefeller centre for their breakfast by the skating rink...memorable. We did the Top of the Rock by day... better views of the park... and the empire State building at night... great city lights views. And all the usual bus and boat and museum tours.  New york is much friendlier than pre 9-11 and is worth revisiting if you have not been back since then.

<Author>LtDan
<Content>Very impressed My wife and I stayed at the Sofitel for two nights and were very happy there. The staff was very professional and courteous, accomodating each request we had: a high floor, a late checkout, a specific newspaper each morning, a yellow pages...all handled quickly and with a smile.Our room was larger than the typical New York hotel, even though it was among the least expensive of the 3.5/4 star hotels we looked at. The bathroom was great: very new, very clean. The bed was a queen, but felt bigger somehow.The location was very convenient. We could easily walk to restaurants, theatres, subway stations, and attractions in minutes. You could get to either 5th or 6th in less than a minute.There's a diner-type place called the Red Flame just down 44th toward 6th that does a decent breakfast; for dinner one night we ate at Triomphe (right next door in the Iroquois Hotel) and it was fantastic.All in all, a great hotel in a great spot. Highly recommended.  
<Date>Mar 18, 2006
<Rating>5	4	4	-1	5	-1	5	-1	

<Author>jackosan
<Content>Terrific Mid-Town Hotel I write only to echo the praises of other reviewers. I could not have been more pleased with this hotel. From experience, I can state that this is one of the finer 4-star hotels in Manhattan. Prompt, attentive service, clean, smartly appointed rooms, bathrobes, slippers and other amenities galore, high-end beds and bedding, large bathrooms with separate bathtub and shower. The exercise room had a nice mix of cardio equipment and enough weights for adequate resistance training.Had drinks in the restaurant/bar, but no meal. Seems like a very nice place, but pricey. If you are looking for some excellent food at comparatively bargain prices, Little Brazil is just a block away. Super location between 5th Ave. and Avenue of the Americas (6th Ave.) and 44th and 45th streets puts you right by the theatre district and Times Square. Plenty to see, do and eat. A short walk or cab ride from anywhere in mid-town.Minor gripe: Charging for internet access is so 20th Century. Still, I will gladly stay here again.  
<Date>Mar 18, 2006

<Author>Aly22

My boyfriend is a chef and therefore not easy to please, but he couldn't rave about his food more. We were even given a tour of the kitchen!! But be prepared, it's pricey but worth every penny.We both thoroughly enjoyed our time in New York, and would happily recommend this hotel to anyone planning a trip.

<Author>Stevebeckhead
<Content>Good value. Stayed 6 nights early March. Paid $359 per night for room on 22nd floor with a city view!, so not cheap and a city view is relative - remember New York city views are limited. Thought the room and facilities were excellent, comfortable large bed, decent sized room, good well stocked bathroom and to me most important peace and quiet. Both my wife and I had 6 nights of excellent sleep only waking when my body clock thought it was time to get up - usually 4 in the morning.Maid service was spot on with bathrobes changed without asking and a plentiful supply of toiletries. Turn down service was always done when we out so no problems.Didn't use the restaurant facilities as I thought they were very expensive and with 13,000 restauarants to choose from I like to venture out. Reception and door staff spot on and as a Sofitel Privilege card holder was able to use our room through to 4 pm which fitted perfectly with our 6pm flight back to UK. Any body can have one of these!Would almost certainly stay there again.

<Author>amp94596
<Content>Great Hotel and location I travel to NYC about 7-8 times a year. This is my first visit to the Sofitel. I got an average rate of $240 a night over four nights for a King bed on a lower floor. The overall experience was very good, very comfortable and hospitable. The bed was excellent. I will come back to the Sofitel again soon. NY City hotels have really gone up in price over the last year and I can't find anything in the $250-325 range as good as the Sofitel anywhere in the city.The room was large by NY standards. I can't remember the last time I had a shower and seperate bath in a NYC hotel. The location is great. Although this hotel isn't a scene, it is relaxing and hospitable. What would I change? The menu is expensive. (Food is good) The workout room needs towels and tuned up machines. The carpeting in my room was starting to show it's age and the room had a strong lingering air freshener smell.

<Author>cl8855
<Content>Good choice, not quite 5* but close I wanted to give them 5*, as we had a great time and were very happy here, but not quite perfect.Rooms: Even the small rooms have plenty of space other than between closet/bathroom (depends on your room as well, they are different configs I believe). Bathtub drain didn't hold water -- didn't call to see if they would fix asap.Service: Good response from the desk, the doormen (usually), and the concierge. Good overall, not spectacular based on other experiences we have had.Location: Excellent, on hotel row pretty quiet street, walk around corner to Best Buy/Duane Reade/Starbucks. Diner on same street. Easy walk to Times Square and all theatres. Can even walk to Central Park from here without too much trouble.They provided a DVD player at no charge when I emailed and asked about availability of one (and I didn't even ask to provide, I just inquired) -- this was excellent service.Overall I give them about 4 1/2 out of 5.We would definitely stay there again.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Lovely We stayed here for four nights in February 2006. We took advantage of a 30% discount deal from Expedia and stayed in a Deluxe King Suite on the 26th floor. We looked out on to the Rockefeller Centre and at an angle could see down to Times Sq and the Hudson beyond. A problem with staying in this part of New York (mid-town) is that all the buildings are tall so good views are few and far between in any hotel. The hotel is in an excellent location and staff we came across very helpful and friendly.Lovely clean, quiet and spacious room with seperate sitting room. Very comfortable bed. Also had a wonderful bathroom with candles and mineral water. The mini-bar (working on sensors/weights so don't touch anything!) prices were ludicrous however but free ice down the hall kept shop bought drinks cool!Don't go for convenient therefore expensive hotel breakfasts (looked as though a standard breakfast for two in the Sofitel is in the region of $70) but find a nearby diner/restaurant. The best breakfast we have ever had in NY is at the 'Pershing Sq cafe' - on 42nd St opposite Grand Central Station (under the bridge).

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Hotel! I chose this hotel (3 visits in one year) for each of my trips to New York City because of the reviews on trip advisor. The sofitel did not spend so much money on a large grand lobby, but they made up for it in your room.I have to say it is one of the cleanest hotels I have ever stayed at and that is one of my most important criteria. My favorite feature of their rooms is the bathroom. The bathroom is very clean and luxurious. I stayed in a twin bed room for one visit and it was not quite a twin bed, but slightly larger, maybe a double bed. The room was spacious and clean.Next two times, I stayed in a king bed room and that was even better! The bedding was so awesome that I copied down the information on the label so I could purchase it for my home. The duvet was all white, no spots and very soft, high thread count Egyptian Cotton. The pillows were very comfortable (I have neck issues and need to be selective). Room service was so good,The food is excellent, but it cost a fortune. There are several charges in addition to the actual cost of the food. I love the cheese tray and french bread as an evening snack and it is worth the money to me. The staff was so friendly and helpful. I liked that part of the nighttime turn down, they left bottled water, Evian of course. Great touch, classy hotel. As for location, I love it. Right off of 5th avenue, it was walking distance to great shopping and a two block walk to Times Square and most theatres.During my last visit, I left my bags with the concierge so I could do some last minute shopping and there was no charge. My friends did not stay at the same hotel, but paid $5 a bag for each bag they stored at their hotel.

<Author>BogartG
<Content>Have to say disappointing Having chosen this hotel by the tripadvisor rating I have to say I was somewhat disappointed. (might I add that this is my first disappointment with tripadvisor which I consult every time I travel).Booked this trip as a surprise for my husbands birthday. I contacted Guest Services to request an upgrade to a suite and champagne to be in the suite when we arrived. This was confirmed on request. On arrival we were told there were no suites available and allocated a small room on the 11th floor. When I opened the curtains to see the fantastic view I was greeted with a man in an office block across the street. My husband sensing my disappointment requested a move to a higher floor and a larger room. Although we were moved to a slightly larger room on the 27th floor it was definitely not what I had expected. (the champagne eventually arrived after the relocation) The view was better but the room was quite tired with black marks on the carpet and curtains that required a good washing. I was awake most nights with the noise of the lift beside us. I, at this point did not wish to complain and be moved again as I didn't want to spoil my husbands trip.The front desk were ok with a hint of super almost icy efficiency. The concierge was more than helpful and friendly and the door man was just great. (couldn't help enough!) My gut instinct tells me there are definitely better hotels in New York that wouldn't be nearly as overpriced. Wouldn't stay there again.

<Author>jefruss
<Content>SWEET! Perfect location on West 44th between 5th Avenue and Avenue of the Americas (6th). Exemplary service, especially housekeeping. Doorman arranged Town Car transportation to La Guardia at a rate comparable to a taxi fare. Lots of smiles from the staff. Free use of computer terminals located in an alcove off of the lobby. Our room on the 26th floor had a wonderful view. Bathroom was spacious with perfect lighting. The closet did not have quite enough space for hanging clothes, otherwise it was well arranged. Forget Gaby's, the hotel restaurant. Sub par eats. We did, however, have a sensational meal at db Bistro Moderne which is only a few doors away. Gaby's is the only reason not to give Sofitel an excellent rating. Also, the addition of in-room coffee and flat screen tv would place this property in rarified air. Bottom line - we will book this hotel again!

<Author>EarlPitts
<Content>Definitely a cut above My wife and I stayed here five nights from Jan 27 - Feb 1, 2006. We picked this hotel based on the reviews here. The good: It was definitely a very classy business hotel. All the staff was extremely friendly and the rooms were impeccably clean which greatly pleased my wife. The rooms had a crown dental molding and nice finishing touches that set it apart from other upscale hotels. Room service and housekeeping were very efficient. You can get a very nice (and inexpensive) breakfast across the street so you can avoid the $25 USD per person breakfasts at the hotel. Overall a very classy place on par with a Ritz Carlton and well located.The bad: I'm very sensitive to smoke and I noticed a slight smell of smoke in our non-smoking room. I complained and they came in and sprayed the next day. It got rid of the smell until late at night when the smell came back through the A/C system. I complained again and they brought in an ionizer which did alleviate the smell. I just didn't want to have to deal with a smokey smell in my room.Even for a NYC hotel room, our upgraded deluxe room was extremely small and there was practically no closet or drawer space... so don't bring much to wear. Although the bathroom was a nice size.I would recommend this hotel as I've payed much more and gotten much less in NYC.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Sofitel: Belle of New York My husband and I just spent a wonderful weekend in New York. The trip was totally enhanced by our experience at the Sofitel. <Author>Woodward1
<Content>Good position but.... We had booked a suite with city view on a high floor but when we arrived it was not ready as the previous guest had arranged a late check-out and we did not get our room until 7.45pm. This was not a good start to our 5 night celebration trip to NYC. If a hotel offers late check-outs then they are duty-bound to ensure that this is not abused by guests staying until early evening thereby obviously inconveniencing arriving guests. 3pm - 4pm would be bearable but after 7pm is not acceptable, especially when the hotel is full. Luckily we persuaded them to allow us the use of a standard room to change and store our bags etc. but I would be reluctant to stay in a Sofitel again unless they change this practice. I know that I am not the first guest to highlight this. The suite was good with a very comfortable bed and great city views. Service good, food OK but front desk staff not always as helpful as they could be.

<Rating>2	4	4	-1	3	-1	3	-1	

<Author>phorid
<Content>Wonderful We stayed at the Sofitel in the fall when multiple events were making rooms impossible to find. We ended up paying a lot for the room (even by NY standards) and even using Priceline (around $400). That said, I still highly recommend this hotel!This is a hotel that just feels different than other hotels. When you stay here, you know that you are not in an ordinary hotel. For one, the lobby is beautiful, but in a subtle, non-ornate way. For another, the service was wonderful. Help was always there but in a discreet manner. In addition, we loved the free use of a computer hidden away in one part of the lobby, complete with internet access and printer. Like many, we needed to print our boarding passes for our flight, and it was a breeze here.The room itself was just wonderful. Not huge, but it is in NY. The bed was one of the most comfortable I have ever slept in, and the linens were fabulous. The room was extremely quiet, and we heard NO noise whatsoever. Very unusual in NY. The bathroom was in a league by itself. It was huge and had lots of marble, mirrors, and special toiletries. It also had a glass-enclosed shower, and a separate huge tub! The towels were big and thick.Lastly, the location is near Times Square, a positive for some and a negative for others. The positive is that it is close to the theaters and many restaurants. The negative is that it tends to be more touristy than other parts of the city and so there are less non-tourist places to eat and shop.For a different feel than your usual big city chains, I highly recommend the Sofitel.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Experience My girlfriend and I just came back from a weekend in NYC. I had selected the Sofitel based on reviews from this site and the ability to get a slightly discounted room. <Author>tryemdad
<Content>Overall positive experience Stayed one night, Saturday, two rooms. My wife and 4 kids ranging from 1-14 in age. Quick, efficient check-in process. Decent (average to slightly above)size rooms. Bathroom is much larger than what you'd usually find at this price-point. Quiet. Comfy beds as advertised. $331 per room (each w/ two double beds)with all fees, taxes, etc.We did not eat in the hotel. The Red Flame Diner is o.k. - but it is JUST a diner, so beware of all the overwhelmingly positive reviews, especially if you're from NY or an area where they're are lot's of diners.Good location - close enough to Times Square - yet far enough away, if you know what I mean.We usually stay at the Excelsior on the UWS. I'd rate this experience as equal to it in overall quality. Sofitel has a much more modern and slightly more impersonal feel than the Excelsior, but it's newer and in better shape. We'd go back again, eventually. But first, I'd probably try the Iriquois and/or Algonquin, both on the same block. They appear to have a bit more character.Only negative aspect of our stay was getting our car back from valet on Sunday morning. It took 30 minutes as we were quoted at the time. There were lots of complaints from the crowd waiting ahead of us. Not sure if this was a one-time or chronic issue.

<Author>VeeBee
<Content>Nice Place to Stay while in NY We are a young couple(30yrs old), and decided to treat ourselves to a nice getaway. The Sofitel comes highly recommended, but the price suggest absolute luxury. It is in a great location, a block away from 5th ave, and surrounded by other great attractions, 10 blocks from broadway and 10 from Penn Station, about a 10 minute walk in either direction. The location was fabulous. Check in: we were greeted at the door by a doorman and concierge in French, and were allowed to check in early for no extra fee. We stayed on the 22nd floor. The view was of another building which was rather disappointing. They also let us check out late for no extra fee. Be sure to sign up for a free loyalty card, that comes with extra upgrades and little perks.Our room: was nice, with contemporary decor, but very small. Not a lot of room to move around. It was clean, linen fresh daily. A thin robe and slippers were provided. TV was a 27 inch. Again, nothing you wouldnt expect at a 3 star hotel. Turn down service every nite with Evian water and weather outlook for the next day.the BED: okay, so I was really curious to see if this bed lived up to its reputation (the pessimist in me) but it does. It was absolutely heavenly. Down sheets and comforter, and pillows. I slept in one position, never moved. The room was nice and dark at night, and truthfully, as a mother of two, this was the best sleep I have had in a very long time. We slept until 10 every morning. Food: We chose to eat outside the restaurant. The Red Flame is a little diner 2 doors down and was great. Good food, fast service, and the usual New York treatment from the staff. The wait was never more than 10 minutes. I did not like the fact that after 11pm, no one was in the lobby. Anyone could have walked in the hotel, so that was kinda odd. There is only 3 computers in the lobby that are always occupied. But overall, it was nice, I will stay again, but for a better deal. For 350.00 a nite, I expect to be treated like I paid 350.00 a nite. :) Hope you enjoy it, its nice, but its gonna cost you. Again, the bed. It might just be worth it for that darn bed!!!

Unit had a minibar, high speed internet conection, and ironing board and iron. The bathroom was very nice - with a separate shower and bath. I really enjoyed the European style with the comforter. They also had a very soft but warm blanket if you wanted it. I had no problem with the positioning of the TV as apparently another reviewer had. This is more of a business hotel than a party hotel. Which was just fine with us - nice to get some quite after a hective day in the City. Relatively good price (about $600)especially considering it was New year's Eve in NY City!. The location was great - only a few blocks from Time Square, the Theatres, Rockefeller Center and Grand Central Terminal! I will definitley stay here again!

<Author>Coltbridge
<Content>Cant understand these great reviews! We picked this hotel purely on the basis of Tripadvisor reviews for a three night stay in New York with our children. So this wasnt even an accident.After an hour of faffing we got into our rooms. Mostly as advertised, but in our suite the bahtub was only 36 inches long at the bottom, and 45 inches at the top. ie you cant stretch your legs out in it.In the bedroom of our suite the TV was set off to one side by about 60 degrees, so we couldnt lie in bed vegging at the tv without getting a severe cricked neck.And the window of our suite, 240 feet above street level, has a three foot crack in both the inside and outside panes - slightly alarming.To console ourselves we tried to make a cup of tea. No kettle. We rang housekeeping to be told that they dont provide kettles, but we will see what can be done. An hour later nothing had been done, so we rang the manager, and 20 minutes later a kettle arrived, but in this heart of the world's greatest economy the kettle has no automatic off switch.Not impressed, at $1000 a night, and puzzled by all these great reviews - suggests that the rest of NY's hotels must be pants!

<Rating>5	4	5	-1	5	-1	4	-1	

<Author>James_Thomson
<Content>Comfortable 4 star hotel (with some problems) suited to the average tourist I had high expectations of this hotel and booked 6 nights at the Sofitel based on it being rated the No. 1 hotel in New York by tripadvisor.com. I was disappointed with this hotel.Sofitel New York is a comfortable 4 star hotel for the average tourist. You should not expect high standards of service or luxury staying here.Sofitel is a 4 star, not a 5 star hotel. People travelling to this hotel should expect comfort, but not luxury. It is not a luxury hotel with consistent excellent service in the same league as The Ritz Carlton, The St. Regis Hotel, or Four Seasons Hotel in New York. Having checked out these five star properties while in New York, for my next stay in New York I would probably choose the St. Regis.The room rates at Sofitel New York are very high. I was paying $US500 a night for a queen bed room with no view.Good points:-Modern marble bathroom with separate bath and shower-Comfortable queen sized bed-Midtown location near Broadway and Times SquareBad points:-Room service ordered on my first night arrived almost cold. I ordered a Vegetable Lasagne and it was luke warm. Also, the night menu seems to suit the hotel rather than containing appealing options.- I returned to the hotel around midnight a couple of nights to find absolutely no staff on the property at all (no doormen, and concierge and front desks were both empty). For a 4 star hotel I think this is not satisfactory. Also, when I returned late on a Saturday night (Sunday morning), there was one staff member in the lobby who was sitting on a chair in a deep sleep. My walking past didn't even wake him!-Doormen do not open doors for guests consistently. For a 4 star hotel charging $500 a night, I tend to expect this.-Internet access terminals in the lobby are always down. I complained a couple of times and they were fixed, only to be down again. One of the terminals was taken away and not returned for 3 days. There seemed to be no rush to ensure it was fixed.-Concierges are not available all the time. There were times when a concierge was not on the property. One night I wanted a restaurant recommendation at 7pm and went to the concierge desk only to be told that there is no concierge on the property at the moment.-Maids are stingy with replacing toiletries. I had used all the shampoo and on one day when my room was serviced and the toiletries were replaced, my empty shampoo was replaced with a half-empty bottle. I asked the maid whether it had been used by another guest and she said I don't know and brought a new one. Equally, with the turndown service, they are supposed to provide bottles of Evian for both guests. We had 2 guests, and for most of the nights only 1 bottle of Evian was provided.I wouldn't rush back to the Sofitel at $500 a night, but if you can get a room for under $300 a night it would represent good value. And remember, it is not a luxury hotel, it is a standard 4 star tourist hotel.  
<Date>Dec 12, 2005

<Content>Top hotel My husband and I treated ourselves to 5 nights in New York at the Sofitel and what a superb hotel. The room was modern yet tastefully furnished, designed with French flair. <Rating>5	5	5	-1	5	-1	5	-1	

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Perfect weekend in New York This hotel is absolutely wonderful....safe, quiet location only minutes from Times Square and Fifth Avenue, beautiful lobby, courteous and helpful staff, quick elevator service, spacious rooms by NY standards, views of Chrysler and/or Empire State Building, extremely comfortable beds, beautiful marble baths with soaking tub and glass shower, special touches such as candles, fresh flowers, terry-cloth robe/slippers, complimentary water bottles, cd players, and late checkouts. We came to NYC for a weekend visit with another couple and enjoyed our stay immensely! My husband and I stayed on the 17th floor where it was extremely quiet. The couple we traveled with were upgraded to a larger room on the 19th floor and surprised with champagne and chocolates after I emailed the hotel a few days prior to arrival that they were celebrating their anniversary. Be sure to register in advance for a Sofitel Loyalty card and bring a printout of your registration so you can request a late checkout. Also, don't touch anything in the room refrigerator unless you want it...There is a sensor inside, and you will be charged for any items moved.As for activities in NYC, I would recommend dinner at Tony's Italian Restaurant and Gallagher's Steak House, breakfast at the Red Flame Diner, cheesecake at Lindy's, early lunch at Carnegie Deli, purchasing tickets in advance on the hotel computers for Top of the Rock so you do not have to wait in line, and of course any show on Broadway...We saw Producers and Chicago this time, but also enjoyed Rent and Phantom on previous visits. Book well in advance if you want to see Wicked, Spamalot, or Odd Couple.We all had a wonderful weekend and will not hesitate to make reservations at the Sofitel on our next visit!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Stay Here! Stayed at Sofitel NY for 1 night Nov 25th. The city was mobbed with holiday shoppers but the Sofitel was calm and lovely! We stayed in suite 2922 and had a nice view of Chrysler building. The bed is super comfy, the bathroom was divine, all marble and a deep tub which was great after a hectic day shopping! Perfect location for all the best NY has to offer. Room service was prompt and accurate. The girl in the gift shop remained kind and smiley even after I repeatedly knocked over a handbag display. The check-in guy had to play the xylophone to summons a bellboy who appeared quickly out of no where. I said They make you play the xylophone??? He smiled and said Yes! ...in fact i think he liked having to play it. I would stay here again in a minute.

<Author>Bas1976
<Content>A Hidden Gem We stayed in the Sofitel in mid October 2005 for 3 nights and thought it was wonderful. The location was brilliant, just 5 minutes from Time Square and all the hussle and bustle of the Big Apple. But....even though it was so close to everything it was incredibly, a small haven of tranquility. We booked a suite (which was huge by NYC standards) so we were on a high floor. It was utterly silent up there and I slept brilliantly on the beautifully comfortable bed. The bathroon was lovely with a huge walk in shower but the 'large' bath we were promised when we booked failed to materialise!! The lifts were very speedy and we never had to wait for them unlike in other hotels (Parker Meridien). Free internet in the lobby topped it off. We would definately stay here again.

<Author>kr203040
<Content>Really Great!! Stayed at The Sofitel 28th Oct-1st Nov - looks exactly like the pictures on the website and has a lovely plush lobby! The rooms are lovely - very clean, nicely decorated and extremely quiet. We were on the 16th floor and didn't hear a sound from outside.When we first got there the bins in the room hadn't been emptied and there were no fresh towels in the bathroom, we rang reception and the head of housekeeping was at our door within literally one minute, she was exteremly apologetic and offered us another room but we were happy to stay where we were and a maid fixed the room immediatley - for the rest of our stay everything was perfect. The Evian water and weather forecast of a night were a lovely touch and all of the staff we encountered were friendly and courteous. I have previously stayed at the Alex and the Westin Times Square and would say the Sofitel definately has the edge over the the Alex and is equal to the Westin - if you want ultra modern go for Westin - ultra comfortable - go Sofitel!!! Don't hesitate to book and enjoy the great location!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Every bit as good as you read! I'm normally not one to write online reviews, but this place certainly merits it for all the right reasons. We booked the hotel for 3 night shopping break based on other reviews and great price obtained through a third party internet site. Check in was simple - no queues and no problem for an early check in just before midday (3PM is preferred time). We were on the 11th floor so our view was restricted by neighbouring buildings, though in all honesty, you are not in NYC to stare out your hotel window as you will see plenty of sites when out and about. Ask at check-in if you want to be higher up. The rooms are a good size and extrememly comfortable. The bed and bathroom are every bit as good as other reviewers have described. The rooms were very quiet too - both in terms of city noise and nighbouring guests/corridor noise. It felt like we were the only ones on the floor. The hotel has an excellent location in midtown Manhattan, convinient for shopping/shows etc. We didn't have much interaction with the staff, but when we did, they were curtious and helpful. The doormen were great too. Didn't eat in the restaurant but opted instead for the diner a few doors down for breakfast which provided a hearty meal for a day on your feet. The small internet access area(3 PCs and printer) in the lobby was excellent for checking on your business email while you are away. All in all, an excellent place to stay, and I have been in my fare share of 5 star luxury hotels that don't come up to the same standard. Won't hesitate to book again.  
<Date>Nov 13, 2005
