<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Good until check out Sofitel was nice until I decided to check out after 3 nights instead of the 5 nights I (unknowingly) prepaid for because my business in NYC was finalized early. The manager, John did not budge or try to compromise on refunding the other two nights. I paid the full $1000 + tax for 2 nights that I did not stay here (yes, it was $500 a night) when I KNOW they were easily able to occupy my room because it was marathon weeekend. My company's travel dept. called John also, he would not work with any of us. He would not even come out and talk to me face to face. John promised to call me later to work this out, which he never did. He seemed to base everything on the fact that I had decided to check into a less costly hotel for personal use for the rest of the weekend and wanted me to cancel that hotel first. What did my personal activities have to do with this? So if you prepay here through an internet site or other travel service you better hope you won't need to check out early in the event of an emergency or for any other reason because it won't matter to management who is clearly greedy. Also, room service is not detail oriented, I got wrong food on two occasions.

<Author>mrwatson

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Good hotel, great location Stayed at the Sofitel 29/10/05 - 2/11/05. Very pleasant stay with no real faults to report but no 'wow' factor either. Not a place you would regret staying at but surprised it gets quite such enthusiastic reviews on this site. We stayed in a King Suite on the 28th floor and the room was very quiet and comfortable. Not sure if the hotel gets its #1 rating because it doesn't do much wrong rather than anything spectacularly right. On the occasions we needed assistance the staff were very polite and helpful. Nice lobby, decent communal areas and an easy place to relax - it depends what you are looking for, and I would recommend the Sofitel as a good, safe bet. Having stayed at the Four Seasons in Dublin a week or so earlier my girlfriend and I are still commenting to friends on the standard or service etc we received - with the Sofitel our only real comment was that it was 'nice'.Minor complaint was the standard of room cleaning - e.g. marks on the bedside tables caused by water glasses were not wiped away in the 4 days we were there and apart from the bed having been made it was difficult to tell if the room had been serviced. We didn't complain, however, so gave them no chance to rectify it.Location very good particularly for a first time visit to NY. If you want good, well located accommodation the Sofitel won't let you down, if you want something truly memorable it may be worth looking further afield (maybe a room at the Four Seasons for the same price as suite at the Sofitel - probably my choice next time).

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Perfect For A Long Weekend! We chose this hotel partially based on reviews from this web site. It did not disappoint. We were pleased to find the staff friendly and helpful, without the snobbishness that comes with some of these higher priced hotels. We were delighted to receive the bottle of champagne the staff sent up for our anniversary. The Sofitel is a nice sized hotel, but not overly huge. The lobby is comfortable and inviting. Our rooms were a good size and fairly quiet, given the location. Very comfortable bed as well. We had good breakfasts at the diner down the street, and other meals while we were out. On our last night there, we were exhausted from all the walking and wanted to eat someplace good and nearby. The concierge recommended Osteria al Doge down the street, and we enjoyed an excellent meal in a relaxed setting to celebrate our 10th anniversary. Sofitel would be my first choice in hotels the next time we travel to NYC.

<Author>Uxbridge_UK
<Content>Good Quality Hotel in a great location We stayed at the Sofitel for a long week-end, our first trip to New York. Whilst acknowledging the Hotel's French ownership, I found being greeted in French upon our arrival in New York in the early hours of the morning, a little bizarre and pretentious. But then I'm English so French is not going to be my cup of tea! The Sofitel is a good quality hotel with a sense of style. The rooms are modern, and well equipped. The bathrooms are very good with a separate shower stall, and bath. The baths are a bit shallow for a good soak. The beds are very comfortable. The rooms are quiet, albeit the air-con was a bit noisy when it cut-in. Staff are very helpful and polite. The Bar is very pleasant, with good service. We did not dine in the restaurant, prefering instead to go out and choose from the many, and varied restaurants within easy walking distance. Like others we would reccommend the Red Flame Diner, just a few doors a long the street. You may have to queue for a few minutes at breakfast time due the its popularity with both locals and visitors - but it's well worth the brief wait. The waitresses are great and work hard, so tip them well. The Hotel is situated adjacent to the Thearte District between 5th and 6th Avenue so it is ideally placed for exploring. We walked from the hotel to Times Square, Central Park, Maceys, Bloomingdales, and the Museum of Modern Art, amongst other places. As I have not stayed at other New York hotels I cannot say how it compares to them. However, compared to other hotels I have stayed at in other countries it scores well, and we would have no hesitation in returning to the Sofitel.  
<Date>Nov 7, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Best hotel in NYC My husband and I started going to the Sofitel a couple years ago when the President was speaking out against the French (2003)- we got such a wonderful deal on the room ($100 per night) that we tried it and even got an upgrade. There were coupons given for free drinks in the wonderful bar there and all the amenities of a luxury hotel- view of Empire State Building, the robes, the mitted washclothes, fresh orchids, candles in the bathroom with music/tv piped into the very large bathrooms with separate marble showers with large shower heads. Although it is close to the action, it is quiet inside and the lobby is serene and welcoming unlike the Times Square touristy hotels where you have to show your key to get inside and there are mobs of people hanging out. Here the staff are attentive, helpful and quietly efficient. The rooms are quiet and you don't hear other people in the hallways or in the next room when you are in your room. Unfortunately, the opinion of hte French must have changed because the prices have gone up but the quality of these large sized rooms and the ambience has not changed from excellent! We love it!

<Rating>4	4	5	-1	5	-1	4	-1	

<Author>BurnedbyHotelHana
<Content>Best Price Guarantee Not Honored Beware of using the Softel web site for booking hotels. They do not honor their Best Rate Guaranteed Policy. I booked the Sofitel for 10-21 thru 10-24 at $1397 on their site. Sidestep found a lower rate and I forwarded this on to Sofitel.Sofitel refuses to match the price because the online reservation had a cancellation charge and Sofitel's did not.To my knowledge, almost every online web site has a cancellation charge or is nonrefundable (Expedia charges $25).This is a gotcha buried in their fine print.This is apparently a common problem too because the person answering the 800 call from their web site explained that it would likely not be honored for this reason as soon as I called. Apparently this is a common answer.In their defense, I will say that the hotel itself was much more cooperative when I called them direct to cancel my reservation. However, at that point I had already made other arrangements.They also pointed out that Sofitel offers a best rate and hot deals. The best rate is cancellable; the hot deals are not. At the time I booked (10-11), the best rate (cancellable) was $100 LESS than the hot deals. As explained to me then, I would have to book the hot deal at the more expensive rate to get a price match.Too much hassle. Too much fine print. Too Mickey Mouse for a reputable company. Bottom line. A company that advertises a best rate guarante on its site that apparently routinely refuses to do so.  
<Date>Oct 14, 2005
<Rating>2	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	

<Author>SterlingRose1212
<Content>Perfect Location! My friends and I (3 gals from Houston) recently went to this hotel after bidding on it from Priceline. Worth every penny for the location alone! We flew into Newark and it was a breeze via taxi ($45 plus tolls and tip) This hotel is within walking distance to most of the NY hot spots-theater district, shops on 5th Avenue, St Pats, Central Park (OK-a little far but everyone walks in NY) Macy's etc.The staff is lovely and the only complaint I had was we couldn't find the doorman a few times to help with cabs and had to flag down our own. There are several hotels on the block and it was raining most of the Columbus Day weekend so cabs were at a premium.We did not eat at the hotel but found tons of inexpensive places for breakfast and lunch. Bar area is nice but drinks are pricey.We were on the 22nd floor and it was so incredibly quiet we over slept every day. The view was so-so but the peaceful sleep was worth it. The beds are fabulous and the rooms are a good size. Bathrooms were big, too.Highly recommend if you can get it for under 300 per night!

<Author>Nakina
<Content>Great location, facitilities and service We stayed at the Sofitel, in part, because of the excellent reviews on tripadvisor. It was great! The location is mid-town and handy to most things. The service was excellent throughout our stay and they seem to have a lot of staff for the size of the hotel. Almost always 3 or 4 people on reception, 2 people on the door and often a person standing at the ready in the lobby in case anyone needed more help. The staff could not have been more pleasant and helpful. It rained while we were there and the hotel had lots of complimentary umbrellas available.The Gabi restaurant is a comfortable spot with very good food, although expensive even by NY standards. The Red Flame diner a few doors down the street is excellent.The rooms are adequate in size and very comfortable with a modern design and decor. The beds are excellent. The only thing that would be nice is in room coffee for the morning. The walls are fairly soundproof , some noise from a noisy person for a while one evening and you can hear noise from the hall through the doors (doors closing etc) but not a big problem and the hotel is generally quiet.The 3 free internet computers in the lobby area worked very well with even a printer provided.The hotel represented top value for NY as I booked through expedia for about $350 a night for the 4 nights. Way better value than other 4 and 5 star hotels we have stayed in on past trips.We will be most happy to stay at the Sofitel the next time we are in New York.

<Rating>5	5	5	-1	5	-1	5	-1	

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>The Most Beautiful Hotel I've ever stayed in We just returned from a weekend trip to NYC. The Sofitel is in a great location, midtown manhattan. This is easy walking distance to Grand Central Terminal, the NYC public library, Times Square, Fifth Ave. Shopping , the Empire State Building and Rockefeller Plaza. We also walked back to the Sofitel from Madison Square Garden. The Hotel is french. The lobby is large and beautiful with fresh flowers. It has intimate conversation areas set up with leather chairs and beautiful damask couches. The doormen were attentive and friendly. All the staff we encountered were polite, friendly, relaxed and attentive, not at all stuffy. Our room was lovely with neutral modern art deco furnishings. The bed was great! It was a king with fine linens including a featherbed and down comforter. The bathroom was nicely appointed with marble flooring and counters. Everything was very clean and french soaps and toiletries were provided. There was an easy to use room safe which we made use of. Even robes and slippers were provided. There was a nightly turn down service where the maid came in and prepared your bed. She also left bottled water, a card with the next days weather forcast and a breakfast order menu. We did not try any of the room service but the items on the menu sounded delicious. There really is nothing they could improve on. It was all great. The only thing I missed was a chocolate on my pillow. I would highly recommend staying at this hotel. I booked way in advance through travelocity and I think I paid $269 a night. I would definitely stay there again.  
<Date>Oct 11, 2005

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Excellent Hotel !!!! Great location, between Times Square and 5th Avenue. I booked a luxury room at $610/night for 7 nights directly with my credit card, but I had also a sofitel favourite guest card ($300) that offers 50% discount Fri-Sun and 25% Mon-Thur. There was a problem at check-in with my favourite guest card, and they solved it immediately presenting their excuses by offering me 50% discount for the entire stay. They really have an aggressive commercial attitude, prefering to lose some money than have unsatisfied customers. The hotel is excellent, the location is excellent, inside and outside noises are non-existent (excellent noise isolation, each floor only has 6-7 rooms), the staff is helpful, the room is clean (they clean it twice a day), marble bathroom, free evian water every night... This list could be endless, so I really recommend this hotel if you really want your stay in NYC to be excellent.

<Author>tonyofolds
<Content>Surely the best hotel in midtown new york The 14 hour days lugging yourself round new york deserves a reward and that reawrd can be a stay at the sofitel hotel. So near to Time Square and Grand Central and yet so far from the madding crowds. Just step into the lobby and the peaceful and serene setting immediately relaxes the mind. Or if you want to use the free aceess computers to check your emails, or step down to the fitness centre to exhaust those last few ounces of energy out of your system. Every member of staff meets and greets with sincerity and you make your way through spotless corridors and up polished lifts. Then enter your room (ours was a queen bed room on the 18th floor overlooking 46th st) Absolute silence and air conditioned. A super marble bathroom with roger gallet toiletries and a seperate walk in shower for me while the goood lady bathed in the seperate bath. And yet we still have not come to the best bit - The Bed, I have never slept in a more comfortable bed in all my travels, It is soooo comfortable and refreshed every day with crisp White linen as though it had just been un wrapped for the first time. A turn down service and bottles of evian just made it even more acceptable. Room service food was excellent if a little pricey but this IS new york and the quality of the food was more than satisfactory. If you want NEW YORK 24/7 this may not be the your option, but if your a seasoned traveller who likes to explore but also values a good nights rest then this may be the place for. My next Visit to New york will be at The sofitel.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Stay Stayed at Sofitel for four nights based on reccomendations on this web site. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Good, but a little overrated Definitely a solid hotel, but based on the glowing reviews I saw here, I thought I was in for the hotel stay of my lifetime. The bathroom was wonderful, large with a bath AND shower. Overall, the staff was helpful, my room was ready by 10am, but I did have to call down three times for some extra toothpaste. Be warned that your Sofitel privilege card will not be honored if you book your room online at a discounted rate. Nice place, above average but not excellent.

<Author>Vendredimanche
<Content>The most comfortable bed in NYC Only stayed in New York for 3 nights this time around so sleep and comfort were a priority and we were not disappointed at the Sofitel. Our queen room was large for NY standards (much larger than I expected!), very nicely furnished (with big cupboards/ iron/ safe / full-length mirror / fluffy bathrobes), and delightfully quiet. The bathroom had both a bath and a shower and lots of lovely products + candles  fresh flower (and the towels are from Frette...). The bed is just amazingly comfortable with fresh crisp linen - we're thinking of writing to Sofitel to ask where they got their beds from and buy the same one for our home!  Service was faultless, and both checking in and out was extremely quick. And of course the location is brilliant - minutes off Times Square and 5th avenue. Price-wise, it is expensive but then again everything is expensive in NYC. We paid the same price for the Hudson hotel last year and had a very disappointing stay there. You can get the best rates on the internet, especially if you book the non-refundable option. Only drawback of the whole stay: the price of the breakfast which we did not know about until we signed the check (and it was too late!) - USD45 for 1 continental breakfast + 1 coffee... extortionate! Once bitten, twice shy - we went to a nearby diner for the rest of our stay. But we'll definitely be back at the Sofitel.

<Author>LittleJan
<Content>Loved Sofitel My husband and I visit New York several times a year to visit our daughter. We stay in different hotels every time we go. This time we stayed at the Sofitel and although it was over and above what we would normally pay, it was worth every single cent. The staff are among the best we have encountered anywhere. Just walking through the lobby you know you are in for something very special. We had booked a Superior room, which is the cheapest, but there was nothing cheap about this room. The bed was the most comfortable we have slept in. The decor was understated elegance. The bathroom was amazing, not only a bath with shower, but an extremely large walk-in shower, enough for at least four people to shower at the same time! Only ever staying in 31/2 or 4 star hotels it is very unusual for room only hotels to have a turn down service at night. Not only were the beds turned down, but all the towels changed as well. They also supply big fluffy robes and slippers.....what more can you ask for. They also leave a note of what the weather will be like the next day....wow. Money permitting, we will definitely stay at the Sofitel again. All this and a five minute walk to Times Square.

<Author>Kitten22
<Content>This is an excellent hotel in a great location I chose this hotel based on tripadvisor comments and I have to agree with most of them - it's right in the centre of the city with all the tourist attractions close to hand. The beds are VERY comfortable but first room we were given was tiny, dark and had a lovely view of a brick wall/water tower!! since we were staying a week I asked for a room change and we were given another room which was huge, king size bed and a fabulous view of the ESB, so it's hit and miss what room your get. The Internet access in the foyer is great and the Red Flame diner for breakfast is a must.Try to enroll as a Sofitel member via their web site because the complimentary chocolates, evening turn down service and water is a nice touch but the late check out is definately worth it.Everywhere is very clean and tidy and everyone helpful especially the bar and door staff, one or two members of concierge were a little off but they were very busy.I would definately consider staying here again when visiting the city.

<Rating>5	4	4	-1	4	-1	4	-1	

<Author>rwpb-houston
<Content>We loved it!! We stayed at the Sofitel New York from 9/2 - 9/5/2005. We have stayed at many fine hotels and this one did not disappoint. It was a great home for us during our visit to NYC. The hotel is nicely tucked away from the crowds but still very close to Times Square, Rocefeller Plaza, Grand Central Station, subway access, etc.The lobby is elegant in an understated way - feels comfortable and approachable. There is a small computer room off the lobby with four computers and a printer with free internet access - this was a big plus! The front desk staff is friendly and efficient - very service oriented - they worked with us to find a room we liked - our first room had a very small window and felt claustrophobic. When we called down to complain the front desk clerk offered to come up and show us another room to see if we liked it better - very accommodating. The front desk is located near the elevators - we were greeted consistently when coming and going. The carpet in the elevators and the guest room corridors were the only things in the hotel that did not feel spotless - they always seemed like they needed to be vacuumed.The room we ended up in was a Deluxe Queen on the 21st floor which had a nice city view. Initially we were not sure about having a queen bed versus a king but it turned out to be a very comfortable room. The bed was fabulous just as others have mentioned in their reviews - felt like a layer of down under the sheet - there were feather pillows - two king size, two standard size - the down comforter and duvay were very cozy - although it was weird that there was no top sheet provided on the bed - we had to request a top sheet every day. All the bedding was very crisp, clean, fresh, high quality. The carpet in the room was soft and comfortable and also felt very clean. The art work was attractive. The bathroom was FABULOUS!! - felt very clean, fresh, updated, luxurious - attractive marble, shiny metal fixtures, separate shower, Frette bath linens, upscale French bath amenities. As others have mentioned the room was VERY QUIET - we did not hear any sirens, city traffic noise, etc while in our room which was very nice! The air conditioning in the room was also very quiet. Also a nice touch to have a Sony CD player/alarm clock - we brought some of our favorite CD's and enjoyed the music while in our room. The housekeepers kept the room clean and fresh twice a day and we never really noticed them - very discreet. Gaby's Restaurant was nice for breakfast - food quality was high, portions were nice - not too much or too little - coffee and orange juice were included in price of breakfast - $21 for American breakfast including 2 eggs, breakfast potatoes, wonderful fresh croissant, breakfast meat, coffee or tee, and juice. They automatically add 15% gratuity to all breakfast checks - that was strange. Anyway, it was a nice experience and worth the $50 for a special breakfast for two (although on day two the hotel was power washing the sidewalk right outside the windows of the restaurant - the noise was disturbing - not sure why they would choose to do that during the morning hours at breakfast time). The french press coffee was a nice touch but they leave the pot on the table and it gets cold too fast. We did enroll in the Sofitel Privilege Program before arriving and were offered a free drink when we checked in (although it was only ONE drink - strange since there were two of us).The concierge was dissapointing when compared with the rest of the experience. We dealt with three different concierge agents during our stay and found all three to be aloof. They did not seem very interested in helping, not very enthusiastic, not service oriented - a bit snobby. The bellmen and door staff also seemed aloof. Overall the hotel was impressive. The facility is modern and clean. The service at the front desk/ restaurant/ housekeeping is very good - the concierge/ bellmen/ door staff need work. We will definitely stay at Sofitel New York next time we visit.  
<Date>Sep 11, 2005

<Author>eprintmp
<Content>Excellent Value, Location and The BEDS, OH THE BEDS I am always skeptical about reviews on these sites as i always think they are written by the staff, especially when they rave about a hotel. I needed to go to NY for a wedding so I wanted to be centrally located within a good area so I opted for the SOFITEL. There was a bit of a mix up on the booking as they deducted 4 payments within 1 day, however this was rectified immediately. When we arrived they checked us in swiftly then sent us to our room. The hotel is very clean, very art deco with a modern feel. The rooms are a little on the small side, however I now know what they mean about all good things come in small packages. The bathroom is superb (the shower is heaven) the marble surround is very plush. My biggest criticism is always the Iron never works properly and the bed is uncomfortable. Well this was certainly not the case. The bed was out of this world the most comfortable I have ever slept in. The iron actually ironed a cotton shirt to perfection. The room service was prompt and the staff was very helpful to say the least. I could not really fault anything about the hotel except there was no laundry service on a Sunday, hence ironing my own shirt. Thanks Sofitel it was a great experience

<Author>Rocco46
<Content>I have never stayed in such a quiet hotel room! The first thing you notice when you step in to the lobby of the Sofitel New York is the silence: no car horns, no sirens, no sounds of the city whatsoever. Whoever designed the soundproofing for this building deserves some sort of award. Of all the hotels I have visited in Manhattan (quite a few), I have never experienced such a quiet room. We had reserved a queen room; the hotel very kindly upgraded us to a king, as we were celebrating our anniversary. By New York hotel standards the room was very spacious, but the bathroom was immense! There was a separate tub and a separate large shower. My wife raved about the personal products that were provided; she finally realized she remembered the soap from staying at the Sofitel in Paris over twenty years ago! I guess Sofitel finds something that works and stays with it.As others have commented, the bed was extraordinary. The housekeeping staff was never seen, yet our room was always spotless, even if we left for a short time. The entire hotel staff was very attentive to any need that arose. I can't imagine a better hotel experience. And I haven't even mentioned the location: close to Times Square and theaters, close to the subway, no wait for a taxi. Rockefeller Center, the Chrysler Building and the Empire State Building are all a short walk (a few blocks) away.We didn't visit Gaby (the restaurant), so I cannot comment on that; we did, however, order room service for breakfast one morning, which was fine.The only remotely negative comment I can make is the room had no hair dryer when we arrived. We called downstairs and someone was there in less than five minutes with a replacement and extensive apologies. He seemed genuinely astonished that the hair dryer had been removed.Other than that, our visit was absolutely perfect. I cannot recommend the Sofitel enough. We will definitely by staying again.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Almost Perfect First time poster, long time reader. Wanted to take my wife somewhere special for a little getaway. Everyone's helpful and informative posts through Trip Advisor led me to the Sofitel in NYC. A superb hotel that I wouldn't hesitate to visit again. As soon as you walk through the doors, you are greeted with the aroma of fresh cut flowers. The staff is all smiles, willing to do whatever it takes to make sure you are comfortable. The location is perfect. Times Square, Central Park, shopping, and fine dining are all so close that a Taxi isn't even a consideration. The room (King Bed Suite) was spacious, comfortable, and well appointed. The bathroom was enormous. And the bed...Ahhh yes, the bed. Let's just say that the Heavenly Beds that Westin hotels brag about, pale in comparison to the beds here. I don't think I moved from the position I started in all night.The only thing that I was disappointed with was the view from our room. When you book a king bed suite, the description on the web site boasts a Superb City View. Our view was far from superb on floor 5. The hotel did offer to inform us if anything came available, but we never received a call (not that we stayed in our room to wait for one). From other reviews that I've read, it sounds like the majority of the rooms have great views. Just make sure you emphasize that when you check in. I'll do that the next time I visit NYC, because I certainly plan on staying at the Sofitel again.

<Author>travelHI
<Content>A great experience! I stayed at the hotel for 8 nights at the end of July and early August. I based my decision to stay at this hotel by the reviews on this website. I was not disappointed. The staff, including the concierge, were professional, friendly, personable, and very helpful. I received a room upgrade (I was celebrating a marker birthday and this was acknowledged). Before I arrived, I talked with the hotel several times before booking to confirm details. I was pleasantly and efficiently serviced. I also called the concierge a few times asking for advice on what to see and for arranging theatre tickets. The service was personal and efficient. The rooms I had (I moved once from a lower level floor to a higher level floor) were large, clean, and nicely decorated. The marble bathroom, including the large acrylic shower stall, was modern and spacious. The make-up lights on the mirror were fantastic - the best I've ever experienced. The location was superb - just blocks to Times Square, the NY Public Library (try the free tour and use the wonderful reading rooms), Bryant Park (next to the library), the theatre district (what a joy to be able to walk to and from and not have to try and find an after-theatre cab), Central Park.... a great and safe location...By the way, I booked through expedia and got a great rate!

<Author>BroadwayMaven
<Content>Simply the Best First time stay at Sofitel. Our eight night stay more than met our expectations. Reviews on this site have cemented the superiority of the Sofitel and I am confirming the comments. From the moment you walk through the door until you leave the Sofitel is an oasis of calm and beauty. Our room was wonderfully appointed, and quiet. A/C works great and the beds are perfect for a great night's sleep. A wait of no longer than 5 seconds for an elevator (particularly important after many years at the Marriott Marquis whose nightmare elevators ended our stays there). The staff at Sofitel is helpful and tends to your every need. Concierge made several phone calls for us about restaurants in the Village and obtained hours of operation, location, etc. The privilege card is an added bonus and we each enjoyed a complimentary drink in the lovely Gaby lounge. Had lunch and dinner in Gaby restaurant, patio area is fabulous and you feel as if you are dining in a private garden. Service is impeccable at the Sofitel on all counts. The Sofitel is now our Signature Hotel for our trips to NYC. We have already booked two more stays this year. BTW, the Red Flame is definitely a must for a very good breakfast. Location of Sofitel is excellent, you can walk to all local sites and avoid the clamor of Times Square area. A truly joyful experience to stay of the Sofitel.  
<Date>Aug 10, 2005

<Author>Alanake
<Content>Great hotel I can only agree with the previous positive reviews. We've stayed in the Sofitel for 10 night and it was just perfect in every way.The rooms were spacious and very quiet, we never heard any noise coming from the hallway or the other rooms. The bathroom was wonderfull, very clean, large and it was nice to take a relaxing bath (with little candle provided by the hotel) in the evening. The entire hotel is beautifully decorated, very tasteful!The location is suberb, 10mins walk to Times Square, Fifth Av just around the corner, 15mins walk to the Empire State Building, perfect for visiting the city. It was great to walk into the calm lobby after a long day of visiting the city. I've never had to wait for an elevator so it didnt bother me at all that there was no airco in the hallway.We only dined in the hotel once since there are so many great restaurants in NY. For breakfast we went to the Red Flame (at the corner of 6th Av).I'm definitely coming back to this hotel!And as for the concierge: we found Vladimir extremely helpfull and friendly (although not in that typical American over the top way).

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Wonderful experience, even with some glitches My wife and I just returned from 4 nights at the Sofitel. We based our decision on the reviews from the TA website, and wanted to be close to Times Square. Our flight was delayed 2 hours, and because of Deltas Frequent Snorer program, sleep was not a possibility on our red-eye. We arrived at JFK at 6:30am, and by the time our cab made it through rush hour, we showed up at the front desk at about 8:00am. My wife (6 months pregnant) was spent. I asked if I could pay a day rate to check in early, and they said the hotel was full that evening. The manager overheard, took one look at my wife, and came over to assist. She found us a room, with a beautiful view of the Chrysler bldg, and offered it at no charge! +1 Sofitel!The room was fine. Very typical size, but very nicely appointed. +2 Sofitel!Delightful bed (we sleep on a tempur-pedic at home) +3, stunning bath room+4. The shower was so good we are now contacting the manf. of the showerhead to have one shipped and retrofitted to ours. +5!!!Location was amazing. So close to TS, but just as easy to the Today show, and then another block or two to 5th Ave shopping. +6Staff was great from them moment we checked in. Very accomidating, and very personal. Always a smile to greet you even when you are walking by. +7.The lobby is stunning, and in general the decor was A++++, +8 Our flight was late afternoon, and a late checkout was no problem. +8.5 Sofitel !!!!Now the glitches...Yes, we got our bottled water about half the time, and if we were in our room during turndown time, the housekeeper never came back, the doorman was a tad preoccupied, and Gaby's was overpriced. Our stay included free breakfast and we only ate there 2 of our 4 days, even though it was free. The juice is $5/glass, and frankly, for $10, the Red Flame breakfast was better, in our opinion. And true, for some reason, the hallway to our room was toasty, yet our room could feel like the southpole if we had the thermostat set below 70. We kept it on automatic 72 and it was pleasant the whole trip. If you think the hallway is hot, try the ice room by the stairs.. wow!I got a kick out of the room service menu, mostly because a Red Bull is $18. I love NYC for stuff like that!All in all... with all the glitches... -1 Sofitel. No big deal! Everything that mattered was perfect. The things that we didn't expect made up for everything else. The hotel, staff and location are incredible, and when we return, we'll stay there again.  
<Date>Aug 3, 2005
<Rating>5	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	-1	

<Author>Karen055
<Content>Well worth the money My teenage son and I stayed at the Sofitel for 7 nights in July 2005. The day after having made and paid for my reservations, I was alarmed to read a couple of negative/so-so reviews of the Sofitel. I had chosen this hotel based on previous reviews, and then these appeared. I am delighted to report that our experience was nothing but positive. Our room was large (for New York), clean and comfortable. The beds and pillows were perfect, and the linens clean and fresh. I usually travel with my pillow because I have such difficulty sleeping with hotel pillows, but had forgotten it this time, so the pillow review is especially meaningful. As mentioned in many other reviews, the bathroom was wonderful. In fact, my son liked it so much I had to remind him at one point that we hadn't come to NY to spend a week in the bathroom taking showers.The service from staff was prompt and courteous. When I mentioned to a front desk clerk that my son had loved the chocolates (sign up for the Sofitel privilege card beforehand!) and was disappointed that they weren't going to be delivered nightly, he saw to it that more were sent up that night (at no charge). On our first night there I heard a high-pitched sound coming from the A/C vent, and knowing I wouldn't be able to sleep with that going, I called the front desk to complain. Within 5 minutes a custodian came to the room and quickly fixed it. So much for my hopes of being upgraded to a suite! We did not use the conceriege service, so I cannot comment on that, but whatever service we did need was provided with a smile. The location of the hotel is excellent for access to everything, either by walking, subway, bus, or taxi. For breakfast we liked the nearby Cafe Europa (5th Ave.) and Cafe Manhattan (W. 45th St.). Yes, the hallway outside the elevators on the floor (17th) was not air conditioned, but on the other hand, we never had to wait more than 30 seconds for an elevator. All in all, I think the hotel is a superior choice. It is a 4-star, so those expecting 5-star ameneties may be disappointed, but we definitely were not. And, by the way, I do not work for Sofitel and am in no way connected with the chain.

<Author>RichardS404
<Content>Good, but far from Wow My girlfriend and I stayed at Sofitel on July 23rd and 24th during a quick little getaway to NYC. Most personnel were quite friendly and accomodating, the lobby is quite nice, and I appreciated the free internet room off the lobby. One very annoying detail was the Lack of Air Conditioning In The Hotel Hallway! If I am being naive, please tell me, but I have travelled all over the world and stayed in a great many hotels. Never have I paid $300 and had to sweat while waiting for the elevator - NYC was in the mid-90's during our stay. Bizarre, but the couple from Boca in the room next door (who apparently paid close to $600 for a room that was just a tad larger) were neither shocked nor put off by this. Whatever. Workout room is decent, no pool, no jacuzzi, no sauna. Concierge is a passive aggressive guy who does things sequentially and slowly. Bell staff were quite nice. large stain in carpet in the room (pretty unacceptable even to rent a room with this problem, I feel, but the bell guy offered us another room, which we declined. bathroom clean, room otherwise pretty nice, but small. I did use my privelige card and got a 4pm checkout, as well as a small box of chocolates and 2 bottles of evian - nobody said anything about the free drink at the bar, which is promised, and I didn't ask. I was told by the older couple that I got a great deal (259 I think, plus a boatload of tax), and I guess I did okay. I like being wowed, though. Maybe you can't do that in New York for these prices, however.

<Author>RJS&Gale

<Rating>4	4	4	-1	4	-1	4	-1	

<Author>enn25
<Content>Well worth the money My husband and I stayed at Sofitel for our 10th anniversary and we were extremely satisfied with the hotel. After reading some of the not-so-hot recent reviews, we were worried. Not to worry...everything was perfect with Sofitel. Before we arrived, we asked for early check-in and a high-floor room. When we arrived at noon, a room on the 22nd floor was waiting for us. However, because there were no Executive King Suites at the time we booked directly with the hotel, we asked if they had any cancellations since our booking and if so, could we upgrade to one from our Premier Queen room. They found a King on the 20th floor that we had to wait for but we didn't mind since it would be free of charge. We later found out that they had moved us without a fuss, even though they had already set up champagne and chocolate-covered strawberries in the first room. The champagne was a nice touch from the hotel and the strawberries were sent from a friend.When we got into our room, we had a nice view to the side of the Chrysler Building and could see part of the top of the Empire State Builidng. The room was nicely decorated, not too modern and none of the furniture was shabby (as one past reviewer mentioned). The room was fairly big for a hotel room in a big city and the carpet looked and felt clean even walking on it barefooted. Strangely though, the room was not a suite even though the bed was a king bed. We had assumed that it would be a suite with it's own sitting room since a past reviewer had mentioned that the only way to get a king bed was to book a suite. I don't think that's the case now. The bed was absolutely comfortable!!! I like firm beds and my husband likes softer beds. For some reason, we BOTH had no problems sleeping in comfort on this bed. The spacious bathroom was extremely clean, with the marble floor so clean that I didn't feel like I had to lay down towels or use slippers while standing bare footed. There is a separate bathtub and a separate shower which is nice since you don't have to step over the side of a tub to get into the shower. The water pressure was adequate and the toiletries they had were nice enough. I would recommend you bring your own hair conditioner if you use it regularly to get out tangles. The hair conditioner they provided never did the trick. The lighting was great in the bathroom, especially with the lights surrounding the entire mirror...great for when you were putting on your make-up or shaving. Unlike a previous reviewer, our air conditioning for the room worked extremely well and was a blessing when we would come back after a day of sightseeing in the heat and humidity. Oddly though, we noticed that the hotel cools the lobby areas nicely but only cooled the hallway of our floor at a minimum. The lobby area was so nicely cooled that you could sit there for hours. Plus, Sofitel provides guests with access to three computers and a printer 24 hours a day in their lobby. This was wonderful for getting Broadway tickets at the last minute (sign up for free membership to Playbill and you'll get discounts or check Craigslist for last minute tickets) and for checking in and printing out your airline boarding pass the night before you depart.For the $289 a night we paid, we were extremely happy with Sofitel. We've stayed in much worse for the price. The hotel is in great shape and it truly is within walking distance to everything...2 blocks to Time Square and the theaters and 3 blocks the opposite direction to Grand Central Station where you can take the subway to all tourist areas. It's even easier to hail a cab from Sofitel than say if you stayed at a busier hotel in or closer to Time Square where you have to compete with others for a taxi at busy commute times. P.S. Try to get Broadway tickets to Spamalot...it was costly but SOOO worth it. Also, do NOT buy the New York City Pass which offers admission for several museums and attractions for one price for a set number of days. We barely recovered the money we spent for the passes because you just couldn't do too much with the lines and the crowds. The pass claims that you get to bypass the ticket lines at some of the attractions. True, you don't have to wait in the TICKET lines at some places but you will have to wait in the line for those people like you who purchased the pass. These lines were almost as long as the ticket lines! For example, we could have used the computer kiosks (no lines) for purchasing admission tickets at the Museum of Natural History but since it was covered in our pass, we waited in a long line. And at the Empire State Building, we had to wait in line with everyone who was buying tickets. If we didn't have the pass, we could have spent a little more money and purchased Express tickets that allowed you to bypass all the lines or move to the front of the lines (i.e., security check).  
<Date>Jul 26, 2005
<Rating>5	5	5	-1	5	-1	4	-1	

<Author>DonnaMark
<Content>Fine Hotel First time visitors to NYC for a romantic fling, my wife and I booked the Sofitel based on reviews from this site. Not disappointed at all. Red Flame, a few doors toward TS + the only real option for breakfast, was delicious, fast, and coffee cups constantly filled. Helpful to us could have been info re: best was to get Broadway tix, tours, recommended deli's, nearby sites (Bryant Park is a jewel and only two blocks away), etc. Would we stay at Sofitel again? Yes!

<Author>Jugdish
<Content>Great, Service, Great Room, Great Choice This hotel is definetly worthy of the rave reviews. The location is fantastic, easy to get everywhere, but not in the middle of chaos. The rooms are nicely decorated, not gaudy and not overly modern. The bathroom is above what I expected with a separate marble shower and tub and a marble top sink. However, I will say this is what I expect in a hotel in this price range ($250+/night). Front desk was extremely accomodating in giving us a room with a view of the chrysler building when asked. Worth noting, however, is not all rooms are outfitted with feather beds and down comforters as noted in other reviews. All suites and King rooms have them, but only scattered queen rooms do. Our first room had a normal hotel polyester bed setup, not what I would expect for this price, so I called the front desk and they came and changed our linens, no questions asked. Overall a great place to stay.

<Author>Finicky_one
<Content>Sofitel was a good choice ! We stayed at the Sofitel for one night 7/16. I think we made the right choice.This is one of those places that will not wow you with any one thing but it's a very subtle, understated, sleek, classy non-toursity hotel. We had a Delux queen room. The room was very clean - loved the bathroom - all granite and shower is great. You can even listen to the tv while you are in the bathroom - they have speakers - nice touch. The bed was comfortable too. The staff is very polite and helpful. This was our first time at this hotel. We requested an early check-in and late check-out. When we got there at 12 noon, the room was ready but since we requested higher floor, we said we would wait. 2 pm check out was arranged - no questions asked. The concierge (both) were very helpful in recommending restaurants, making and even canceling the reservations. The location is very good - easy access to all the restaurants, shopping etc - walking distance - just take comfortable shoes - my girlfriend didnt and she had blisters on her feet. Good overall experience - decent value for money - we pd $259 for our room - not bad since its NYC theater district ! I guess I am rating it as 4 stars coz we were on the other side so we didn't have a view of the Chrysler building - GE bldg is not bad to look at but still, it ain't no Chrysler ! :)Jay HRichmond, VA

<Author>boo2ting
<Content>Above and beyond We stayed at the Sofitel for two nights and experienced incredible service. Having booked a premier Queen room, we were upgraded to a deluxe King room. I had emailed ahead of time to let them know that it was a special occasion (husband's first art opening in NYC), and that we would be arriving at 8am on a redeye. In my email I asked to store our luggage upon arrival, and if possible (it was a longshot) to check in early. To our surprise, when we arrived at the hotel at 8am as planned, they had the upgraded room ready for us! And they didn't charge us for an extra night, as is usually the case when you check in that early. We took a nice luxurious nap in the extremely comfy King size bed before heading out into the city later that day. Our entire stay was wonderful, the food at Gaby's is very good (if pricey) and the location is right in the heart of Times Square. We have stayed at four-star hotels in NYC several times, and have never received such warm and generous service. I would highly recommend this hotel to anyone traveling to NYC.

<Author>spiffdeb
<Content>Always a great experience I almost always stay at the Sofitel when I am in NYC. It is well-maintained, the rooms are pretty good size by NY standards and the service is efficient and polite. I like the vibe here. It is not touristy - lots of repeat visitors and business travelers (like me) stay here. The bathrooms in particular are really nice. The lighted closets are a great touch. The beds are very comfortable as well. The property is well-maintained. The Roger  Galliet bath accessories are also very nice. The Sofitel is a great hotel for the price! I have the opportunity to stay at many upscale and boutique hotels and I like the Sofitel almost as well as any of them for a whole lot less money! If you want the all-out experience and don't mind paying for it then you should definitely go to the Four Seasons. If you want the same vibe and to save a few $$, check out the Sofitel.

<Author>wise2374
<Content>Elegant and lovely European style hotel My wife and I just celebrated our fifth wedding anniversary at the Sofitel. Unlike a previous reviewer, we did receive acknowledgement and some special treatment, with an upgrade to a suite on a high floor. We were staying on a Saturday night, however, and it's likely there was plenty of availability.The hotel has elegant and sleek public spaces, with a very nice lobby and front desk area. It certainly has a European/French feel to it, with French TV channels and everything written in both English and French. Our suite was well-apportioned, with terrific fixtures, including an incredibly cozy and handsome bed, and gorgeous bathroom and shower area. Otherwise, I'd call the rest of the room understatedly elegant and modern, with handsome fixtures all around.I like the location in that it isn't in the heart of Times Square, but was an easy walk to it, and is also convenient to the Theater District. Because the hotel is further east of both of those areas, it's got a touch less hustle and bustle, and just feels like a less touristed area. Don't get me wrong - it's still midtown New York City, but being a few blocks east of those other areas make it a more relaxed setting. Plus, catching a taxi down Fifth is an easy shot to Greenwich Village which, given the NYC traffic patterns, is nice.Because I live in NYC, I don't stay in New York hotels much, it's hard to compare the Sofitel to the nicer hotels here. But relative to the upscale business hotels I normally stay in in other cities, this is really a lovely hotel, and I do recommend it. You just can't go wrong with a place this nice.

<Author>fotocoquine
<Content>Upscale hotel in convenient location My husband and I just celebrated our 20th anniversary at the Sofitel. The rooms were immaculate and comfortable with an elegant bathroom stocked with great products. Towels were changed twice daily. The room was quiet from street noise and we did not hear noise from neighboring rooms, but we were awakened by loud people in the hallway at 2am. Though not the hotel's fault, consideration would have been nice.I asked if there were any rooms with views, but we were given a room on the 21st floor overlooking 44st Street (no real view). I don't know if they had control over that, but I didn't feel that they put in any special effort, given the fact that we told them months in advance when we reserved that it was an anniversary. Maybe it is too large a hotel for that kind of attention to detail, as I've seen in smaller hotels.The concierge was very helpful, as was the doorman who hailed a cab for us in the rain. After our dinner, we walked back to the hotel from the Village, which was fun.Sunday morning, the Puerto Rican parade originated in front of the hotel. It was interesting to see the floats up close, and we didn't have trouble leaving the city that afternoon (as I expected when I saw the crowds!) The Red Flame diner was a quick and inexpensive breakfast. We had an easy walk up to MoMA.We signed up for the privilege card and took advantage of the late check out which was very convenient. That alone makes it worthwhile. No one mentioned a free drink at the bar, so we didn't take advantage of that. I had obtained a good rate through a Playbill offer, but when I went to check out, I was charged the wrong rate. After some time they corrected it, but did not apologize. I would stay here again, because it was very convenient and well-maintained.  
<Date>Jun 16, 2005
<Rating>5	3	5	-1	5	-1	4	-1	

<Author>symmie
<Content>The Sofitel.....The Best My husband and I just returned from 4 days in NYC staying at the Sofitel. Words cannot describe how thrilled we were with the hotel services and our executive king room. We had requested and given an early check-in (10:00 a.m.) and from then on everything was perfect. Our suite, on the 26th floor, was spotless, spacious, quiet and luxurious. We normally stay in a suite but the Sofitel's was above expectation. Very expensive, but worth it. After a hectic day, it was so nice to walk two blocks from the busy Times Square streets to the quiet, out of the way, hotel. I originally was booked at the Marriott Marquis, basically because of the location, but after reading all the reviews determined that the Sofitel would be an ideal location for two people wanting peace and quiet after a busy day. Quiet it was! Only on one occasion did we see a housekeeper and never saw another guest on our floor, although the hotel was booked. There were only 8 rooms on our floor and no door noise, kids running down halls, no elevator noise, etc. Just tranquility! We felt as if we were a zone away from a very busy world. Housekeeping seemed to always know when we were out of our room, for both morning service and turn down service. I highly recommend spending the extra money for a stay at this hotel. Also, in a cornor suite, the views from both very large floor to ceiling windows were spectacular. Gaby's bar is a great place to wind down with a before dinner drink. Food was good at the restaurant although we only had dinner there on one occasion. GREAT HOTEL....!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Overated but you get a good nights sleep My partner and I stayed at the end of April in this hotel. The hotel is situated in a good location, especially for Broadway and Times Square.The hotel has an impressive exterior and a beautiful eleganty designed entrance hall.The reception staff were very helpful and courteous during our stay.Our room was fairly high up with an unpleasant view of an avenue, but in New York you're only in your room to sleep and we got our best sleep ever staying here.The room was on the small side for New York but the bed was one of the best we have tried , and we have tried alot of beds! The bathroom was lovely and the shower was great for shower voyeurs. It was sort of fixed to the end of the bath, so that if you had a bath you could watch your partner shower. Those that have been will know what I mean.Hotel facilities are what you would expect for a New York Hotel of this standard but the toiletries were nothing special.We went to the Red Diner next door and found it filled a hole, however we found nicer places than this for our Breakfast.New York is excellent and we will definitely go again. We highly recommend the Comedy Cellar for a great night out, Central Park - the squirrels are so tame, Brooklyn Bridge and Brooklyn for the sunset view of Manhatten.We enjoyed our stay at the Sofitel and anyone who stays there will have a pleasant time, but we find it hard to believe that it is No 1 in New York.

<Rating>5	3	5	-1	5	-1	4	-1	

<Author>Schmaltzy
<Content>The Sofitel really deserves to be the top hotel in New York. We stayed at the Sofitel May 12 - May 19 for 7 nights in a deluxe room. I did a lot of research before I chose my hotel as I wanted somewhere really romantic and special. Tripadvisor reviews helped me choose the Sofitel and I don't regret it. I passed a lot of other top hotels while in New York and they certainly did not look nearly as nice.I highly recommend the Sofitel hotel and here's why:-The rooms are beautifully decorated, romantic and luxurious. The rooms still feel very new (which may be unusual in New York). The rooms were certainly large enough and I cannot see any need for a suite. We had plenty of storage areas for both our clothes. The beds are also very comfy. I would have put some photos on but they are identical to the ones already available and identical to the photos on the Sofitel website.-I booked a deluxe room (one with a view). The view was well worth the extra money. We had a view of the Chrysler building, which when lit up at night is beautiful. On a couple of evenings we ordered room service, dimmed the lights, opened the curtain and put on some romantic music. This was probably the most romantic meal to be had in the whole of New York.-The marble bathroom (with shower and bath) is everything you would expect of a top hotel. The shower is hot and powerful and I found it very relaxing after a day traipsing around New York.-The staff are extremely attentive, prompt, friendly and polite. The door staff were always on hand opening doors and getting cabs. Whenever I called room service or any other staff someone arrived very promptly. Maid service is very good and twice a day.-Location is good (20 minutes to Central Park, 2 mins Time Square and 10minutes from nearly every shop). That said, my ideal location would be nearer central park and not so near Time Square. -The lobby and gym look wonderful.-You cannot hear any other rooms or outside from the rooms in the Sofitel. Again I think this is unusual in New York.Other points:-I arranged a Sofitel card before I arrived and so I got a late check out (although I had to ask twice).-If you want a high floor (some room prices are not for a high floor so I don't think you will get one) ask for one, I asked for the 27th floor and got it.-Room service is 24 hours which is very handy when you are too exhausted to leave the room. The food is nice.-As with many Tripadvisors mentioned, the Red Flame Diner next door offers a very good breakfast.-For anyone worried about snobbery, don't... we were young AND in jeans all week and were treated very nicely!-Traveller's tip: book the tour of the statue of liberty (to go inside) in advance otherwise even if you turn up early you may only be able to visit the island.-Traveller's tip: If you are a foreign visitor in Macy's go to the visitor's centre on the 1st floor for an 11% discount card.Drawbacks:-Its not cheap so book early and use the internet to reduce the cost.-For some reason there was an occasional noise in our room, possibly the air con. It didn't really bother me, but I guess it could be a draw back.-The hotel is not really a social place with a lively bar, so if you need somewhere like that I hear that the Hudson is better.-There is very slight wear and tear in the rooms, again I think it is probably far better than any other older hotels (the Sofitel is only 5 years old).Overall I would rate this hotel as luxurious with excellent service and staff and beautiful rooms.  
<Date>May 25, 2005
<Rating>5	4	5	-1	5	-1	5	-1

<Author>WI-Couple

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Sofitel visit met expectations My wife and I booked Sofitel through Expedia and enjoyed our 3-d stay. Impeccably clean, deco-type rooms with nice illumination around the bathroom mirror, and a great shaviing mirror. The size was certainly adequate for a hotel room in NYC (we have stayed in rooms at other hotels that more approximated closets). Having booked through Expedia, we were not eligible for the continental breakfast , and, warned ahead of time, we avoided the restaurant, which was pricey, and made good use of the Red Lion Cafe mid-way down the street. The small knob on the bathroom door fell off but was replaced. We stored a small container of milk in the Frigo-Bar (as they are called in Gemany), and just displacing an item caused it to be billed; on complaint, the charge was removed and a refrigerator was then brought in for our needs during the stay. This was all gratis, as were the little slippers supplied. The only thing we missed was a Bible in the room, which, we were told by a clerk at check-out, is offensive to some people (of course its absence could equally be offensive), but we were assured that they were available for anyone requesting them. A small complaint is that I could succeed, even with help from the hotel operator, in placing a local call (no problem for long distance!).The hotel, is, as far as we could see, in almost every way, first class. The wonderfully quiet room, convenient location, and excellent service make it well-worth its cost.

<Author>hjdklhsrijeua
<Content>Great!!!! Just returned from the Sofitel and I can not recommend this hotel enough. Its in a great location which allows you to walk almost anywhere. The Bathrooms are really nice with a seperate shower. I would recommend this hotel to anyone. There's a diner just down the road called the red flame, very reasonably priced - good for breakfasts! The staff at the hotel were always willing to help and very friendly.If anyone wants to go to the theatre do not purchase tickets before hand. There's a kiosk in times square and they sell tickets for the day at a 50% discount. We went on the day we wanted to see the show at 4pm (show was at 8pm) there were hardly any queues and got brillant seats for half price.A must go to restaurant for steak lovers is Smiths  Wollensky's. <Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Sleepy but Happy at Sofitel We stayed at the Sofitel for four nights in early March while doing the NYC tourist thing. The location is great - within walking distance of lots of the museums and attractions. We walked everywhere.The exterior of the hotel isn't too impressive, but the lobby and check in area are polished and chic. Marble floors, plush chairs, fireplaces... you get the picture. The staff was polite, friendly and professional. We had a very early flight into NYC andthe front desk allowed us to check in early, making two tired travellers very happy.  Our room was clean, clean, clean, which I loved. It did smell a little detergent-y when we arrived. It got better with time - or maybe I got used to the sanitized scent.The beds are not big (queen-size), but the bathroom was amazing - all marble, great lighting (I swear, I've never looked that good!), a big glass shower and a nice-sized bathtub. Our room was a bit small yet comfortable. The decor was subdued - very modern and sleek. The only item I missed was a plush comforter. The bed had only a thick bedspread that was a little too unwieldy for sleeping.We stayed on the 27th floor and I would suggest requesting a higher floor. There was very little street noise and the walls were thick enough we never once heard our neighbors.All in all, we liked the Sofitel - a lot. We'd happily stay there again.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Rated highly for a reason Based on other reviews on the TripAdvisor site, I booked a stay at the NYC Sofitel for March 2005. Just 3 blocks from Times Square and the heart of the Theatre District, the hotel is in a wonderful location. Also on the block are the Red Flame Diner, a quintessential New York diner with comfort food at good prices, and the Times Deli, a great stop for a take-back-to-the-room sandwich or a muffin for breakfast. (The lemon cake is superb!) But I digress - back to the hotel. The room was a bit larger than most NYC hotels that I have stayed at, and was clean and nicely appointed. The bathroom was enormous, with a wonderful walk-in shower and separate tub. Very nice. The hotel seemed quiet, with no room-to-room noise. I also appreciated the ice machine on every floor. The staff was attentive but unobtrusive, and I would stay here again with pleasure, if I could again find a rate more reasonable than the rack rate quoted on their website.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Great Service - Average Beds The Sofitel is a wonderful place to stay unless a really comfortable bed is important to you. Their beds are just average, their pillows below average. The sheets are 100% cotton, but the blankets are velux (yuk) and the duvet is polyester. PLUSES:-Wonderful location - close to Fifth Avenue and the Theatre District.-Fantastic bathroom, marble, glass, soaking tub, separate shower, large luxurious towels and robes. Bath products are Roger  Gallet, slippers are provided.-Service is fast, very friendly and gracious. We were shown three different suites until we found the one we liked.-Tall windows that open at the bottom. Great views available on the higher floors.MINUSES:-Beds are not that comfortable. Too bad because everything else at the hotel is very high quality.-In order to get a king bed you have to get a suite. -No drawers for clothing. You have to use shelves and a very small closet.One tip - go to the Sofitel website and get a free Accor Privilege Card. This entitles you to a free drink per person, chocolate, Evian and 4:00 pm checkout.

<Author>WarrenBer
<Content>Disappointing and not what NYC is all about After reading all the great reviews here, I decided to give the Sofitel a try. I travel to NYC every 2 months and have always stayed at Starwood Hotels (Westin, W). They are roughly the same price which makes them a good base to compare against. The first thing I noticed about the Sofitel is that it is looking quite shabby in parts. Something you do not expect from a hotel which is only a few years old. I had a suite on the 29th floor which was a nice size and pleasantly furnished, but only had enough cupboard space for one person. One of us had to leave our clothes in the suitcase. Not what you would expect from a suite. The bathrooms and beds are very nice, but do not compare to the Westin's heavenly bed and shower. The products in the bathroom are great, but the staff are very slow to replace them. I cannot really falter the rooms, but then I also cannot find anything about them to really rave about.My biggest disappointment with the Sofitel is that it has no ENERGY. New York City is all about energy and the hotel was completely dead over a weekend when it should be buzzing with life. Not something you would expect in a highly rated hotel. We had drinks at The Peninsula one evening and it was alive and buzzing. It was quite depressing when we got back to the Sofitel and once again found a handful of people scattered amongst the foyer lounge and bar. It was as if only a handful of rooms were occupied, but the staff ensured us that the hotel was almost full.My suggestion is that if you like the energy of NYC and want the same from a hotel, do not stay here. If you are looking for a very quite hotel where you see a scatter of people in and out, then this is the perfect place for you.

<Author>MorganB
<Content>Another perfect stay at the Sofitel We just completed another stay at the Sofitel. We moved from there to the Millenium Hilton because i had some HHonors points to use. Despite the Millenium Hilton being a nice hotel the Sofitel excels in many ways. As we are staying back to back in the two I thought I would offer a comparison.Bathrooms are much better at the Sofitel. They are truly beatiful, with a seperate glassed in shower, marble floors and granite counter tops. Hiltons bath is very average with a shower curtain over the tub (ick!). Hiltons shower control had 2 inch in red and blue that say HOT COLD. Its very tacky/ institutional.Towels in the Sofitel are thick and absorbant. You can also lounge around in the provided robe and slippers. Towels are nice at the hiton but not as thick, no robe, no slippers. Bath Products in the Sofitel are Roger et Gallet. I love them and stock up on them at every stay. I also find the sewing kit handy. Hilton offers Neutrogena which is okay but I am not compelled to keep them, no sewing kit in sight.AC unit in the sofitel well conceled in the ceiling and cools the rooms swiftly. The Hilton has a large metal unit under the window. The AC happens to be out in the entire hotel today.Despite the two hotels being about the same price I find the Sofitel much more luxurious.

The nightly turn down service was awesome, and included a freshly cleaned bathroom stocked with fresh towels. The bathrooms at the Sofitel are beautiful and the towels are large, thick, and soft. I could not have asked for a better experience at any hotel. I will be returning agian with friends soon!

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Perfect, as expected We booked 4 nights at the Soffitel seeing all the positive reviews. And we were not disappointed!!! We arrived at 11am in the morning hoping to be able to put our bags with the Concierge. Instead they offered us a room!!! That was very nice considering that the check-in time is at 3pm. We really appreciated this. (We did have the Soffitel Privilege Card)Everything in the room was very well organized. The room was very clean and had all the amenities. The only thing we could have used was a coffee maker. But not critical at all. We were also given 2 free drinks and chocolates the first night.The bathroom was big, spacious and had all the little knick-knacks one needs. Cosmetics were all french, a bonus for those who prefer french toiletries.The service at every level was impeccable and helped to make the stay very very pleasureable.Although room service was expensive, there were a number of very good restaurants within walking distance to the hotel. As a tourist, the subway was very close, shopping at 5th avenue was 2 mins away, and the museums were either within walking distance or a short subway ride away. The location was excellent.And yes, I would recommend this hotel to all my friends. And we would stay there agian when we went to NYC.

<Author>A TripAdvisor Member
<Content>Sofitel an easy sell ! Just returned from an excellent break at the Sofitel New York, my husband and I booked a suite which was on the 26th floor directly with the Hotel. We stayed from Friday 1 April to Monday 4 April 2005. We also completed the privilege card which allowed for a late check out (4pm)  complimentary drinks. The service was fast and friendly from beginning to end, and the hotel well located for shops, museums etc. The decor was great as was the view!The suite was a good size,equipped with iron and board !Breakfast in the Gaby Restaurant was also good, but there are sooo many places to eat that you cant go wrong!If you are going before June 2005, spend an evening at the Belesco Theatre, 3 minute walk, where Julius Caesar is running, starring Denzel Washington and British Actor Eamon Walker. The whole cast was excellent! Shopping in New York is good, we walked everywhere and did not feel intimidated in any way.I will be returning later this year and the Sofitel will be my first choice , thank you to previous write ups for assisting us in making such a good choice which is why I am doing one in return !

<Author>PeterK939
<Content>Truly Magnificent I booked the Sofitel based (after exhaustive research) on the reviews here, and it really does deserve the reputation it's earned here. This review applies to a suite - I splashed out this one time as it was a special occasion. Good accomodation is something I place great importance on - it's great to just crash out sometimes and watch a movie for a few hours - the Sofitel surpassed this expectation in every measurable sense.Rooms are absolutely luxurious - they look identical to the pictures on their site (something that's very rare these days). Attention to detail is extraordinary; mini Hi-fi, CD clock radio, travel adapter in room, bathrobes, slippers, candle in bathroom (along a little box with a nail file, shower cap and some mints), separate shower, silk coat hangers; there was even an umbrella provided in the closet.Location is perfect - 5th Ave (including Met Life building) on one side; Times Square is a few blocks away on the other, but it's still in a very quiet spot. The room was totally soundproof; I never heard any street noise, and couldn't even tell if there was anyone in the room next to me - it's the first hotel I've stayed in for a long time where I've had a proper nights sleep.Staff go out of their way to help their guests - nothing is too much trouble. Just to give an idea of the high quality service - on the first night, there was some ambient noise from the air conditioning in the room. When I asked to change rooms the following morning, the receptionist brought to a suite that had an even better view of the Empire State building. When transferring the bags to the new room, he not only insisted on carrying both (heavy) bags, but would not accept a tip for the trouble - that truly is first class service. The only problem after that was that I didn't want to leave the room !All in all, fabulous; if like myself, good accomodation is of great importance, don't hesitate to book the Sofitel - I know I won't next time.

<Author>simeon_1
<Content>Sorry to be unoriginal but..... Yes i'm afraid i am going to write a similar review to every other one posted on this hotel.We had booked a King Suite for a 3 night stay over Easter on the back of the recommendations on this page and as you would expect me to say,we were not disappointed.A beautiful hotel with great sized rooms and everything you need to have a beautiful stay and probably the world's most comfortable bed.My wife and I had stopped in a suite at the Bellagio in Las Vegas earlier this year and there wasn't any difference in the quality or the service at all and all this on top of being in the middle of everything.We were delayed by 5 hours on the way out so were worn out by the time we got to the hotel as it was very late,it was a pleasant surprise then that it took us all of about 30 seconds to check in with the exceptionally friendly staff on reception.I asked for a room with a view of The Chrysler Building and The Empire State to which i was told that the views from this room were exceptional but if we were not happy in any way at all just ask and we would be moved.When we woke up early the next morning we didn't have views of either building but even though it was made clear that we could move we are not the fussy type and were more than happy with our room anyway so we stayed put.The fact that the offer to move was enough,you really couldn't fault the attitude of the staff,it was first class.We did go to the Red Flame every morning for breakfast and,as everyone says,it is great.A real old school,friendly place just 4 doors down from the front entrance to the hotel but get in there before 9am otherwise you'll have to wait a while.I can also recommend a deli on the same side of the street as the entrance(the back of the hotel) to Gaby,the hotel's retaurant about 5 doors down,everything you needed in there.Also the worlds best Pizza parlour was opposite the entrance to Gaby,a place called Little Italy,it has been voted New York's best pizza place and if you have a slice you can tell why.A great hotel,great location and everything taken care of so you don't need to worry.We would definitely stay at the Sofitel again if we go back to New York.

<Author>Dave0365
<Content>The most perfect hotel in NYC - location,charm,amenities I can simply say that anytime we return to NYC, this is where we will stay. I cannot imagine a better hotel for: location (peacefully quiet and only a 2 block walk down 44th and you are in Times Sq), ammenities (imagine a large king bedroom with perfect A/C, a good sized bathroom with seperate bath and shower and great toiletries and this in NYC?), staff (always friendly and polite with a ready smile), facilities (4 elevators and our maximum wait was about 15 seconds!!!, quiet bar/lounge, plenty of quality umbrellas for use).We arrived on the red-eye from San Francisco at 6:00 am on Sunday morning and were at the hotel by 7:00 am. Although room checkin is usually 3:00 pm and the hotel was FULL the previous night, they were able to get us a room by midday.I recommend breakfast each day 3 doors down at The Red Flame diner - cheap but nice and not rushed. We didn't use the hotel restaurant for eating, though we had a couple of night cap cocktails that were nice and not overly expensive (I do recommend the 8th floor lounge at the Marriott on Times Sq for cocktails and Tapas).Cabs are convenient because they are EVERYWHERE however a cheaper alternative is the subway. The nearest subway entry is 42nd and 5th - 3 streets down - a great/safe way to explore the city for $7 a day jumping on and off as often as you like. Greyline bus tours is located on 46th and 8th - again a short walk.I could go on and on about the benefits of this hotel, but that would only duplicate other reviews. Go on, just do it!

<Author>Simian-Gait
<Content>Excellent Hotel - Excellent location My wife  I have just returned from a 4 night stay at the Sofitel (9th - 13th March '05). Our decision on booking this hotel was primarily based upon TripAdvisor reviews and I'm glad to say the good reviews are accurate.The staff were polite  friendly and there was a distinct french feeling about the place (possibly being greeted with bonjour  bonsoir each day!). The lobby/reception areas were spacious and very smart. There were 4 lifts which were very quick, so not much hanging around. The concierges  doormen were helpful - in fact the concierge organised our transfer back to the airport with SuperShuttle.The room was excellent - spacious, clean, tastefully decorated and being on the 27th floor, we had a magnificent view with a window that went from floor to ceiling. The room was quiet and even with the window open it wasn't too noisy. Didn't use the TV except for the TV Internet facility ($10.95 for 24hrs) which was useful for checking emails  info on Broadway shows, Heliport flights etc etc). The bathroom was a good size with separate bath and shower cubicle and all fitted to a high standard.Hotel location was also excellent. It felt as though it was in a very safe area on 44th street halfway between 5th  6th avenues. Very close to Grand CT, Time Square, Rockefeller Center and so on. Didn't try the Hotel restaurant so can't comment on it, but there is a great diner (The Red Flame) about 30 metres along the street that opens at 6:00am and serves all your breakfast needs at reasonable prices.The Sofitel isn't necessarily a cheap hotel, but worth the extra to have somewhere decent to crash out after a busy day. Would certainly consider staying here again on our next visit - can't think of any reason not to.  
<Date>Mar 15, 2005
